contextId.occurrenceNote: How Judah would have been like Sodom and Gomorrah can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “God would have destroyed us, like he destroyed the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: we would have been like Sodom, we would have been like Gomorrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wool is the hair of a sheep or goat. How they will be like wool can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “white like wool” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like wool

contextId.occurrenceNote: The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Men will go … to hide from the terror” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Men will go & from the terror

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes how man is human and weak by emphasizing that he needs to breath to live. Alternate translation: “who is weak and will die” or “who needs the breath in his nose to live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: whose life-breath is in his nostrils

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “I” refers to Yahweh. This can also be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Yahweh says, ‘I will place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will place

contextId.occurrenceNote: “He made a tall building in the middle of the vineyard to watch over it.” Someone would stand at the top of the tower to watch the vineyard and make sure that no animals or people went into it. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He built a tower in the middle of it

contextId.occurrenceNote: “to those who take more and more houses, and who take more and more fields.” Isaiah assumes that his audience knows that the law forbids someone from taking land from a family permanently. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to those who join house to house, who join field to field

contextId.occurrenceNote: The size of the vineyard is represented by the number of pairs of oxen that could plow it in one day. Each pair of oxen would be connected by a yoke. Alternate translation: “a vineyard that is large enough for ten pairs of oxen to plow it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a ten-yoke vineyard

contextId.occurrenceNote: What they do not understand can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “because they do not understand Yahweh or his law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for lack of understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Yahweh will send someone to speak his message to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Whom shall I send to be a messenger to my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Whom shall I send

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Pekah is the king of Samaria and all of Israel. Alternate translation: “the king of Samaria is Pekah, who is a weak man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the head of Samaria is Remaliah’s son

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “By the time that child is old enough to eat curds and honey, he will be able to reject what is evil and choose what is good.” This emphasizes that the child will be very young when he knows to choose what is right instead of wrong or (2) “By the time the child is old enough to reject what is evil and choose what is good, he will be eating curds and honey.” The people of Judah considered a child to be responsible for doing what is right when he was 12 years old. This emphasizes that within twelve years the people will be able to eat much curds and honey because most of the people of Israel will be killed or taken as captives. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He will eat curds and honey when he knows to refuse the evil and choose the good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Why the hunters come to these lands can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “because there will be nothing in these lands but briers, thorns, and wild animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: because all the land will be briers and thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people imagine there are conspiracies, and it makes them anxious. Alternate translation: “Do not worry like this people who think someone is always trying to harm them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not call conspiracy anything that this people calls conspiracy

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be made more explicit by translating it as a new sentence. Alternate translation: “burned. You will make the boots and the garments fuel for the fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: burned, fuel for the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: What they will know can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “All the people will know that the Lord has judged them, even those in Ephraim and Samaria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: All the people will know, even Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria

contextId.occurrenceNote: The full meaning can be made explicit. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “We will replace the common bricks of our destroyed cities with expensive cut stone, and we will plant great cedar trees where ordinary sycamore trees grew” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The bricks have fallen, but we will rebuild with chiseled stone; the sycamores have been cut down, but we will put cedars in their place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The meaning of “this” and “this way” can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “But the king of Assyria does not intend to do what I tell him, nor does he think that I am using him as my weapon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: But this is not what he intends, nor does he think this way

contextId.occurrenceNote: The meaning can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “that has escaped from the army of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: that has escaped

contextId.occurrenceNote: The full meaning can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “as the Egyptians ruled over your ancestors and made them slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: as the Egyptians did

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “what his eyes see” refers to seeing things that are not important for judging a person rightly. Alternate translation: “he will not judge a person simply by seeing what the person looks like” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will not judge by what his eyes see

contextId.occurrenceNote: “and he will not decide by what his ears hear.” The phrase “what his ears hear” refers to hearing what people say about someone. Alternate translation: “and he will not judge a person simply by hearing what others say about him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: nor decide by what his ears hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that the baby will be safe because the snake will not bite it. Alternate translation: “Babies will play safely over the hole of the snake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: A baby will play over the hole of the snake

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly what time is being referred to. Alternate translation: “At that time” or “When the king rules” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: On that day

contextId.occurrenceNote: “even those who proudly exult.” Why they proudly exult can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “even my people who proudly exult because of the great things I do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: even my proudly exulting ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Why there will be so few people can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I will cause so many people to die that living people will be more rare than fine gold” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make men more rare than fine gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their “eyes” to emphasize what they see. It can be stated clearly that the parents are unable to help their infants. Alternate translation: “in front of them” or “while their parents helplessly watch” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: before their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Why they rejoice can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “rejoice that God has made you powerless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: rejoice over you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This alludes to the myth that many people in the Ancient Near East knew, that the Canaanite gods met in council on the top of a mountain in the northern part of Syria. Sitting on the mountain represents ruling with the gods. Alternate translation: “I will rule on the mountain where the gods assemble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will sit on the mount of assembly

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that their bodies were buried in an honorable way. Alternate translation: “all the kings who have died are buried in an honorable way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: all of them lie down in honor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that a large army is coming from the north. Alternate translation: “For from the north comes a large army with a cloud of smoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: For out of the north comes a cloud of smoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be made explicit who left these lands. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that the Hivites and Amorites left after the people of Israel came” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that were forsaken because of the people of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The signal was a flag used to call people to battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “pay attention when you see the battle flag on the mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: when a signal is lifted up on the mountains, look

contextId.occurrenceNote: The trumpets were used to call people to battle. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “pay attention when you hear the sound of the battle trumpets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: when the trumpet is blown, listen

contextId.occurrenceNote: What God will observe can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I will quietly observe that nation from my home” or “From my home, I will quietly watch what the people of that nation do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will quietly observe from my home

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a harvest of grapes. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Before the grape harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Before the harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that this refers to blossoms on grape vines. Alternate translation: “when flowers have finished growing on the grape vines” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: when the blossoming is over

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will cut off the branches before the grapes can ripen. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cut off the branches with knives before their produce fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will cut off the sprigs with pruning hooks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three phrases mean basically the same thing. If necessary, the reason they will grieve can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “The fishermen who catch fish with hooks or nets will cry in despair because the fish in the Nile have died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: The fishermen will wail and mourn, and all who cast a hook into the Nile will mourn, and those who spread nets on the waters will grieve

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the border” refers to the border of Egypt. Alternate translation: “a stone pillar to Yahweh at the border of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a stone pillar at the border to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh being in the land of Egypt represents the people of Egypt worshiping him. Alternate translation: “that the people in the land of Egypt worship Yahweh of hosts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to Yahweh of hosts in the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Who Yahweh will deliver them from can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will deliver the Egyptians from their oppressors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will deliver them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The object of their worship can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “They will worship Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: They will worship

contextId.occurrenceNote: The object of their worship can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “the Egyptians and Assyrians will worship Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated clearly that they will first attack and capture people. Alternate translation: “will attack Egypt and Cush and capture their people and lead them away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will lead away the captives of Egypt, and the exiles of Cush

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “wilderness” refers to the wilderness of Judea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Soldiers would put oil on their leather shields so they would stay soft and not crack during battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: anoint your shields with oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Arabia does not have a forest. Alternate translation: “Far off from the road in Arabia” or “Out in the bushes of Arabia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: In the wilderness of Arabia

contextId.occurrenceNote: “as a hired laborer would count the days of a year.” A hired worker is careful to count the days so that he works exactly the amount of time he is paid to work. This means Kedar will be defeated in exactly one year. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: as a laborer hired for a year would see it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people will store water so that they will have enough to drink while their enemies surround the city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you collected the water of the lower pool

contextId.occurrenceNote: The most important people in Israel had tombs in the highest places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: on the heights

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the sea” refers to the Mediterranean Sea which is west of Israel. Alternate translation: “and those in the west towards the sea will shout with joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: and will joyfully shout from the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: A host is an army. Here “the host of the heaven” refers to the many powerful spirits in the heavens. It can be stated clearly that they are evil. Alternate translation: “the powerful beings” or “the evil spiritual beings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the host of the heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be made more explicit. Alternate translation: “this is not a people who understands Yahweh or his law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: this is not a people of understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: These refer to places where God miraculously defeated enemy armies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Mount Perazim & Valley of Gibeon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “yourselves” refers to the people of Jerusalem. Why they are astonished can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Be astonished at what I am telling you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Astonish yourselves and be astonished

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that they are secretly doing evil things. Alternate translation: “who do evil things in the dark so no one can see them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: whose deeds are in darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to giving testimony in court against someone. Alternate translation: “who testify against a man and make him out to be an offender” or “who say in court that an innocent man is guilty of doing something wrong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who by a word make a man out to be an offender

contextId.occurrenceNote: This possibly refers to when Yahweh called Abraham from his home country and sent him to the promised land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who redeemed Abraham

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be made more explicit to explain what they will understand. Alternate translation: “will begin to understand Yahweh and his laws” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will gain understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be made more explicit to explain what knowledge they will learn. Alternate translation: “those who complain will begin to know that what Yahweh teaches them is true” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: complainers will learn knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the people rest because they trust that Yahweh will take care of them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: resting

contextId.occurrenceNote: Quietness here refers to not being anxious and worried. It is implied that they are not worried because they trust in Yahweh. Alternate translation: “You will be strong if you are quiet and trust in me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in quietness and in trust will be your strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: Apparently these are horses that the people of Judah received from the Egyptians. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: we will flee on horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is the meaning of the word “Topheth.” Topheth is a place in the Hinnom Valley, south of Jerusalem, where at one time people burned their children as sacrifices to a false god. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a place of burning

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that this refers to the king of Assyria. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh prepared it for the king of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: it is prepared for the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that their horses are only horses and not spiritual beings. Alternate translation: “their horses are only horses; they are not powerful spirits” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: their horses flesh and not spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The shepherds would make loud noises to try and chase away the lion. Alternate translation: “from the loud noises that they make” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from their sound

contextId.occurrenceNote: “will come down.” This refers to descending from heaven. Alternate translation: “will come down from heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will descend

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that there would not be good grapes to harvest. Alternate translation: “there will be no grapes for you to harvest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the grape harvest will fail

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bare” does not necessarily mean naked, but to wear minimal covering such as undergarments. Alternate translation: “take off you fine clothes and make yourself unclothed” or “take off your fancy clothes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: take off your fine clothes and make yourselves bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they will cry out loudly as they grieve what happens to their fruitful fields and vines. Alternate translation: “You will wail because of what happens to your pleasant fields and fruitful vines” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You will wail for the pleasant fields, for the fruitful vines

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the fort and the watchtower being abandoned as if they became caves. Alternate translation: “the hill and the watchtower will become abandoned and empty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the hill and the watchtower will become caves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the these animals will enjoy the grass that grows among the abandon fort and watchtower. Alternate translation: “the wild donkeys and the flocks of sheep will eat the grass there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a joy of wild donkeys, a pasture of flocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings of **the loud noise** are: (1) it refers to Yahweh’s voice. Alternate translation: “The peoples flee at the sound of your loud voice” or (2) it refers the loud sounds of Yahweh’s army. Alternate translation: “The people flee at the sound of your army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: At the loud noise the peoples flee

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means they weep because they do not succeed in making peace. Alternate translation: “the diplomats hope for peace but they do not succeed and so they weep bitterly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the diplomats hoping for peace weep bitterly

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the sinners in Zion ask these questions. Alternate translation: “They say, ‘Who among us … burnings?’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Who among us & burnings?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he will take revenge on them for how they had previously waged war against the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “he will give them the punishment they deserve for what they had done to the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will pay them back for the cause of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that a pool of water will appear in the hot sand. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “A pool will appear in the burning sand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The burning sand will become a pool

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that springs will appear in the dry ground. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “springs of water will appear in the thirsty ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the thirsty ground springs of water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they are standing on the wall. The top of the wall was wide and a place where people could sit or stand. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “who are standing on the wall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who are on the wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a very offensive statement. He is implying that they will need to eat these things because they will have nothing else to eat because their city will be under attack. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “will soon need to eat their own dung and drink their own urine, just as you will, because you will have nothing else to eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will have to eat their own dung and drink their own urine with you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah is indirectly suggesting that if the people pray Yahweh may listen and act upon what the chief commander had said. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Maybe if you pray to Yahweh your God will hear the message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: It may be Yahweh your God will hear the words

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase “the words which Yahweh your God has heard” refers to what the king of Assyria had said. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Yahweh your God will rebuke the king of Assyria for what he has said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will rebuke the words which Yahweh your God has heard

contextId.occurrenceNote: You may need to make explicit that the cherubim are those on the lid of the ark of the covenant. The biblical writers often spoke of the ark of the covenant as if it were Yahweh’s footstool upon which he rested his feet as he sat on his throne in heaven above. Alternate translation: “you who sit on your throne above the cherubim on the ark of the covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: you who sit above the cherubim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah is referring to the letter from Sennacherib. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “in the message he has sent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: which he has sent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the servants that he had sent to Hezekiah with a message. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “In the messages you sent with your servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: By your servants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh had planned for Sennacherib’s army to destroy the cities that they had destroyed. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “I planned that your army would destroy cities and cause them to become piles of rubble” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You are here to reduce impregnable cities into heaps of ruins

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to causing the king to return to his own home country. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “I will force you to return to your own country” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn you back the way you came

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to prepare your family and those in charge of your affairs so that they know what to do after you die. This can be written clearly. Alternate translation: “You should tell the people in your palace what you want them to do after you die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Set your house in order

contextId.occurrenceNote: These stairs are referred to this way because they were built while Ahaz was king. You can make this information clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: stairs of Ahaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Hezekiah looking to heaven for God to help him. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “of waiting for help to come from heaven” or “of waiting for you to help me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: with looking upward

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the rest of his life. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “the rest of my life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: all my years

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah did not die but he was close to dying. This refers Yahweh saving him from dying. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “from dying and going to the pit of destruction” or “so that I did not die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: from the pit of destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to him being saved from dying. It can be made more explicit. Alternate translation: “save me from dying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: save me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was used as an ointment. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “use an ointment of mashed figs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: a lump of figs

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be made more explicit. Alternate translation: “When the king’s messengers arrived, Hezekiah was pleased with what they brought to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Hezekiah was pleased by these things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Messengers would often stand on elevated land, such as mountains, so that many people could hear what they proclaimed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Go up on a high mountain

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question applies to the gods whom the people of the nations worship. The implied answer is that none of them could do this. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “None of their gods could have declared this or announced to us earlier events.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who among them could have declared this and announced to us earlier events?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to their ability to tell about events that happened in the past before they happened. Alternate translation: “announced to us earlier events before they happened” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: announced to us earlier events

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “formed” indicates that Yahweh is speaking of idols that people have made. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “None of the gods whom people have formed existed before me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Before me there was no god formed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The object of the verb “send” may be supplied in translation. Alternate translation: “I send an army to Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I send to Babylon and lead them all down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the events following the exodus from Egypt, when Yahweh divided the sea to let the Israelites walk through on dry ground but then drowned the Egyptian army. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who opened a way & mighty waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the events following the exodus from Egypt, when Yahweh divided the sea to let the Israelites walk through on dry ground but then drowned the Egyptian army. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who led out & a burning wick

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this refers to the associates of the craftsman who makes the idol. Alternate translation: “all of the craftsman’s associates” or (2) this refers to those who associate themselves with the idol by worshiping it. Alternate translation: “all those who worship the idol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: all his associates

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means when he did not have any children yet. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “when he had no children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: when he was a lone individual

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that by putting the cup of his anger in their hand Yahweh will be forcing them to drink what is in the cup. Alternate translation: “I will force your tormentors to drink from the wine of the bowl of my anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put it into the hand of your tormentors

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is assumed knowledge that the people of Israel were slaves in Babylon. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “go out from the land where you are slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: go out from there

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the servant is disfigured because enemies beat him very badly. The full meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “his enemies beat his body so badly that he did not even look like a human anymore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: his appearance was so disfigured beyond that of any man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to peace with God. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “He accepted this punishment so we could live in harmony” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The punishment for our peace was on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the flood that Yahweh caused during the time of Noah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the waters of Noah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to counting silver coins in order to pay someone for something. Alternate translation: “pay money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: weigh out silver

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the description of the word returning to Yahweh means that it has completed the task that Yahweh had sent it to complete. That it will not return “empty” means that it will not fail to accomplish its task. Alternate translation: “it will not fail to complete its task” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: it will not return to me empty

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these actions are associated with worshiping idols. The oaks were sacred trees to the Canaanites. People thought such activity would increase fertility for people and the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: You heat yourselves & under the rocky overhangs

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often went on top of hills and mountains to worship false gods. They thought those were the best places for worship. This might even refer to Jerusalem, too. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: on a high mountain

contextId.occurrenceNote: The story of Yahweh miraculously splitting the waters of the Sea of Reeds so that the Israelites could cross and escape the Egyptians is assumed knowledge. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: who brought them up out of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: These refer to Canaanite places for worshiping idols. Their sacred altars were made of bricks, which Yahweh forbid for his altars. Yahweh’s altars were made of stone. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: in gardens & on brick tiles

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a reference to consulting the dead, a practice that Yahweh prohibited. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: sit among the graves and keep watch all night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh did not allow the people of Israel to eat meat from pigs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: eat pork

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a place where people would go to worship idols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: enter the gardens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “come” can be stated as “gone.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-go]])
contextId.quoteString: have come to Hanes

contextId.occurrenceNote: “one bath of wine” or “22 liters of wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: one bath

contextId.occurrenceNote: “220 liters of seed will produce only 22 liters of grain.” One homer equals ten ephahs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])
contextId.quoteString: one homer of seed will yield only an ephah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Amoz was the father of Isaiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Amoz

contextId.occurrenceNote: men’s names (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Rezin & Pekah & Remaliah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Translators may also add a footnote that says, “The name Shear-Jashub means ‘a remnant will return.’” The meaning may have given hope to Ahaz. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Shear-Jashub

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is the proper name by which the people called the field or (2) this is the common noun that the people used to talk about the field, “the launderer’s field” or “the field where men wash wool” or “the field where women wash clothes.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Launderer’s Field

contextId.occurrenceNote: A launderer is either: (1) a man who washes wool that someone has cut from the sheep, “Wool Washer Field,” or (2) a woman who washes dirty clothes, “Clothes Washer Field.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Launderer’s Field

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is unknown who this man is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: son of Tabeel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Translators may add a footnote that says: “The name Immanuel means ‘God with us.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: his name Immanuel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all names of cities. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kalno & Carchemish & Hamath & Arpad

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to when God helped a man named Gideon defeat the army of Midian. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: as when he defeated Midian at the rock of Oreb

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all cities and villages near Jerusalem that the army of Assyria went through and caused trouble in. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Aiath & Migron & Michmash

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all cities and villages near Jerusalem that the army of Assyria went through and caused trouble in. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Geba & Ramah & Gibeah

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Pathros & Elam & Hamath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ophir was the name of a place where there was pure gold. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: pure gold of Ophir

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of cities and towns in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ar & Kir

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of cities and towns in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dibon & Nebo & Medeba

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of cities and towns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Heshbon & Elealeh & Jahaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of cities and towns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Zoar & Eglath Shelishiyah & Luhith & Horonaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city or town. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nimrim

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of cities and towns. Dimon was the principal city of the country of Moab. Several modern versions have “Dibon” instead of “Dimon.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Eglaim & Beer Elim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city or town. Dimon was the principal city of the country of Moab. Several modern versions have “Dibon” instead of “Dimon.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dimon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Selah

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Kir Hareseth” is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kir Hareseth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of cities. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sibmah & Jazer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a valley where people normally grew and harvested much food. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the Valley of Rephaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a city in northern Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Zoan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a city in the northern part of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Memphis

contextId.occurrenceNote: the name of the chief commander of the armies of Assyria (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Tartan

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another name for Edom. Here “Dumah” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “about the people of Dumah” or “about the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: about Dumah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of mountains west of Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Seir

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a people group that lived in Arabia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Dedanites

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city in Arabia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: land of Tema

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a region in Arabia. Kedar represents the population of Kedar. Alternate translation: “of the people of Kedar” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: of Kedar

contextId.occurrenceNote: Kir is a city in Media. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kir

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of the manager of the king’s palace in Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Shebna

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Eliakim & Hilkiah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “the men heard about Tyre when they were in the land of Cyprus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: from the land of Cyprus it has been revealed to them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shihor was the name of a valley near the Nile River in Egypt known for its production of grain. Alternate translation: “The men traveled on the large sea to transport the grain from Shihor in Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Upon the great waters was the grain of Shihor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another name for Jerusalem, and it means “altar.” If possible translate this as “Ariel” rather than “Jerusalem” since the meaning of “Ariel” is important in 29:2. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ariel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These were cities in the northern part of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Zoan & Hanes

contextId.occurrenceNote: There were popular stories about a sea monster named Rahab. The name Rahab means “strength” or “arrogance.” Alternate translation: “I call Egypt a loud boaster who does nothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: I have called her Rahab, who sits still

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an important city in Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of the king of Assyria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sennacherib

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a city southwest of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Lachish

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Asaph & Joah

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Aramean” is the name of a people group. “Aramaic” is the name of their language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the Aramean language, Aramaic

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sepharvaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a city in southern Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Libnah

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Tirhakah” is the name of a man. He had mobilized his army so that they were ready to fight. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “Tirhakah king of Cush and Egypt had mobilized his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Tirhakah king of Cush and Egypt had mobilized to fight against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are places that the Assyrians had conquered. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Gozan & Haran & Rezeph & Eden & Tel Assar

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are places that the Assyrians had conquered. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Hena & Ivvah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a false god. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nisrok

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Adrammelek & Sharezer & Esarhaddon

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of men. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Marduk-Baladan & Baladan

contextId.occurrenceNote: a city in Edom (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sela

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Seba

contextId.occurrenceNote: This also refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Jeshurun

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are people from the nation of Seba. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sabeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: These were the two primary gods whom the Babylonians worshiped. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Bel & Nebo

contextId.occurrenceNote: The location of this place is uncertain, but it may refer to a region in the southern part of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of Sinim

contextId.occurrenceNote: an area in Arabia (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ephah

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the names of areas in Arabia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kedar & Nebaioth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the capital city of Edom. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a fertile grazing area. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Sharon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a valley that possibly ran from Jerusalem to south of Jericho. This was also a fertile grazing area. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Valley of Achor

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of areas that are far from the land of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Put & Lud & Tubal & Javan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Clasping hands together is the symbol of friendship and peace. Alternate translation: “they make peace and work together with people who are not from Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: they shake hands with sons of foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bending down often symbolizes being humiliated. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Man will be forced to bend down

contextId.occurrenceNote: They do this to show their extreme sadness. AT” “They will all shave their heads and cut off their beards and grieve” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: All their heads are shaved bare and all their beards are cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: They do this to show their extreme sadness. Alternate translation: “they wear sackcloth and mourn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: they wear sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Moabites will send rams to the king of Judah so that he might protect them from the enemy army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: Send rams to the ruler of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a sign of mourning and repenting. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: for shaved heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an act of grieving or mourning. Alternate translation: “put sackcloth around waists as you grieve” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: put on sackcloth around your waists

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah’s officials tore their clothes as a sign of mourning and distress. The meaning of this can be made clear. Alternate translation: “with their clothes torn because they were extremely distressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: with their clothes torn

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a sign of mourning and distress. Alternate translation: “he tore his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth because he was very distressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a sign of mourning and distress. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: all covered with sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a gesture of scorn. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: shakes her head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moles are small animals that dig and live underground. Bats are small flying animals that sometimes live in caves. Alternate translation: “to the animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: to the moles and bats

contextId.occurrenceNote: A musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be beaten with the hand. It probably had pieces of metal around the side that sounded when the player shook it. The tambourine was small enough for the player to hold it and shake it with one hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: tambourine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This word suggests that the creatures might have a fiery appearance or resemble snakes. Because we do not know exactly what “seraphim” means, you could translate this as “winged creatures” or “winged living things.” Or, you can borrow the word and use it in your language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-transliterate]])
contextId.quoteString: seraphim

contextId.occurrenceNote: a kind of oak tree (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: terebinth

contextId.occurrenceNote: a large cat with yellow fur and black spots that kills and eats other animals (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: leopard

contextId.occurrenceNote: a very large animal with thick hair and sharp claws that kills and eats other animals (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: bear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the defenseless people of Israel as if they were a gazelle or a sheep that was being chased by hunters or wild animals. Alternate translation: “Like gazelles that run away swiftly when people hunt them, and like sheep that have no shepherd run away from wild animals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like a hunted gazelle or like a sheep with no shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: an animal that is similar to a deer. People hunt them, and wild animals sometimes attack and kill them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: gazelle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Owls are wild birds that hunt at night. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: owls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ostriches are large wild birds that run fast and cannot fly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: ostriches

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hyenas are large wild animals that look like dogs and eat dead animals. Their loud cry sounds like a person laughing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: Hyenas

contextId.occurrenceNote: wild dogs (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: jackals

contextId.occurrenceNote: Papyrus is a tall plant that grows along the side of the Nile River. People bound together papyrus bundles to make boats. Alternate translation: “papyrus boats” or “boats made of reeds” or (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: vessels of papyrus

contextId.occurrenceNote: In order to catch fish, some people put a little food on a hook, tie the hook to a string, and throw the hook into the water. When a fish tries to eat the food, its mouth gets stuck on the hook, and the person pulls the fish out of the water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: cast a hook into the Nile

contextId.occurrenceNote: In order to catch fish, some people toss a net on the water. When fish get caught in it, they pull the net with the fish out of the water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: spread nets on the waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Flax is a plant that grows along the Nile River. People comb its fibers in order to separate them, and use them to make thread for linen cloth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: combed flax

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of plants that are spices. Translators may represent them in general as seeds of spices used to spice food. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: caraway & cumin

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all names of plants that are grains. Translators may represent them in general as seeds of grains. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: wheat & barley & spelt

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “palisade” is a tower armies would build to attack cities with high walls. Also “siege works” refers to other various weapons armies would build to attack cities. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: palisade & siege works

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “bridle” is a device that people put over a horse’s head to guide it. The bridle contains a small piece called a “bit” that goes in the horse’s mouth. Alternate translation: “a bridle on the heads of the peoples” or “a bit in the jaws of the peoples” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: a bridle in the jaws of the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are types of trees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: the myrtle & the pines and the cypress box trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: a tall evergreen tree (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: cypress tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an animal, similar to a deer, that has horns and runs very fast. Alternate translation: “deer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: antelope

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are precious gemstones. Turquoise is light blue-to-green, sapphires are typically dark blue. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: turquoise & sapphires

contextId.occurrenceNote: These precious gemstones are red to pink. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: rubies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “thornbushes” and “brier” refer to species of plants that have sharp thorns growing on them. The words “cypress” and “myrtle” refer to species of evergreen trees. The thorny plants symbolize desolation, while the evergreens symbolize life and prosperity. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.quoteString: Instead of the thornbushes, the cypress will grow; and instead of the brier, the myrtle tree will grow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Briers and thorns are often used as symbols of ruined cities and land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: briers and thorns will spring up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the imperatives “do not understand” and “do not perceive” express what God is causing to happen. Alternate translation: “You will listen, but Yahweh will not let you understand; you will look carefully, but Yahweh will not allow you to understand” or (2) the imperatives “Listen” and “see” express the idea of “if.” Alternate translation: “Even if you listen you will not understand; even if you look carefully, you will not understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-imperative]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen, but do not understand; see, but do not perceive

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Isaiah tells a parable about a farmer and his vineyard. The farmer represents God and the vineyard represents the people of Judah, the southern kingdom of the Israelites. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In Isaiah’s parable of the vineyard, the owner of the vineyard, who represents God, speaks to the people of Jerusalem and Judah about his vineyard. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah states that the vineyard in the parable represents the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “For the vineyard of Yahweh of hosts represents the house of Israel” or “The people of Israel are like the vineyard of Yahweh, Lord of the angel armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: For the vineyard of Yahweh of hosts is the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: God seems to change from telling the parable to speaking more directly about the nation. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “Those who are killed will be left together” or “Like branches that are cut off and thrown away, the bodies of those who are killed will be left on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: They will be left together

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

This begins a parable that ends in 28:29. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parables]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: In prophecy things that will happen in the future are often referred to as if they had already happened. This emphasizes that the prophecy will certainly come true. Alternate translation: “enemies from other countries will take my people, Israel, as slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: my people have gone into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of the future as if it were happening now. Alternate translation: “Many people of Israel, their important people and common people, their leaders and those who enjoy wild parties, will go into Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: their elite, the people, their leaders, and the revelers and those who are happy among them, descend into Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: Future events are spoken of as if they have already happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: Man will be forced to bend down, and mankind will be humbled

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of the future as if it had already happened. He does this to insist that the prophecy certainly will come about. Alternate translation: “he will punish them with his powerful hand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: He has reached out with his hand against them and has punished them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of these future events as though they have already happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: has come & has passed & has stored

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of these future events as though they have already happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: have crossed & lodge & trembles & has fled

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Often in prophecy events that will happen in future are described as happening now or in the past. This emphasizes that the event will certainly happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Isaiah describes an event that will happen in the future as if it already happened. This emphasizes that it certainly will happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: For the fortified city is & consumes its branches

contextId.occurrenceNote: Often prophets speak of things that will happen in the future as if they have already happened. This emphasizes the event will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “he will completely destroy them, he will give them over to the slaughter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: he has completely destroyed them, he has handed them over to the slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: An event that will happen in the future is spoken of as if it happened in the past. This emphasizes that the event will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “For the children of the desolate woman will be more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: For the children of the desolate one are more

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an indirect quote that ends in 8:17. Alternate translation: “warned me and said, ‘Do not act like this people.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: warned me not to walk in the way of this people.

contextId.occurrenceNote: If you translate this as a direct quote, you can also translate it with Yahweh speaking in the first person: “But you will consider me, Yahweh of Hosts, as holy. And you will fear and be in awe of me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: It is Yahweh of hosts whom you will honor as holy; he is the one you must fear, and he is the one you must dread

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be written as an indirect quote. “Judah” and “Jerusalem” refer to the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “has told the people of Judah and Jerusalem that they must worship only at this altar in Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: has said to Judah and to Jerusalem, “You must worship before this altar in Jerusalem”?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This word is used here to mark a break in the main story line. This gives background information about Isaiah and Hezekiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: Now

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-newevent]])
contextId.quoteString: It came about that

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was probably a proverb that the people knew at the time. It means that what they believe will keep them safe from Yahweh’s punishment will disappoint them like a bed that is too short or a blanket that is too narrow. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-proverbs]])
contextId.quoteString: For the bed is too short for a man to stretch out on, and the blanket too narrow for him to wrap himself in

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Although these prophecies were meant for the people of Jerusalem and Judah to hear, Isaiah knows they will not listen. This could mean: (1) he speaks in apostrophe, as though the “heavens” and “earth” would be able to listen to what Yahweh said, or (2) the words “heavens” and “earth” are metonyms and a merism for all living beings everywhere. Alternate translation: “you who live in the heavens … you who live on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: Hear, heavens, and give ear, earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks as if people in other countries can hear him. Alternate translation: “Listen, all you people in far away places” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen, all you distant countries

contextId.occurrenceNote: In the vision given to Isaiah, Yahweh speaks to the armies of Elam and Media as if they are there listening to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Go up and attack, Elam; besiege, Media

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks to the people who live on the coast as if they could hear him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Be silent, you inhabitants of the coast

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Isaiah speaks various parts of creation as if they were people and commands them to praise Yawheh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Sing, you heavens & glory in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh momentarily turns his attention from his people and begins to speak to the heavens. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: You heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah turns his attention from the people of Israel and speaks to the heavens, earth, and mountains as if they were people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Sing, heavens, and be joyful, earth; break into singing, you mountains!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks to the city of Jerusalem as if it were listening to him. Here Jerusalem represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “You afflicted people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Afflicted one

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated positively. It can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “every part of you has been harmed” or “someone has harmed every part of you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: there is no part unharmed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “If you continue to believe in me, you will certainly remain safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: If you do not remain firm in faith, surely you will not remain secure

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be written as a positive statement. Alternate translation: “Each animal will have a mate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: None will lack for a mate

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a slight exaggeration as Hezekiah showed them many things, but not everything. Also, this can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “Hezekiah showed them almost everything in his house and in his kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: There was nothing in his house, nor in all his kingdom, that Hezekiah did not show them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “I showed them all the valuable things in my palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: There is nothing among my valuable things that I have not shown them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “I have spoken plainly and clearly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.quoteString: I have not spoken in secret

contextId.occurrenceNote: Someone who is arrogant speaks and acts as if he is better than other people. These two phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize that Yahweh will punish them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: who is proud & who is arrogant

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how quickly they will come. Alternate translation: “very quickly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: speedily and promptly

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “high” and “elevated” emphasize that the throne was very high and above everything around it. The height of the throne represents how great and powerful the Lord is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: he was high and elevated

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “afraid” and “intimidated” mean the same thing and can be translated as one word. Alternate translation: “afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: afraid or intimidated

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “briers” and “thorns” both refer to useless, thorny plants. It is not necessary to translate both words. Alternate translation: “thorn bushes” or “brier bushes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: briers and thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “trap” and “snare” mean almost the same thing and emphasize that when Yahweh decides to punish the people of Jerusalem they will not be able to escape. Alternate translation: “he will trap the people of Jerusalem so they cannot escape him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: he will be a trap and a snare to the people of Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that they will be caught in the trap. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: ensnared and captured

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “destroy” and “eliminate” mean basically the same thing. They are used for emphasis. Alternate translation: “He wants to completely destroy many nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: It is in his heart to destroy and eliminate many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two verbs mean basically the same thing. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “No one will live in it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: It will not be inhabited or lived in

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “laid waste” and “destroyed” mean the same thing and emphasize that the city was completely ruined. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Enemy armies will completely destroy Ar of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Ar of Moab is laid waste and destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: As wandering birds, as a scattered nest

contextId.occurrenceNote: These mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “a beautiful crown” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: a beautiful crown and a diadem of beauty

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. This work is strange because God is using a foreign army to defeat the people of Jerusalem rather than helping the people of Jerusalem defeat their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: his strange work & his strange deed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “mourning” and “lamenting” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of mourning. Alternate translation: “they will mourn deeply” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: mourning and lamenting

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “a vision of the night” is the same thing as “a dream.” The two phrases emphasize that soon it will be like the invading army was never there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: It will be like a dream, a vision of the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: These mean the same thing and emphasize how quickly the wall will fall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: suddenly, in an instant

contextId.occurrenceNote: “a female lion or killer lion.” This is a doublet with both phrase referring to a fierce lion. Alternate translation: “a lion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: a lion, even a young lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize Yahweh’s appearance. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the glory of Yahweh, the splendor of our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “gladness” and “joy” mean basically the same thing, as do “sorrow” and “sighing.” Together they emphasize the intensity of these emotions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: gladness and joy & sorrow and sighing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “the greatness of his might” and “the strength of his power” form a doublet that emphasizes Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “By his great might and powerful strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: By the greatness of his might and by the strength of his power

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases both refer to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Why do you say, O people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you say, Jacob, and declare, Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh is the one who has done these things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: performed and accomplished

contextId.occurrenceNote: This doublet means that the people gather together. Alternate translation: “they come together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: they approach and come

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of their shame. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: ashamed and disgraced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” and “men of Israel” mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “you people of Israel who are like worms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob you worm, and you men of Israel
