contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and indicate that Yahweh has kept himself from acting. Alternate translation: “I have kept myself from doing anything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: I have been still and restrained myself

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize how badly the enemy had plundered them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: robbed and plundered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “precious” and “special” mean basically the same thing and emphasize how much Yahweh values his people. Alternate translation: “Because you are very precious to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Since you are precious and special in my sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these mean the same thing and emphasize that it is God who made the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: whom I have formed, yes, whom I have made

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “I” is repeated to emphasize the focus on Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I alone am Yahweh” or “I myself am Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: I, I am Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “I” is repeated for emphasis. Alternate translation: “I alone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: I, yes, I

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses two similar expressions in order to strengthen his encouragement. Alternate translation: “Do not be afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Do not fear or be afraid

contextId.occurrenceNote: These both refer to the descendants of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob & Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the words “price” and “bribe” share similar meanings. Cyrus will not do these things for financial gain. Alternate translation: “he will not do these things for money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: not for price nor bribe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “ashamed” and “disgraced” mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of shame. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Their idols will leave them all completely ashamed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: They will all be ashamed and disgraced together

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words share similar meanings. They describe one who is beautiful and lives in luxury. Alternate translation: “very beautiful” or “very luxurious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: dainty and delicate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these refer to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob, and Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “I” is repeated for emphasis. Alternate translation: “I myself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: I, I

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two expressions in this context refer to destroying the people. Alternate translation: “destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: cut off nor blotted out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “a waste” and “desolate” mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the enemy has destroyed Zion and left it empty. Alternate translation: “Though you were completely desolate” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Though you were a waste and desolate

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joy and gladness mean the same thing. Being found there represents being there. Alternate translation: “there will be joy and gladness in Zion again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: joy and gladness will be found in her

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “gladness” and “joy” mean basically the same thing, as do “sorrow” and “mourning.” Together they emphasize the intensity of these emotions. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: gladness and joy & sorrow and mourning

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words have similar meanings and emphasize the destruction of the land caused by the opposing army. Alternate translation: “your enemies have left your city empty and ruined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: desolation and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “inside the walls of my temple” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: in my house and within my walls

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that, although the people should have remembered Yahweh, they did not. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: so much that you would not remember me or think about me

contextId.occurrenceNote: You can make clear the understood information. Alternate translation: “the donkey knows his master’s feeding trough” or “the donkey knows where his master gives him food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the donkey his master’s feeding trough

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “he waited” is understood from earlier in the verse. It can be repeated to make the meaning clear. Alternate translation: “He waited for righteousness” or “He waited for them to do what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: for righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “there was” are understood from earlier in the verse. They can be repeated to make the meaning clear. The reason people shouted out for help can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “instead, there was a shout for help” or “instead, those who were weak shouted out for someone to help them because others were attacking them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: instead, a shout for help

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “wings” and “seraph” are understood. Alternate translation: “with two wings each seraph covered his face, and with two wings he covered his feet, and with two wings he flew” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: with two each covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew

contextId.occurrenceNote: You can state clearly the understood information. Alternate translation: “Listen to Yahweh’s message, but do not understand what it means; look at what Yahweh is doing, but do not realize what it means” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Listen, but do not understand; see, but do not perceive

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will be” are understood in this phrase. Alternate translation: “faithfulness will be the belt around his hips” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: faithfulness the belt around his hips

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “will be” is understood. Alternate translation: “the calf, the lion, and the fattened calf will be together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the calf, the young lion and the fattened calf, together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “there is” are understood. The phrases “multitude” and “many people” mean the same thing. Alternate translation: “There is the noise of many people in the mountains” or “There is the noise of a great crowd of people in the mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: The noise of a multitude in the mountains, as of many people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “there is” are understood. The words “kingdoms” and “nations” here refer to the same thing. Alternate translation: “There is the noisy commotion of many kingdoms gathered together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: The noise of a tumult of the kingdoms like many nations gathered together

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the enemies will attack the women and force them to have sex with them. The words “will be” are understood. This can also be expressed with an active form. Alternate translation: “their wives will be raped” or “their enemies will rape their wives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their wives raped

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will cry” are understood. Alternate translation: “jackals will cry in the beautiful palaces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: jackals in the beautiful palaces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “how and “has” are understood. Alternate translation: “how the proud fury has ended” or “his pride and fury have ended” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the proud fury ended

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will disappear” are understood from the previous phrase. Damascus was where the king of Aram ruled from. The kingdom disappearing represents the king no longer having royal power. Alternate translation: “the kingdom will disappear from Damascus” or “there will be no royal power in Damascus” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the kingdom from Damascus

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “olives” is understood from the phrase before this. Alternate translation: “four or five olives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: four or five

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will fight” are understood from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “a man will fight against his neighbor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: a man against his neighbor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will be” or “will fight” are understood from the previous phrases. Alternate translation: “kingdom will be against kingdom” or “kingdom will fight against kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: kingdom against kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “them” is understood in this phrase. Alternate translation: “afflicting them and healing them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: afflicting and healing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “will come” are understood. Alternate translation: “the Egyptian will come to Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the Egyptian to Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that they are to attack the Babylonians. Alternate translation: “Go up and attack the Babylonians, you soldiers of Elam; go and besiege the Babylonians, you soldiers of Media” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Go up and attack, Elam; besiege, Media

contextId.occurrenceNote: What Yahweh will do is not stated here, but it is understood. This shows that God will treat all people the same way. Alternate translation: “as Yahweh scatters … so he will scatter”(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: as with & so with

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that Yahweh is not angry with his people any longer. Alternate translation: “I am not angry with my people any longer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: I am not angry

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood information can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “those who are in exile and dying in the land of Assyria and the land of Egypt will return to the land of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the perishing ones in the land of Assyria will come, and the outcasts in the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The translator can supply the verb “will become.” Alternate translation: “the soldiers who show you no mercy will become as chaff” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the ruthless ones as chaff

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is understood that this is a broken part of a wall. Alternate translation: “like a broken part of a wall that is ready to fall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: like a broken part ready to fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “solider” is understood. Alternate translation: “One thousand soldiers will flee at the threat of one enemy soldier; at the threat of five enemy soldiers all of your soldiers will flee” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: One thousand will flee at the threat of one; at the threat of five you will flee

contextId.occurrenceNote: This understood verb “be” may be supplied. Also, the word “salvation” may be expressed with the verb “save.” Alternate translation: “be our salvation” or “save us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: our salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the things that Yahweh will give to them. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you can express the same idea with the verb “save.” The abstract nouns “wisdom” and “knowledge” can be expressed with adjectives. Alternate translation: “and he will give you an abundance of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge” or “he will save you and cause you to be very wise and knowledgeable” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: abundance of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the second of two parallel phrases. The understood words may be supplied in this phrase. Alternate translation: “the world, and all things that come from it must listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the world, and all things that come from it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The understood verb may be supplied. Alternate translation: “streams will flow in the wilderness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: streams in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “fruitful” refers to the forest being dense and full of healthy trees. The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “and into its most fruitful forest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: its most fruitful forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes what the people will eat. The words “you will eat” are understood from the previous phrase Alternate translation: “in the second year you will eat what grows” or “next year you will eat what grows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the second year what grows

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “nor will I share my praise with carved idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: nor my praise with carved idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “you, Jeshurun, whom I have chosen, do not fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: you, Jeshurun, whom I have chosen

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “I will pour out my blessing on your children” or “I will give my blessing to your children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: my blessing on your children

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “like a cloud, I have blotted out your sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: like a cloud, your sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “your salvation would have flowed like the waves of the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: your salvation like the waves of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: The last part of the phrase can be clarified from the previous line. Alternate translation: “you will put them on, like a bride wears jewelry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: you will put them on like a bride

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “let the sinful man leave his thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the man of sin his thoughts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The verb may be supplied from the first phrase in this sentence. Alternate translation: “let him return to our God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: to our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will give more valuable building materials to them now. Alternate translation: “instead of wood, I will bring bronze, and instead of stones, I will bring iron” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: instead of wood, bronze, and instead of stones, iron

contextId.occurrenceNote: This clause assumes the same verb as the previous one. Alternate translation: “their offspring will be known among the peoples” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: their offspring among the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a polite way to speak of the hair on the lower body or (2) this speaks of the hair on the legs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: the hair of the legs

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be stated explicitly that Isaiah is married to the prophetess. Alternate translation: “I slept with my wife, the prophetess” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I went to the prophetess

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a polite way of referring to those who have died. Alternate translation: “those who are dead and buried” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: you who live in the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “shame” is a euphemism for one’s private parts. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “people will see your shame” or “people will see your private parts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: your shame will be seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “lie down” refers to dying. Dying painfully is spoken of as if it were lying down in a place where they will experience pain. Alternate translation: “You will die with great suffering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You will lie down in a place of pain

contextId.occurrenceNote: “die and go away … dies and goes away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: are gathered away & is gathered away

contextId.occurrenceNote: they die (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: they rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to sleeping with prostitutes as a part of worshiping false gods. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: You prepared your bed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, “willing” and “obedient” are used together to express one idea. Alternate translation: “If you willingly obey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]])
contextId.quoteString: If you are willing and obedient

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “glory” describes “majesty.” Alternate translation: “the beauty he has as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]])
contextId.quoteString: the glory of his majesty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heat” describes the word “sun.” The people suffering from the sun’s heat is spoken of as if the heat struck them. Alternate translation: “nor will they suffer from the sun’s heat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hendiadys]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: nor will the heat or sun beat on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration for a very long time. Alternate translation: “an extremely long time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exaggerates the princes losing their royal status by saying that they will become nothing. Alternate translation: “all her princes will no longer rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all her princes will be nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization. The kings had destroyed many of the nearby lands, but not necessarily all lands. Alternate translation: “many of the nations and their lands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all the nations and their lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennachrib is exaggerating his conquest and travels across the rivers of Egypt by claiming to have dried up the rivers when he marched his army through them. Alternate translation: “I have marched through all the rivers of Egypt as if they were dry under my feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: I dried up all the rivers of Egypt under the soles of my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a generalization, as Hezekiah showed them many things, but not necessarily everything in the palace. Alternate translation: “almost everything in my house” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: everything in my house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is generalization. Many children will lie in the street, but not necessarily on every street corner. Alternate translation: “they lie on the street” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: they lie at every street corner

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people did not literally go to Sheol, the world of the dead. Instead, Yahweh is indicating by exaggeration that the people were willing to go anywhere to find new gods to worship. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: you went down to Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom and refers to the time when each king reigned. They reigned one after the other, not all at the same time. Alternate translation: “when Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah were kings of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “daughter” of a city means the people of the city. Alternate translation: “The people of Zion” or “The people who live in Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The daughter of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom is a way of saying “I will not look at you” or “I will not pay attention to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I hide my eyes from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “on the day that Yahweh judges everyone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: on that day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “that are very high” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: that are lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase means “let us marry you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: let us take your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “falls into” is an idiom that means to become something worse. Alternate translation: “the land becomes a desolate waste” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the land falls into a desolate waste

contextId.occurrenceNote: “When Ahaz … was king of Judah” This was when the events happened. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: During the days of Ahaz & king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his strong hand upon me” is an idiom that refers to Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke to me in a very powerful way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh spoke to me, with his strong hand upon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “shadow of death” is an idiom that means absolute darkness. Alternate translation: “the land of deepest darkness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of the shadow of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “day” is an idiom that can refer to an event that takes more than one day to happen. Alternate translation: “as when you defeated the Midianites” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: as on the day of Midian

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Send a word” means to speak. Alternate translation: “The Lord has spoken against the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord sent a word against Jacob, and it fell on Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “stir up” is an idiom that means to incite them to attack. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cause Israel’s enemies to attack” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: will stir up his enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “spare” someone means to save them from harm. Alternate translation: “No one does anything to help his own brother escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: No man spares his brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “daughter” here refers to the people who live in the city. Alternate translation: “Gallim” or “people of Gallim” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Gallim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “he” and “his” refer to the king of Assyria and his soldiers. People would shake their fists at people whom they were threatening. Alternate translation: “the army of Assyria will stop at Nob and threaten” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he will halt at Nob and shake his fist

contextId.occurrenceNote: Giving light represents “shining.” Alternate translation: “will not shine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: will not give their light

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “generation to generation” refers to all generations of people who will live in the future. Alternate translation: “for ever” or “ever again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from generation to generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “up to the heights” refers to a temple or altar that was built on high ground like a hill or mountain side. Alternate translation: “went up to the temple on the hilltop to weep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: went up to the heights to weep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Looking toward God here represents hoping that he will help them. Alternate translation: “men will hope that their Maker, the Holy One of Israel, will help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: men will look toward their Maker & will look to the Holy One of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase “to look to” means to trust in something. Alternate translation: “to defend yourselves you will get the weapons” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you looked in that day to the weapons

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Here silence is meant to signal shock and amazement. Alternate translation: “Be shocked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Be silent

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “lift up their voices” is an idiom that means to speak loudly. Alternate translation: “They will sing and shout about the majesty of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: They will lift up their voices and shout the majesty of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means they asked Yahweh for help. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: looked to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who has a “spirit of justice” is someone who has the characteristic of justice and is a just person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: a spirit of justice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means the person has the authority to judge. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: sits in judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “to turn back” is an idiom that means to defeat in battle. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cause the soldiers to be strong so that they defeat their enemies when the enemies attack their city” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: strength for those who turn back their enemies at their gates

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “every day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: morning by morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh preparing to act is spoken of as if he were sitting and then rising up. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to distort what is true. Alternate translation: “You make things opposite of the way they should be” or “You distort the truth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: You turn things upside down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he will no longer be afraid. Alternate translation: “nor will he be afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: nor will his face be pale

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to trust or rely on something. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: lean on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “bring” means to “cause.” Alternate translation: “he will cause disasters to happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he will bring disaster

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “called out against it” means to be sent out to chase the lion away. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “when someone sends shepherds to chase the lion away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] or [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: when a group of shepherds is called out against it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he will be successful. Alternate translation: “he will be successful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he will stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to begin doing something. Alternate translation: “begin acting” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: arise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here walking refers to living. Alternate translation: “He who lives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: He who walks

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “day” is an idiom for a point in time; it is not a literal “day.” Alternate translation: “it will be the time when Yahweh gets revenge” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: it will be a day of vengeance for Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Here “walking” refers to “living.” This refers to the person who lives a holy life. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: “who lives in the holy way” or “who lives a holy life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: him who walks in it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “to speak in someone’s ear” means to speak where they can hear you. Alternate translation: “where the people who are on the wall may hear us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in the ears of the people who are on the wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to agree officially to act peacefully towards one another. Alternate translation: “Let us agree to have peace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Make peace with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to surrender. Alternate translation: “surrender to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: come out to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means that he was in charge of the affairs of the palace household. Alternate translation: “in charge of the palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: over the household

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means that he was in charge of the affairs of the palace household. Alternate translation: “in charge of the palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: over the household

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “put a spirit in him” means that God will influence him to make a specific decision. The word “spirit” here means a strong attitude or feeling. Alternate translation: “I will influence him so that when he hears a certain report, he will go back to his own land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put a spirit in him, and he will hear a certain report and go back to his own land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “fall by the sword” is an idiom that means that his enemy will kill him with a sword. Alternate translation: “And there in his own land, I will cause his enemies to kill him with their swords” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to have authority and to rule over all the kingdoms. Alternate translation: “have authority over all the kingdoms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: over all the kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means to look at something pridefully, considering yourself more important that you should. Alternate translation: “looked at pridefully” or “acted pridefully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: lifted up your eyes in pride

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “to bring something to pass” means to cause a specific thing to happen. Alternate translation: “I am causing it to happen” or “I am causing these things to take place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I am bringing it to pass

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to kill. Alternate translation: “killing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: putting to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means to remember. Alternate translation: “remember” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Here “walk” means to “live.” The phrase means to live in a way the pleases Yahweh. Alternate translation: “faithfully lived before you” or “faithfully served you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: faithfully walked before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that is used to introduce something that God told his prophets or his people. Alternate translation: “Yahweh spoke this message” or “Yahweh spoke these words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh came

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Here “walking” refers to living. Alternate translation: “I will like humbly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I will walk slowly

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the east, the direction from which the sun rises. Alternate translation: “from the east” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: from the sun’s rising

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Babylon’s false sense of security in thinking that she will never lose her position of wealth and honor. Alternate translation: “who think you are safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: sit securely

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) that this is a literal expression of submission where the person licks the dust off of a superior’s foot or from the ground at the superior’s foot or (2) that this is an idiom that describes a person prostrating himself before a superior. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: lick the dust of your feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hot” means “strong” or “great.” Alternate translation: “great fury” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: hot fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “shout loudly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: raise their voices

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “shut their mouths” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “kings will stop talking” or “kings will be silent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: kings will shut their mouths

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of making him live for more time. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will make his servant live again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: he will prolong his days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hid my face” is an idiom that means God abandoned his people and let them suffer. Alternate translation: “I abandoned you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I hid my face from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “causes trouble” or “troubles you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: stirs up trouble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “you will defeat them in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: will fall in defeat

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fatness” refers to meat that has plenty of fat on it and is an idiom for fine food. Alternate translation: “with the best foods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: in fatness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “holds it tightly” is an idiom that means to continue to observe something. Alternate translation: “who is careful to always do this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who holds it tightly

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God gave up on his people and no longer helped or blessed them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I hid my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase represents starting the meal by the host tearing the loaf of bread apart. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: break your bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Break open” here is an idiom that means when a light begins to shine brightly. This means that if they help people in need, their deeds will be like lights others will see, as when the sun comes up after a dark night. Or the light may refer to the light of the Lord, shining on them and blessing them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Then your light would be broken open like the sunrise

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means “remember.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God gave up on his people and let them suffer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: you have hidden your face from us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to remembering the past. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Spreading out my hands” here is a person’s gesture to show imploring or a strong request. Alternate translation: “I have continually begged a stubborn people to receive my help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I have spread out my hands all day to a stubborn people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God will punish them to the fullest extent. This expression compares Yahweh punishing the people to dumping on their legs as they are sitting. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: into their laps

contextId.occurrenceNote: “hidden from my eyes” represents the attention and memory of Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I will not even think about them again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: they will be hidden from my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to those who continue to sin (verse 18) and then mockingly challenge God to stop them. Alternate translation: “those mockers who say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: those who say

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah is implying that wise men should be able to understand God’s plans, but Isaiah does not really believe they are wise. Alternate translation: “If they were really wise, they would be able to tell you what Yahweh of hosts plans concerning Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Let them tell you and make known what Yahweh of hosts plans concerning Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Keep celebrating your festival year after year.” This is an ironic statement. Yahweh tells the people to keep celebrating their festivals where they sacrifice to him, but he knows it will not prevent him from destroying them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Add year to year; let the festivals come round

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander continues to ridicule Hezekiah and his army by implying that he did not have many soldiers. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: if you are able to find riders for them

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In these verses, Yahweh is mocking the people and their idols. He is challenging the idols to tell what will happen in the future, but he knows they cannot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh challenges the gods whom the nations worship to provide witnesses who will testify that they have been able to do these things, although he knows that they cannot do so. Alternate translation: “These gods have no witnesses who will prove them right, witnesses who will listen and affirm, ‘It is true’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Let them bring their witnesses to prove themselves right, let them listen and affirm, ‘It is true.’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh challenges the people to offer proof that they are innocent of the charges that he has brought against them, although he knows that they cannot do so. Alternate translation: “present your case, but you cannot prove yourselves to be innocent” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: present your cause, that you may be proved innocent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh mocks Babylon by telling her to continue to practice her sorcery to keep bad things away, but he knows that it will not help her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: Persist in casting your spells & perhaps you will scare away disaster

contextId.occurrenceNote: There is a sense of irony in this statement since a person usually has to use money to buy something. This emphasizes Yahweh’s amazing grace in giving these things freely. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: buy wine and milk without money and without cost

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is being sarcastic, calling their evil deeds so-called righteousness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: I will proclaim all your righteous acts and tell all that you have done

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is mocking the people and their idols. He tells the idols to save the people though he knows they cannot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.quoteString: let your collection of idols rescue you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This negative statement emphasizes the positive. Alternate translation: “every one is present” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: not one is missing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means they are continually pleading to Yahweh or calling to each other. Alternate translation: “they are earnestly praying to Yahweh throughout the entire day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: they are not silent day or night

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “I will spare some of them who are righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not ruin them all

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: “will burn forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: will not be quenched

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who do nothing all day but drink alcoholic drinks. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: those who rise up early in the morning & who linger late into the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses the word “depths” and “height” to mean Ahaz could ask him for anything. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: ask for it in the depths or in the height above

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this emphasizes that God will completely destroy the forests and farmlands. Alternate translation: “completely” or (2) this means God will completely destroy the people of Assyria. The phrase “soul and body” refers to the spiritual part and the physical part of a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: both soul and body

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “far” and “near” are used together to mean “everywhere.” Alternate translation: “a people who are feared everywhere” or “a people that everyone in the earth fears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: a people feared far and near

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “far” and “near” are used together to mean “everywhere.” Alternate translation: “a people who are feared everywhere” or “a people that everyone in the earth fears” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: a people feared far and near

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “night” and “day” are combined here to mean “all the time.” Alternate translation: “all the time” or “continually” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: night and day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means “throughout the entire day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: by day and night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses the words “far away” and “near” to mean all people. The word “might” can be expressed with the adjective “mighty.” Alternate translation: “All people everywhere hear what I have done and acknowledge that I am mighty” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: You who are far away, hear what I have done; and, you who are near, acknowledge my might

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means all of the time. Alternate translation: “It will burn throughout the night and the day” or “It will burn constantly, all night and all day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: It will burn night and day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he created everything. Alternate translation: “You made everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: You made the heavens and the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all activities of life. Alternate translation: “I know everything you do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: But I know your sitting down, your going out, your coming in

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “good” and “evil” form a merism and represent anything. Alternate translation: “do anything at all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: do something good or evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The directions “east” and “west” form a merism and represent from every direction. Alternate translation: “I will bring you and your offspring from every direction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: I will bring your offspring from the east, and gather you from the west

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase emphasizes Yahweh’s eternal nature. This could mean: (1) “I am the one who began all things, and I am the one who ends all things” or (2) “I am the one who has always lived, and I am the one who always will live.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: I am the first, and I am the last

contextId.occurrenceNote: “you lowest parts of the earth.” This could mean: (1) that this refers to very deep places on the earth such as caves or canyons and forms a merism with “heavens” in the previous phrase or (2) that this refers to the place of the dead. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: you depths of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since the sun rises in the east, this phrase forms a merism and means everywhere on earth. Alternate translation: “from every place on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: from the rising of the sun, and from the west

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these expressions form merisms that emphasize that Yahweh is sovereign creator of everything. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: I form the light and create darkness; I bring peace and create disaster

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah combines these words to mean people in all places of the world. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: from the west & from the sun’s rising

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both are extremes that also represent everything between. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: new heavens and a new earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks as if his words were food and as if the Israelites were his children. Alternate translation: “I have taken care of the people living in Judah like they were my children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have nourished and brought up children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something very heavy that a person might carry is a metaphor for their many sins. Alternate translation: “their sin is like a heavy bag on their shoulders that makes it hard for them to walk” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a people weighed down with iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “offspring” is a metaphor for people who do what others have done. Alternate translation: “people who do the same evil they see others doing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: offspring of evildoers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor compares the nation of Israel to a person who has been beaten. Alternate translation: “You are like someone whose head is wounded and whose heart is weak” or “You are like someone whose whole mind and heart are sick” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The whole head is sick, the whole heart is weak

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor compares the punishment God has given Israel to physical wounds. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “no one has closed, cleansed, bandaged, or treated them with oil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they have not been closed, cleansed, bandaged, nor treated with oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah is comparing the people of Judah to Sodom and Gomorrah to emphasize how sinful they have become. Alternate translation: “you rulers who are as sinful as the people of Sodom … you people who are as wicked as those who lived in Gomorrah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you rulers of Sodom & you people of Gomorrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how God feels about the people’s celebrations to carrying a heavy object. Alternate translation: “they are a heavy load that I am tired of carrying” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they are a burden to me; I am tired of enduring them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God compares a person who stops sinning with one who washes his body. Alternate translation: “Repent and wash the sin from your heart like you wash the dirt from your body” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Wash, cleanse yourselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: God was not telling them to do their evil deeds somewhere else, but to stop doing them. Alternate translation: “stop doing the evil deeds that I see you doing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: remove the evil of your deeds from my sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of people who oppress others as if they had made crooked something that should be straight, and he calls on them to make that object straight again. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **oppression**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form. Alternate translation: “make sure that those helpless people you have harmed no longer suffer from the bad things you have done to them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: make straight the oppression

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah is speaking of the people as if they were wearing clothes that were supposed to be white wool and of their sins as if they were red stains on the clothes. If Yahweh forgives their sins, it will be as if their clothes become white again. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: though your sins are like scarlet, they will be white like snow; though they are red like crimson, they will be like wool

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compared the people to a woman who is not loyal to her husband but who sleeps with other men for money. The people were no longer loyal to God but were worshiping false gods. Alternate translation: “acts like a prostitute” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: has become a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “she” refers to Jerusalem and its people. Those who wrote the Bible often refer to cities as women. Alternate translation: “but now the people of Jerusalem are murderers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but now she is full of murderers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that Isaiah uses silver and wine as metaphors for: (1) the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “You are like silver that is no longer pure, and like wine that is mixed with water” or (2) the good deeds that the people formerly did. Alternate translation: “You used to do good deeds, but now your bad deeds make your good deeds worthless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Your silver has become impure, your wine mixed with water

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person eagerly desiring for someone to give him a bribe is spoken of as if the payoff were running away and the person were running after it. Alternate translation: “everyone desires for someone to pay money to them to make dishonest decisions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: runs after payoffs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the process in which God removes his people’s sin is spoken of as if her were separating metal from the bad things mixed with it. The words “as with lye” adds another metaphor, because lye is used in soap, not in refining metal. Alternate translation: “and like fire removing the dirt from silver, I will remove all the evil from among you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: refine away your dross as with lye

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of importance as if it were physical height. Alternate translation: “the most important of the mountains” or “the most important place in the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: as the highest of the mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of honor in metaphor as if it were physical height. This can be stated (1) in active form. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will honor it more than any other hill” or (2) as a metonym for the people who worship there. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will honor the people who worship there more than he honors any other people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: it will be raised up above the hills

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people around the world going to the mountain of Yahweh is compared to how a river flows. This emphasizes that many people will come, not just a few people. Alternate translation: “will flow like a river to it” or “will go to it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will flow to it

contextId.occurrenceNote: “For the law will go out from Zion.” Isaiah speaks as if the law were something like a river that moves without people doing anything. Alternate translation: “Those to whom they teach the law will go out from Zion” or “Yahweh will proclaim his law from Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For out of Zion will go the law

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the word of Yahweh will go out from Jerusalem.” Isaiah speaks as if the word of Yahweh were something like a river that moves without people doing anything. You can make clear the understood information. Alternate translation: “Those to whom they teach the word of Yahweh will go out from Jerusalem” or “Yahweh will proclaim his word from Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of Yahweh from Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of people learning and then doing what Yahweh wants them to do as if they were walking at night with a lamp that Yahweh has provided so they can see the path. Alternate translation: “let us learn how Yahweh wants us to live and then live that way” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: let us walk in the light of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks as if the people were containers who were full of something from the east. Possible meanings are that he speaks of: (1) the deeds that the eastern peoples do. Alternate translation: “they do all the time the evil things the people who live in lands east of Israel do” or (2) people, specifically those who claim to speak to dead people, who have come from the east to do evil deeds. Alternate translation: “many diviners have come from the east and now live there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: they are filled with customs from the east

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks as if the land were a container in which someone had placed silver, horses, and idols. The word “land” is a metonym for the people themselves, and the words “is full of” is a metaphor for the people possessing these items. Alternate translation: “They possess much silver and gold … they also possess many horses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Their land is full of silver and gold & their land also is full of horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks as if the land were a container in which someone had placed silver, horses, and idols. The word “land” is a metonym for the people themselves, and the words “is full of” is a metaphor for the people possessing these items. Alternate translation: “They also possess many idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Their land also is full of idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being low to the ground represents people who are completely humiliated because they realize all they trusted in is worthless, and they can do nothing to help themselves. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will make the people ashamed, and they will realize that all they trusted in is worthless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The people will be bowed down, and individuals will fall down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “raise them up” are a metaphor for Yahweh forgiving the people. Alternate translation: “do not forgive them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: do not raise them up

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Yahweh will bring down the lofty gaze of man.” A man with a “lofty gaze” is looking above everyone to show them that he is better than they are. Here all people are guilty of thinking they are better than Yahweh, and the way they look at those who worship Yahweh, is a metonym for their pride. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will make ashamed all people because they think they are better than he is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The lofty gaze of man will be brought low

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “day of Yahweh of Hosts” will be against the cedars and oaks. This could mean: (1) these trees are a metaphor for the proud people whom God will judge or (2) God will actually destroy these mighty trees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: against all the cedars of Lebanon & against all the oaks of Bashan

contextId.occurrenceNote: These refer to things people would build around their cities so they could defend themselves against their enemies. They are a metaphor for the Israelites’ pride and belief that they had no need for Yahweh and could stand against any punishment Yahweh would mete out to them for their sins. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: high tower & impregnable wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these words refer to a walking stick, on which someone leans for support. This idea here stands for the things that people need the most in order to live: food and water. Alternate translation: “everything that supports you” or “everything that you depend on” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: support and staff

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” represents authority. Alternate translation: “take charge of this ruin” or “rule over this ruin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: let this ruin be in your hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) many or most of the buildings in the city of Jerusalem were destroyed or (2) the people in Jerusalem have no more prosperity or leadership. Alternate translation: “this city, which is now ruined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: this ruin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Solving the people’s troubles is spoken of as if it were healing them. Alternate translation: “No, I cannot fix this problem” or “No, I cannot help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will not be a healer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying God is spoken of as if it were stumbling and falling. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem has stumbled, and Judah has fallen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deeds are spoken of as if they were trees giving fruit that can be eaten. The fruit stands for the reward for doing good deeds. Alternate translation: “for they will receive their reward for their good deeds” or “for they will receive their reward for the good things they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for they will eat the fruit of their deeds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “young people have become their leaders and they oppress the people” or (2) “their leaders are immature like children and oppress the people.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: children are their oppressors

contextId.occurrenceNote: It was common in the Ancient Middle East to speak of a nation’s leaders as if they were shepherds. As shepherds lead the sheep along good paths to safety, leaders should teach the people the truth and help them do what is right. Judah’s leaders were not doing this. Alternate translation: “your leaders are like bad shepherds who lead you away from good paths and do not show you where to go” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: those who guide you lead you astray and confuse the direction of your path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh’s decision to harm the people as if Yahweh were bringing a legal accusation in a courtroom against the people of Israel. The second part of this line means the same thing as the first part, but it says it a little more completely. Alternate translation: “It is as though Yahweh had taken his place in a courtroom and were ready to accuse the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh stands up for an accusation; he is standing to accuse the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Judgment is spoken of as if it were an object that one could bring to another person. Alternate translation: “will announce his judgment” or “will declare his judgment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will come with judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making people suffer is spoken of as if it were crushing them with a very heavy weight. Alternate translation: “cruelly harm my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: crush my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making people suffer is spoken of as if it were rubbing their faces into the ground. Alternate translation: “harm the poor and make them suffer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: grind the faces of the poor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zion, meaning here the city of Jerusalem, is spoken of as if it were a woman with her daughters. Alternate translation: “the women of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the daughters of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Fruit” sometimes simply represents food produced in the land, and sometimes it represents spiritual blessings. This could mean: (1) God will cause the land to produce good food again. Alternate translation: “the people who are still in Israel will enjoy the best food from the land” or (2) the future Messiah will bring spiritual blessings to the people in the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fruit of the land will be tasty and delightful for those survivors in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression speaks of sin as if it were physical dirt. Alternate translation: “after the Lord removes the sins of the daughters of Zion as someone washes away filth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when the Lord will have washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is how God would remove the sin from Jerusalem. Here “spirit” probably represents the activity of judging and burning. Alternate translation: “by judgment and flaming fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: by means of the spirit of judgment and the spirit of flaming fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor that means Yahweh will remove sinners from Zion like a fire removes impurities or (2) “flaming fire” is a metonym that represents the destruction in general of all the sinners. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the spirit of flaming fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of a space separating two things is often used to express the idea of choosing one or the other of those things. Alternate translation: “decide who has acted right, I or my vineyard” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: judge between me and my vineyard

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Judah are spoken of as if they are a vine that Yahweh planted. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “the people of Judah are like a vine that Yahweh planted for Yahweh’s pleasure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the man of Judah his pleasant planting

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the power of wine to make its drinkers drunk is spoken of as if it were inflaming them, that is, setting them on fire. Alternate translation: “until they are drunk with wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: until wine inflames them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase speaks of Sheol, which stands here for the grave, to an animal that is ready to eat other animals. It implies that many, many people will die. Alternate translation: “death is like a hungry animal that has opened its mouth wide to eat up many people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Sheol has made its appetite greater and has opened its mouth very wide

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here proud, arrogant people are spoken of as if they are high above other people. Alternate translation: “proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the lofty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being honored is spoken of as if it were being lifted high. Alternate translation: “will be greatly honored” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will be exalted

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s plans are spoken of as if they were objects that could come by themselves. Alternate translation: “let the Holy One of Israel accomplish his plans” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: let the plans of the Holy One of Israel come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Those who do these things are the same as those “who call evil good, and good evil.” These things are opposites and people know the difference between them, but some people lie and say that bad things are good. Alternate translation: “They are like people who call darkness light and light darkness. They are like people who call bitter things sweet and sweet things bitter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who represent darkness as light, and light as darkness & bitter as sweet, and sweet as bitter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of these people as if they were a dying plant. Alternate translation: “they will die like a plant whose roots have rotted and whose blossom has dried up and blown away in the wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their root will rot, and their blossom will blow away like dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh’s anger as if it were a fire. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is very angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the anger of Yahweh is kindled

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the enemy killing the people of Judah to a lion killing a weaker animal. This could mean: (1) lions make a sound not as loud as a roar just before they strike, or (2) the writer is using two words to mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: They will growl and seize the prey

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here darkness represents suffering and disaster. This metaphor can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “the dark clouds will completely block the light of the sun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: even the light will be made dark by the clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the earth as if it were a container and glory were the contents in the container. Alternate translation: “Everything on the earth is evidence of God’s glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The whole earth is full of his glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh no longer considering a person to be guilty is spoken of as if “guilt” were an object that someone could take away from someone else. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your guilt has been taken away

contextId.occurrenceNote: “make it so that they cannot hear, and make it so that they cannot see.” Isaiah making people to not understand Yahweh’s message or what he is doing is spoken of as if Isaiah were making them deaf and blind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their ears dull, and blind their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being able to understand Yahweh’s message and what he is doing is spoken of as if the people were able physically to see and hear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they might see with their eyes, hear with their ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Repenting and starting to obey Yahweh is spoken of as if the people were physically to turn towards him. Alternate translation: “follow me again” or “then start trusting in me again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: then turn

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people who will serve Yahweh after armies destroy Israel are spoken of as if they were set apart as a holy seed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the holy seed

contextId.occurrenceNote: God compares Rezin and Pekah to burning sticks whose fire has gone out and are making smoke now. God is emphasizing that they are not real threats to Judah. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “do not let Rezin and Pekah make you afraid; their fierce anger is like a burning stick whose fire has gone out and there is only smoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: do not be afraid or intimidated by these two smoldering firebrands, by the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram, and of Pekah son of Remaliah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the armies of Egypt and Assyria are spoken of as if they are insects that will invade the land of Israel. This can be stated as a simile. Alternate translation: “for the armies of Egypt and Assyria, and their soldiers will be everywhere like flies and bees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]]and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: for a fly from the distant streams of Egypt, and for a bee from the land of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “razor” is a metaphor for the king of Assyria and his army, and Yahweh speaks of the king as if the king were a man who would do Yahweh’s work and then receive money from Yahweh. Alternate translation: “the Lord will call the king of Assyria from beyond the Euphrates River to work for him to shave you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the Lord will shave with a razor that was hired beyond the Euphrates River—the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah does not say whose head, hair, and beard the Lord is going to shave, but Ahaz and the reader would understand that this is a man; the man is a metaphor for the people living in the land of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the head & the hair of the legs & the beard

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “gentle waters” are a metaphor for the law of the Lord. Alternate translation: “Because this people has rejected Yahweh’s law, which is like the gentle waters of Shiloah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Because this people has refused the gentle waters of Shiloah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The river symbolizes the army of Assyria. Alternate translation: “the army from Assyria, which is powerful like a mighty river” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the waters of the River, mighty and many, the king of Assyria and all his glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: The army of Assyria is like a flood of water. Alternate translation: “More and more soldiers will come like a river rising up to your neck” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The River will sweep onward into Judah, flooding and passing on, until it reaches to your neck
