contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) as “the River” in the metaphor rises, its “wings” flow over and cover what had been dry land or (2) Isaiah changes metaphors and now speaks of Yahweh as a bird who is protecting the land, “But his outstretched wings will cover.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Its outstretched wings will fill

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sanctuary” is a metaphor for Yahweh keeping his people safe and protecting them. Alternate translation: “He will protect them when they go to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will become a sanctuary

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of people who do not know God as if they were people walking in darkness without any light. Alternate translation: “it is because they are like a person lost in the dark” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it is because they have no light of dawn

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of people who are spiritually lost as if they were walking around in total darkness. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will remove the darkness from her who was in anguish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The gloom will be dispelled from her who was in anguish

contextId.occurrenceNote: “her who was suffering great pain and sadness.” This is probably a metaphor for the people of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her who was in anguish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the people living sinful lives and suffering because of it as if they had been walking in a dark or living in a land of shadow of death. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walked in darkness & lived in the land of the shadow of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “light” represents hope and deliverance. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a great light & light has shone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the Israelites, who are the Assyrians’ slaves, as if they were an ox wearing a yoke. This will happen in the future, but he speaks as if it has already happened. Alternate translation: “For as on the day of Midian you will set the people of Israel free from being slaves to their oppressors like a person removes a yoke from the shoulders of an animal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: For the yoke of his burden & you have shattered as on the day of Midian

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the people of Israel as if they were one man. Alternate translation: “For the yoke of their burden … their shoulders … their oppressor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For the yoke of his burden & his shoulder & his oppressor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the power the oppressor has over the people of Judah as if it were the piece of wood used by a person to beat oxen so they will work. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the rod of his oppressor

contextId.occurrenceNote: His authority to rule is spoken of as if it were the robe that is a symbol of his authority. Alternate translation: “he will wear his royal robe on his shoulder” or “he will have authority to rule as king.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the rule will be on his shoulder

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Devour” is how wild animals eat their prey. Alternate translation: “Like a wild beast eating its prey, the army of the enemy will destroy the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will devour Israel with open mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah explains this metaphor in verse 15. The “head,” the part of an animal a person would want to be, is “the leader and the noble man,” and the “tail,” the dirty part of the animal, is “the prophet who teaches lies.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: head and tail

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “palm branch” grows high on the tree and is a metaphor for people who are important and rule others. The “reed” grows in shallow water and is a metaphor for people who are poor and unimportant and are ruled by others. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: palm branch and reed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders causing people to disobey is spoken of as if the leaders led them on the wrong path. Alternate translation: “The leaders of Israel have caused the people to disobey God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Those who lead this people lead them astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor that can be stated in active form. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: “those that they lead become confused” or (2) Alternate translation: “Yahweh destroys those that they lead” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: those who are led by them are swallowed up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people’s evil deeds are spoken of as if they were a very destructive fire. This fire burns even the briers and thorns, plants that grow in places where people no longer live, and “the thickets of the forest” where no one has ever lived, because it has already destroyed the places where people were living. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Wickedness burns like a fire; it devours the briers and thorns; it even burns the thickets of the forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) people will be so hungry that they will want to eat or will actually eat their own arms or (2) the word “arm” is a metaphor for the person’s neighbor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Each will even eat the flesh of his own arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares orphans to animals that other animals hunt and eat. This emphasizes that orphans are powerless and judges can easily harm them. Alternate translation: “harm children who do not have parents like an animal that goes after its prey” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make the fatherless their prey

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his wrath as if it were more liquid than a container could hold; “the people” are trying to carry this container, but it is heavy, and Yahweh keeps pouring liquid in even after it starts to spill out. Alternate translation: “at whom I continue to be angry even after I have punished them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who bear my overflowing wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the king of Assyria has shamed the people of the countries he conquered or (2) he has removed the kings of the nations so they no longer rule. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have brought down the inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “light of Israel” refers to Yahweh. It is unclear whether Yahweh or Isaiah is speaking. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, the light of Israel, will become like a fire, able to destroy everyone that does not honor me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The light of Israel will become a fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The fire will burn and devour the king of Assyria’s thorns and briars.” The speaker compares the king of Assyria’s army to thorns and briers. This emphasizes how easily God will destroy them. Alternate translation: “I will destroy the Assyrians like a fire burning thorns and briers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will burn and devour his thorns and briers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “Yahweh will destroy the great forests and farmlands in the nation of Assyria” or (2) “Yahweh will destroy the army of Assyria as a fire burns up great forests and farmlands.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will consume the glory of his forest and of his fruitful land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “rod” and “staff” refer to pieces of wood that people use as clubs to beat animals and other people. Isaiah speaks of the way the Assyrians will rule over the Israelites as if the Assyrians were beating the Israelites with clubs. Alternate translation: “He will rule over you and make slaves of you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will strike you with the rod and raise his staff against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: “will beat the Assyrians with a whip.” God will not really use a whip. This refers to God’s power to punish the Assyrians severely. Alternate translation: “will punish the Assyrians severely as if with a whip” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will wield a whip against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of God rescuing the people from the Assyrians as if they were the Egyptian army. This refers to when God caused the water of the Red Sea to split so the people of Israel could escape from the Egyptian army and so that the Egyptian army would drown in it. Alternate translation: “He will help you escape from the army of Assyria as he helped your ancestors escape the army of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will raise his rod over the sea and lift it up as he did in Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the army of Assyria as if it were the tall trees in Lebanon. God will destroy the army like people cutting down the mighty trees of Lebanon. This emphasizes that though the army is strong, God has the power to destroy it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will lop off the boughs & the lofty will be brought low

contextId.occurrenceNote: “will cut off the big branches of the trees.” In order to make it clear that this refers to the army of Assyria, it can be translated as a simile: He will destroy the army of Assyria like strong men cutting off the big branches of trees. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will lop off the boughs

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for “the strongest soldiers.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the tallest trees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the army of Assyria as if it were the tall trees in Lebanon. God will destroy the army like people cutting down the mighty trees of Lebanon. This emphasizes that though the army is strong, God has the power to destroy it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will chop down the thickets & and Lebanon in his majesty will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the dense shrubs in the forest.” This is possibly a metaphor for those people who are not well known. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the thickets of the forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the forests of Lebanon will no longer be so grand.” This is possibly a metaphor for the Assyrian army. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will defeat the army of Assyria, as mighty as it is” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Lebanon in his majesty will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: A stump is what remains of a tree after it is chopped down. The “stump of Jesse” represents what was left of the kingdom that Jesse’s son David was once king of. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the stump of Jesse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Resting upon him represents being with him and helping him. The word “him” refers to the one who would become king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The Spirit of Yahweh will rest upon him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wearing righteousness like a belt represents being righteous. This could mean: (1) the king’s righteousness will enable him to rule. Alternate translation: “His righteousness will be a like a belt around his waist” or (2) the king’s righteousness would show his authority to rule. Alternate translation: “He will rule righteously” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Righteousness will be the belt of his waist

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wearing faithfulness like a belt represents being faithful. This could mean: (1) the king’s faithfulness will enable him to rule, or (2) the king’s faithfulness will show his authority to rule. Alternate translation: “his faithfulness will be a like a belt around his hips” or “he will rule faithfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: faithfulness the belt around his hips

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “The Lord will set up the king as a banner for the nations” or (2) “The king will set up a banner for the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will set up a banner for the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel and Judah are pictured as if they were birds that fly down quickly to attack a person or animal. Alternate translation: “they will go quickly to the Philistine hills to attack the people there” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will swoop down on the Philistine hills

contextId.occurrenceNote: Waving his hand over something represents his power to change it. Alternate translation: “By his power he will cause a scorching wind to blow on the Euphrates River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: With his scorching wind he will wave his hand over the Euphrates River

contextId.occurrenceNote: God causing someone’s salvation is spoken of as if God were that salvation. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **salvation**, you can express the same idea with the noun “savior” or the verb “save.” Alternate translation: “God causes my salvation” or “God is my savior” or “God is the one who saves me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: God is my salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: God causing someone to be strong is spoken of as if Yahweh were their strength. Alternate translation: “Yahweh makes me strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh is my strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “song” here represents what a person sings about. Alternate translation: “the one I joyfully sing about” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: song

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of people being saved as if they were getting salvation the way people get water out of well. Alternate translation: “you will rejoice when he saves you, as people rejoice when they draw water from a well” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The soldiers that God is sending to attack Babylon are spoken of as if they were weapons. “Judgment” represents punishment because God has judged Babylon. Alternate translation: “the army that he will use to punish Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his instruments of judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that is about to happen soon is spoken of as if it is coming near. Alternate translation: “the day of Yahweh will happen soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of Yahweh is near

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “it” refers to the day of Yahweh. “It comes with destruction” means that destruction will happen on that day. “Destruction from the Almighty” means that the Almighty will destroy them. Alternate translation: “on that day, the Almighty God will destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: it comes with destruction from the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: People being terribly afraid is spoken of as if their hearts melt. Alternate translation: “everyone is terribly afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: every heart melts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being in labor represents giving birth to a baby. Alternate translation: “like a woman giving birth to a baby” or “like the pain of a woman who is giving birth to a baby” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: like a woman in labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their faces being hot and red is spoken of as if they were burning. Possible reasons for their faces being hot are: (1) the people are very afraid or (2) the people feel ashamed or (3) the people cry. Alternate translation: “their faces will be hot and red” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their faces will be aflame

contextId.occurrenceNote: The day coming with wrath and anger means that there will be wrath and anger on that day. The abstract nouns “wrath” and “anger” can be expressed with the adjectives “furious” and “angry.” Alternate translation: “on the day of Yahweh, he will be furious and extremely angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the day of Yahweh comes with cruel wrath and overflowing anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Anger here is spoken of as if the one who is angry is a container filled with anger. Overflowing anger means that he is extremely angry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: overflowing anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being low often represents being humble. Bringing down people’s arrogance represents making them humble. Alternate translation: “will humble the ruthless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will bring down the arrogance of the ruthless

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making people want to do something is spoken of as stirring them up. Alternate translation: “I am about to make the Medes want to attack them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am about to stir up the Medes to attack them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being laid low represents being made powerless and unimportant. Alternate translation: “Since you have become powerless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Since you are laid low

contextId.occurrenceNote: The dead kings will speak of the king of Babylon having no more splendor as if his splendor had gone down to Sheol. Alternate translation: “Your splendor ended when God sent you here to Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Your pomp has been brought down to Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: People would make music on string instruments to honor the king. The dead kings will speak of people no longer honoring the king of Babylon with music as if the music went to Sheol. Alternate translation: “along with the sound of people playing music to honor you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: with the sound of your string instruments

contextId.occurrenceNote: The maggots under his dead body are spoken of as if they were a mat or bed. Alternate translation: “You lie on a bed of maggots” or “You lie on many maggots” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Maggots are spread under you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The worms all over his body are spoken of as if they were covering him like a blanket. Alternate translation: “Worms cover you like a blanket” or “There are worms all over your body” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: worms cover you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The daystar is a bright star that rises just before morning. The people of Israel will refer to the king of Babylon in terms of this star in order to imply that he once was great, but now he was not. Alternate translation: “You were like the bright morning star, but you have fallen from the sky” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: How you are fallen from heaven, daystar, son of the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel will speak of the king of Babylon as if he were a tree that was cut down. Alternate translation: “You are defeated like a tree that someone has cut down to the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: How you are cut down to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor for “conquered kingdoms” or (2) this is metonymy for “terrified the people of kingdoms.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: shook kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being thrown out of the grave represents not being buried. Alternate translation: “But you are not buried. Your body is left on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: But you are cast out of your grave

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “them” refers to the other kings who died and were buried properly. Joining them in burial represents being buried as they were. Alternate translation: “you will never be buried as other kings were buried” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You will not join them in burial

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents taking control of the people on the earth, in this case by conquering them. Alternate translation: “take control of the peoples on the earth” or “conquer the peoples on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: possess the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents causing the world to have many cities on it. Alternate translation: “build cities all over the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: fill the whole world with cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents wild animals living in the city because there are no people there. Alternate translation: “a place where owls live” or “a place where wild animals live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a possession of owls

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing there to be swamps or ponds of stagnant water where the city was is spoken of as making the city into those things. Alternate translation: “into a place where there are stagnant ponds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: into pools of water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Breaking represents defeating. Alternate translation: “I will defeat the Assyrian in my land” or “I will cause the Assyrian in my land to be defeated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will break the Assyrian in my land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents completely defeating him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: trample him underfoot

contextId.occurrenceNote: God being ready to punish the nations is spoken of as if he raised his hand in order to hit them. The word “hand” may also represent his power. Alternate translation: “this is Yahweh’s power to punish all the nations” or “this is how Yahweh will punish the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: this is the hand that is raised over all the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents Yahweh being ready to punish the nations. Alternate translation: “He is ready to punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: His hand is raised

contextId.occurrenceNote: The rod that struck Philistia represents a king who sent his army to attack them. Being broken represents either being dead or being defeated. Alternate translation: “the king that sent his army against you is dead” or “the army that attacked you is defeated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the rod that struck you is broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “fiery” probably refers to the serpent’s poisonous bite, and the word “flying” refers to its quick movements. Alternate translation: “a quickly moving poisonous snake” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a fiery flying serpent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the poorest people. Alternate translation: “The poorest people” or “The poorest of my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The firstborn of the poor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “your root” refers to the people of Philistia. Alternate translation: “I will kill your people with famine that will put to death all your survivors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will kill your root with famine that will put to death all your survivors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Melting away represents becoming weak because of fear. Alternate translation: “you will grow weak with fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will melt away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this represents a cloud of dust that the army stirs up as they travel on dry dirt roads. Alternate translation: “a cloud of dust” or (2) there is a lot of smoke because of all the things that the army destroys and burns. Alternate translation: “much smoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a cloud of smoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: People’s crying out and others hearing it is spoken of as if the cry had gone out. Alternate translation: “People all over the territory of Moab cry out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The cry has gone around the territory of Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heat of the middle of the day represents the Moabites’ suffering from their enemies, and shade represents protection from their enemies. Comparing the shade to night shows that they want strong protection. Alternate translation: “protect us completely from our enemies as a large shadow protects people from the hot sun” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: provide some shade like night in the middle of the day

contextId.occurrenceNote: Providing a hiding place is spoken of as being a hiding place. Alternate translation: “give them a place to hide from those who are trying to destroy them” or “hide them from those who want to destroy them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: be a hiding place for them from the destroyer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Seeking justice represents wanting to do what is just. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: as he seeks justice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The land of Moab was known for its vineyards. Here God describes the land of Moab as one large vineyard. This emphasizes that the rulers, which refers to the armies, completely destroyed everything in Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The rulers of the nations have trampled the choice vines

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of his deep sorrow for these places as if he would cry much and his many tears would fall on them. Alternate translation: “I will cry much for you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will water you with my tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Gleanings” here represents the people who will still live in Israel. Alternate translation: “But there will be a few people left in Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Gleanings will be left

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares God to a large rock which people could climb on to get away from their enemies or hide behind. Alternate translation: “have ignored God, who is like a rock that protects you” or “have ignored the one who protects you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have ignored the rock of your strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: What happens to them is spoken of as if it is a portion that they inherit. Alternate translation: “This is what happens to those” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: This is the portion of those

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, the phrase **the rustling of wings** could mean (1) the boats that have sails are spoken of as having wings. Alternate translation: “Woe to those who live in the land beyond the rivers of Cush, whose many ships look like insects on the water” or (2) the rustling of wings refers to the noise of insects that have wings, perhaps locusts. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to the land of the rustling of wings, which is along the rivers of Cush

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Nile River was very wide, and people in Egypt and Cush referred to it as “the sea.” Alternate translation: “on the great river” or “along the Nile River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: by the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh seems to be pictured here as riding on a cloud as if he was riding in a chariot. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh rides on a swift cloud

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart melting represents losing their courage. Alternate translation: “the Egyptians have no more courage” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the hearts of the Egyptians melt within themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being crushed represents being discouraged. Alternate translation: “will be discouraged” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will be crushed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The princes of Zoan and Memphis are spoken of as if they are the cornerstones of buildings because they are an important part of the community. Alternate translation: “the leaders have made Egypt go astray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they have made Egypt go astray, who are the cornerstones of her tribes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh’s judgment as if Egypt was a cup of wine. He speaks of Yahweh causing the leaders’ thoughts to be distorted as if their distorted thoughts were a liquid that Yahweh mixed in with the wine. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has judged them by distorting their thoughts” or “Yahweh has judged Egypt by distorting its leaders’ thoughts, as intoxicating drinks confuse people’s thoughts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has mixed a spirit of distortion into her midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: Leading people astray represents influencing them to do what is wrong. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have led Egypt astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “head,” the part of an animal a person would want to be, represents the leader. The “tail” is the opposite and represents people who follow. Alternate translation: “whether leader or follower” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: whether head or tail

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon being completely defeated by their enemies is spoken of as if Babylon has fallen. Here “Babylon” is a metonym that represents the people of Babylon. Alternate translation: “The people of Babylon are completely defeated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Babylon has fallen, fallen

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel suffering because of the Babylonians is spoken of as if the people were grain that was threshed and winnowed. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My threshed and winnowed ones, children of my threshing floor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The terror and suffering that is experienced during war is spoken of as if war were a heavy weight on people. Alternate translation: “from the horrors of war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from the weight of war

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy soldiers coming and taking Shebna as a captive to a foreign land is spoken of as if Yahweh were throwing him like a ball into another land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will surely wind you round and round, and toss you like a ball into a vast country

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing Shebna to no longer work in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will throw him to the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will thrust you from your office and from your station & ou will be pulled down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing Eliakim to take Shebna’s place in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Yahweh will dress Eliakim in Shebna’s clothes that represent his authority in the king’s palace. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will clothe him with your tunic and put on him your sash

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eliakim caring for and protecting the people of Judah is spoken of as if he would be their father. Alternate translation: “He will be like a father” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will be a father

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing Eliakim’s authority to be strong and secure in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg and Yahweh will set him firmly in the palace wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will fasten him, a peg in a secure place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing Eliakim’s whole family to be honored because of Eliakim is spoken of as if Eliakim were a peg in the wall and his family were something that hangs on the peg. Alternate translation: “They will give honor to his whole family because of him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will hang on him all the glory of his father’s house

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues to speak of Eliakim as a peg. His offspring will be like cups that hang on the peg. This means his descendants will be honored because of him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: every small container from the cups to all the jugs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his authority in the king’s palace is spoken of as if Shebna were a peg in the wall that breaks off and falls to the ground. This emphasizes that Shebna thought his authority was secure but God will remove him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the peg driven in a firm place & will be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The merchants are compared to princes to emphasize how much power they had when they went to different lands. Alternate translation: “whose merchants are like princes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: whose merchants are princes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh using his power to control the sea and the people of mighty kingdoms is spoken of as if Yahweh reached out his hand and shook kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has reached out with his hand over the sea, and he has shaken the kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about the people of Tyre as if they were a prostitute. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: like in the song of the prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about the people of Tyre as if they were a prostitute (verse 15). Just as a prostitute who is no longer popular may sing in the streets to regain her former lovers, the people of Tyre will try to get people from other nations to return to them to continue trading so that the people of Tyre will be rich and powerful again. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Take a harp, go about the city, you forgotten prostitute & so that you may be remembered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the people of Tyre with a prostitute. Just as the prostitute sells herself for money to any man, the people of Tyre will again buy and sell to all kingdoms. Alternate translation: “And like a prostitute they will buy and sell will all the kingdoms of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: she will start making money again by doing the work of a prostitute & of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people sinning and making the earth unacceptable to God is spoken of as if the people made the earth physically unclean. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The people have polluted the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The earth is polluted by its inhabitants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh cursing the earth and destroying it is spoken of as if a curse were either a wild animal that completely eats the earth or a fire that completely burns up the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a curse devours the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of large amounts of rain falling from the sky as if Yahweh opened a window in the sky and let the water pour through. Alternate translation: “The sky will split open and torrents of rain will fall” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The windows of the heavens will be opened

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the earth as if it were a person and transgressions were a heavy object. The person tries to carry the heavy weight but the weight causes the person to fall and not be able to stand back up. Here the earth represents the people of the earth who cause Yahweh to destroy the earth because of their sins. Alternate translation: “The sins of the people are many and so Yahweh will destroy the earth, and the earth will be like a person who falls and cannot get back up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Its sin will be heavy on it and it will fall and never rise again

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh protecting his people is spoken of as if he were a place that the people could go to be safe and comforted. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you have been a place of safety & a shelter & a shelter from the storm & a shade from the heat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Death, suffering, and sadness are spoken of as if they were a dark cloud or web that covers everyone on the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: the covering over all peoples, the web woven over all the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing people to live forever is spoken of as if he would swallow death. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will swallow up death forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people to never be ashamed again is spoken of as if disgrace were an object that Yahweh would take away. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the disgrace of his people he will take away from all the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh destroying the people of Moab is spoken of as if he would step on them and crush them. This is compared to how people trampled on straw to mix it with manure. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab will be trampled down in his place, even as straw is trampled down in a pit filled with manure

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh humiliating a proud person is spoken of as if pride were something high and Yahweh would cause it to be low. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will bring down their pride

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s power to protect and save his people is spoken of as if his salvation were walls around a city. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: God has made salvation its walls and ramparts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh having the power to protect his people is spoken of as if he were a tall rock where people could go to escape from their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh, is an everlasting rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh humiliating those who are proud is spoken of as if proud people were up high and he would cause them to come down low. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will bring down those who live proudly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doing what Yahweh judged to be right is spoken of walking on his path. Alternate translation: “we wait for you, Yahweh, as we continue to do what you judged to be right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in the path of your judgments, Yahweh, we wait for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wanting to know Yahweh and his laws better is spoken of as if the person were seeking to find Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I earnestly want to know you better” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my spirit within me seeks you earnestly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh preparing to punish wicked people is spoken of as if his hand were raised and about to hit the wicked people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your hand is lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing and completely destroying his adversaries is spoken of as if he would send a fire that will completely burn them up. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: fire of your adversaries will devour them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing people to no longer remember those he destroyed is spoken of as if Yahweh made their memory perish or die. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: made every memory of them to perish

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of dead people coming back to life as if they were waking up from sleep. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Awake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh acting kindly towards his people and bringing them back to life is spoken of as if it were the dew that causes the plants to live. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for your dew is the dew of light

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the earth will give birth to those who died.” Yahweh causing dead people to come back to life is spoken of as if the earth would give birth to those who have died. Alternate translation: “and Yahweh will cause those who have died to rise from the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the earth will bring forth its dead

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh having the power to destroy his enemies is spoken of as if he had strong, large sword. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh with his hard, great and fierce sword will punish

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Sing about the vineyard of wine.” This speaks about the people of Israel as if they were a vineyard that produced fruit. Alternate translation: “Sing about the people of Israel as if they were a vineyard that produced grapes for wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A vineyard of wine, sing of it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemies of the people of Israel are spoken of as if they were briers and thorns growing in the vineyard. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that there were briers and thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh fighting his enemies is spoken of as if he were a warrior in an army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: In battle I would march against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Isaiah combines different images to speak of Yahweh’s enemies. He speaks of them as if they are briers and thorns but also as soldiers in an army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I would march against them; I would burn them all together

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about a day as if it travels and arrives somewhere. Alternate translation: “In the future” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: In the coming day

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh blessing the people of Israel and causing them to prosper is spoken of as if they were a vine that grows roots and blossoms. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Israel will prosper like a vine that has taken root and blossomed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob will take root; Israel will blossom and bud

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people of Israel to prosper greatly so that they can help other people is spoken of as if they were a vine that grows so much fruit that it would cover the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will fill the surface of the ground with fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s power to send his people away to a foreign country is spoken of as if Yahweh used his breath to blow them to a foreign country. Alternate translation: “the power of Yahweh drove them out like a fierce wind from the east” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he drove them away with his fierce breath in the day of the east wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the results of an action as if it were the fruit that grows as on a tree or vine. Alternate translation: “the result” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the full fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people becoming so weak because they disobey Yahweh so that enemies can easily destroy them is spoken of as if they are dry branches that women break off of a tree. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: When the boughs & not a people of understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh gathering his people to bring them back from the foreign nations to the land of Israel is spoken of as if he were threshing wheat to separate the grain from the chaff. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will thresh

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “garland” is a crown made of flowers. Here it represents the city of Samaria, the capital of Israel, which sits above a fertile valley. Samaria and its people being destroyed is spoken of as if the flowers in the garland will grow old and stop being beautiful. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to the proud garland & on the head of the lush Valley of those who are overcome with wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king and his powerful army destroying the people of Samaria and their city is spoken of as if the king will throw the people’s garlands onto the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will throw each garland crown down to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “garland” is a crown made of flowers. Here it represents the city of Samaria, the capital of Israel, which sits above a fertile valley. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: proud garland & of Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Samaria, the capital of Israel, sits above a fertile valley. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that is on the head of the rich valley

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were to become a beautiful crown that the people who honor him as their true king would wear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will become a beautiful crown and a diadem of beauty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their drinking so much that they can no longer think properly is spoken of as if the wine swallowed them. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the wine is causing them to be confused” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they are swallowed up by wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: People losing in battle to the enemy army is spoken of as if the people will fall down and break. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: go and fall backward, and be broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy soldiers capturing the people of Israel is spoken of as if they were hunters that catch an animal in a snare. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: ensnared

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh’s judgment and punishment as if it were a whip that would strike the people. And the whip is spoken of as if it were a flood that would pass through Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “As a result, when everyone else is suffering and dying, nothing will harm us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: So when the overwhelming whip passes through, it will not reach us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh sending a strong person to help the people of Israel is spoken of as if Yahweh is constructing a strong foundation for a building. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will lay in Zion a foundation stone & sure foundation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh testing according to his justice and righteousness to determine if the people are just and righteous is spoken of as if he were a builder using tools to determine that something is the correct length and perfectly level. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make justice the measuring stick, and righteousness the plumbline

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing a large amount of hail to fall is spoken of as if it would be an overwhelming flood. Alternate translation: “Hailstorms will destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Hail will sweep away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh punishing the people even more severely is spoken of as if he would tighten their bonds. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will tighten your bonds” or “Yahweh will punish you even more severely” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: your bonds will be tightened

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people ignoring what Yahweh says is spoken of as if they would make themselves blind. Alternate translation: “keep being ignorant and spiritually blind to what I am showing you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: blind yourselves and be blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people being senseless and not understanding what Yahweh is doing is spoken of as if they were drunk. Alternate translation: “Be senseless like a drunk person, but it is not because you have drank too much wine or beer” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Be drunk, but not with wine; stagger, but not with beer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the spirit of” means “to have the characteristic of” being asleep. Yahweh causing the people to be asleep is spoken of as if “the spirit” were a liquid that he poured out on the people. Also “deep sleep” is a metaphor that means the people are senseless and cannot understand what Yahweh is doing. Alternate translation: “The reason you are senseless is because Yahweh has caused you to be spiritually asleep” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For Yahweh has poured out on you the spirit of deep sleep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the people to be senseless and not to understand what he is doing is spoken of as if he closed their eyes and covered their heads so they could not see. Alternate translation: “It is as though Yahweh has closed the eyes of the prophets and covered the heads of the seers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He has closed your eyes, the prophets, and has covered your heads, the seers

contextId.occurrenceNote: People trying to make plans without Yahweh knowing about it is spoken of as if they hide their plans in a deep place where Yahweh cannot see. Alternate translation: “who try to hide their plans from Yahweh” or “who try to keep Yahweh from finding out what they are planning to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who deeply hide their plans from Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh who created humans is spoken of as if he were a potter and humans were the clay. This metaphor emphasizes that it is foolish for humans to reject or criticize the one who created them. Alternate translation: “Should you consider me, your maker, to be like the clay rather than the potter? It is as if a potter created something, and that thing said about the potter, ‘He did not make me,’ or ‘He does not understand.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Should the potter be considered like clay, so that the thing that is made should say about him who made it & “He does not understand”?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is literal and Yahweh will cause the places where trees grew wild in Lebanon to become fruitful fields or (2) this is a metaphor and the large forests of Lebanon represent powerful oppressors, and the crops that grow in the field and become a forest are the common people who are suffering. This means Yahweh will humble those who are powerful, but he will honor those who are suffering. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Lebanon will be turned into a field, and the field will become a forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is literal and Yahweh will cause deaf people to hear and blind people to see or (2) this is a metaphor that means Yahweh will enable the people to hear and understand his message or (3) it may mean both options 1 and 2. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the deaf will hear the words of a book, and the eyes of the blind will see out of the deep darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The evil people doing anything they can to stop a good person is spoken of as if the evil people set a trap like a hunter catching his prey. Alternate translation: “They lie and try to stop those who want to do what is fair and right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They lay a snare for him who seeks justice at the gate and put the righteous down with empty lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks about his people as if they were his children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the rebellious children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Continuing to sin is spoken of as if sins were objects that could be stacked on one another. Alternate translation: “they continue to sin more and more” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they add sin to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Egypt’s protection from enemy armies is spoken of as if it were a shadow that protects someone from the burning heat of the sun. Alternate translation: “they rely on the Egyptians to keep them safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: take refuge in the shadow of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Egypt’s protection from enemy armies is spoken of as if it were a shadow that protects someone from the burning heat of the sun. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the refuge in Egypt’s shade

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of time as if it travels and arrives somewhere. Alternate translation: “for a future time” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for the time to come

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh’s people as if they were his children. This can be translated as a new sentence. Alternate translation: “They behave like children who lie and do not listen to what Yahweh commands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: lying children, children who will not hear the instruction of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: How Yahweh wants his people to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path on which to walk. To disobey Yahweh is spoken of as if the person strays away from Yahweh’s path. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Turn aside from the way, stray off the path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Repenting is spoken of as if it were physically returning to Yahweh. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will save you from your enemies if you will repent and rest knowing that I will take care of you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: In returning and resting you will be saved

contextId.occurrenceNote: How Yahweh wants his people to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path. To obey Yahweh is spoken of as if it were a person walking on his path. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: This is the way, walk in it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying Yahweh is spoken of as if the person turned left or right off of Yahweh’s path. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: when you turn to the right or when you turn to the left

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh comforting his people and causing their suffering to end is spoken of as if he would put bandages on their wounds. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will bind up the breaking of his people and heal the bruises of his wounding them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh being extremely angry is spoken of as if he were a large fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the name of Yahweh & like a devouring fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh separating the people of the nations and destroying the wicked people is spoken of as if Yahweh puts the nations in a sieve. This can be translated as a new sentence. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will separate and destroy the wicked people of the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to sift the nations with the sieve of destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh having the power to cause people’s plans to fail or causing them to be destroyed is spoken of as if his breath were a bridle that steers people off the correct path. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: His breath is a bridle in the jaws of the peoples to cause them to wander away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh having the power to protect his people is spoken of as if he were a rock on which the people could climb and escape from enemies. Alternate translation: “to Israel’s protective rock” or “which is like a protective rock for Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to the Rock of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s anger is spoken of as if it were a storm or a fire. Alternate translation: “in anger that is like a storm and flames of fire” or “in great anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in storming anger and flames of fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of Assyria’s fear as if Assyria is an object that Yahweh’s voice shatters. Alternate translation: “Assyria will be terrified” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Assyria will be shattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing an army to defeat the Assyrians is spoken of as if Yahweh would hit the Assyrians with a rod. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Every stroke of the appointed rod that Yahweh will lay on them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing the enemy army to defeat the Assyrians is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who would fight along with the enemy army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he battles and fights with them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about people relying on their horses to help them as if they were leaning on their horses. Alternate translation: “rely on their horses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: lean on horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “retract his words” speaks of a person not fulfilling what they said they will do as if the words that he had said were something that he could pull back to himself. Here it says that Yahweh will not do this, meaning he will fulfill what he has said. Alternate translation: “he will do what he said he would do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will not retract his words

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how Yahweh protects and rescues Jerusalem, describing him as a bird that flies over the city. Alternate translation: “he will protect and rescue the city from it’s enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will protect and rescue as he passes over it and preserves it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases emphasize that the leaders will enable the people to understand God’s truth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Then the eyes & attentively

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh giving him Spirit to his people as if his Spirit were a liquid that he would pour on them. Alternate translation: “the Spirit is given to us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the Spirit is poured on us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh ruling Zion with his justice and righteousness as if he were filling Zion with justice and righteousness. Alternate translation: “He will rule Zion with justice and righteousness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will fill Zion with justice and righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh causing his people to be secure as if he were the stability himself. The phrase “your times” refers to their lives. Alternate translation: “He will make you secure all your lives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He will be the stability in your times

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of fearing Yahweh as if it were a treasure that Yahweh gives his people. Alternate translation: “revering Yahweh will be like a valuable treasure that he will give to you” or “to fear Yahweh will be as valuable to you as a treasure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fear of Yahweh is his treasure

contextId.occurrenceNote: To arise or stand up is a metaphor for no longer watching and thinking and instead beginning to act. Alternate translation: “will I begin to act” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will I arise

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the Assyrians making plans as if they were conceiving and giving birth to their plans as a mother gives birth to a baby. This speaks of their plans being useless by comparing them to chaff. Alternate translation: “You make plans that are as useless as chaff and straw” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You conceive chaff, and you give birth to stubble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the man being safe as if he lived in a home on a high hill. These two phrase are parallel and the second phrase describes the place where the man lives. Alternate translation: “he will be safe, like a man who home is built on a high hill, in a rocky place that is easy to defend” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: this is the man who will dwell on the heights, his place of defense will be the fortress among the cliffs

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of rocky areas that are easy to defend as if they were actually fortresses. Alternate translation: “the large piles of rocks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the fortress among the cliffs

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Zion being secure and well establish as if it were secure tent. This can be stated in active form and written as a new sentence. Alternate translation: “it will be secure, like a tent that no one will ever remove” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a tent that will not be removed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is part of the metaphor that compares Zion to a secure tent. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “whose stakes no one will ever pull up and whose cords no one will ever break” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: whose stakes will never be pulled up nor will any of its cords be broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes himself as a warrior bearing a sword. The phrase “drunk its fill” speaks of Yahweh’s sword as if it were a person who has eaten and become satisfied. Yahweh uses this imagery to emphasize that there will be a lot of destruction in heaven and to state its completion. Alternate translation: “when I am finished destroying things in heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: when my sword will have drunk its fill in heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “it” refers to Yahweh’s sword. This continues the metaphor about Yahweh destroying things with a sword. Alternate translation: “I will come to punish the people of Edom, the people whom I have set aside for me to destroy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: it will now come down on Edom, on the people I am setting apart for destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh killing the people as if he were a priest sacrificing animals. He does this by describing the sword of a priest. Alternate translation: “Yahweh sacrifices them as a priest sacrifices animals, whose sword drips with the blood and fat of lambs, goats, and rams” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The sword of Yahweh is dripping with blood and covered with fat & of rams

contextId.occurrenceNote: The water and land becoming useless for drinking or growing food because it is burnt and covered in pitch and sulfur is spoken of as if their streams and land will actually become pitch and sulfur. Alternate translation: “The streams in Edom will be full of pitch and the ground will be covered with burning sulfur and burning pitch” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The streams of Edom will be turned into pitch & become burning pitch

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh as if he were a careful builder as he causes destruction in Edom. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will measure that land carefully; he will measure it to decide where to cause ruin and destruction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will stretch over it the measuring line of ruin and the plumbline of destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh deciding where to cause the animals to live as if he actually cast lots for their places. Alternate translation: “He has determined where they will live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He has cast lots for their places

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the way that people measured things in biblical times. Alternate translation: “he has given the animals their places” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: his hand has measured it out for them by a cord

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh making the desert look beautiful as Carmel and Sharon as if he were giving the desert their splendor. The understood information may be supplied. Alternate translation: “the splendor of Carmel and Sharon will be given to it” or “Yahweh will make it as splendid as Carmel and Sharon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: the splendor of Carmel and Sharon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Egypt, specifically its army and its Pharaoh, as if it were a splintered reed to emphasize that relying on them would not help them but would only harm them. Alternate translation: “that is like walking with a splintered reed for a staff. If a man leans on it, it will stick into his hand and pierce it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that splintered reed that you use as a walking staff, but if a man leans on it, it will stick into his hand and pierce it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Praying to Yahweh is described this way to emphasize that Yahweh is in heaven. A prayer is spoken of as if they were objects that could be lifted high into the sky. Alternate translation: “pray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: lift up your prayer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to speaking loudly as if the person’s voice were an object that they lifted high. Alternate translation: “have you shouted” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have you exalted your voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: broken into small pieces. This is a metaphor for being greatly discouraged. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: shattered

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how weak and vulnerable the cities are before the Assryian army by comparing the cities to grass. Alternate translation: “The cities are as weak as the grass in the fields before your armies. They are as weak as the grass that grows on the roofs of houses and is scorched by the hot east wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They are plants in the field, green grass, the grass on the roof or in the field, before the east wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh hearing the king’s speech as if the king’s speech were something that traveled to his ear. Alternate translation: “I have heard you speaking arrogantly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your arrogance has reached my ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person uses a hook and bit to lead an animal around. This speaks of Yahweh controlling the king as if the king were an animal Yahweh controlled with a bit and hook. Alternate translation: “I will control you like a man controls his animal by place a hook in its nose and a bit in its mouth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put my hook in your nose, and my bit in your mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people of Judah becoming prosperous as if they were plants that would root and bear fruit. Alternate translation: “will prosper like a plant that takes root and produces fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will again take root and bear fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sight of Yahweh represents Yahweh’s judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “what pleases you” or “what you consider to be good” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: what was good in your sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of dying as if Sheol were a kingdom that has gates that one enters. Alternate translation: “I will die and go to Sheol” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will go through the gates of Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah speaks of Yahweh forgiving his sins as if they were objects that Yahweh threw behind himself and forgot about. Alternate translation: “for you have forgiven all my sins and no longer think about them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for you have thrown all my sins behind your back

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making the valleys level with the rest of the ground is spoken of as if it were lifting up the valleys. Alternate translation: “Every valley will be filled in” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Every valley will be lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “flesh” refers to people. The speaker speaks of humans as if they are grass, because they both die quickly. Alternate translation: “All people are like grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: All flesh is grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speaker speaks of humans as if they are grass, because they both die quickly. Alternate translation: “people die as quickly as grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: humanity is grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speaker speaks of what God says lasting forever as if his word stands forever. Alternate translation: “the things that our God says will last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the word of our God will stand forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh’s people as if they were sheep and of Yahweh as if he were their shepherd. Alternate translation: “He will care for his people like a shepherd feeds his flock” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will feed his flock like a shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh knowing how much water is in the oceans is spoken of as if Yahweh held the water in his hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: measured the waters in the hollow of his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “span” is the measure of length between the thumb and little finger when the hand is outstretched. Yahweh knowing the length of the sky is spoken of as if he measured it with his hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: measured the sky with the span of his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh knowing how much dust there is on the earth is spoken of as if he carried it in a basket. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: held the dust of the earth in a basket

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh knowing how heavy the mountains are is spoken of as if he weighed them in scales and balances. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: weighed the mountains in scales, or the hills in a balance?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of Yahweh creating the earth as if the earth were a building for which Yahweh laid the foundation. Alternate translation: “from the time that Yahweh created the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from the foundations of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of Yahweh ruling the earth as if Yahweh were seated on a throne above the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He is the one who sits above the horizon of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of rulers being helpless before Yahweh as if they were new plants that wither away when a hot wind blows on them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They are barely planted & and they wither

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of Yahweh removing the rulers from power as if Yahweh were a scorching wind that blows upon the plants and causes them to wither. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he blows upon them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “formations” refers to military formations. The prophet speaks of the stars as if they were soldiers whom Yahweh commands to appear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He leads out their formations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh not knowing what happens to them is spoken of as if Yahweh could not see the road upon which they travel. Alternate translation: “Yahweh does not know what happens to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My way is hidden from Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. AT “the farthest places of the earth” or “the entire earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: People receiving strength from Yahweh is spoken of as if the people were able to fly like eagles fly. An eagle is a bird often used as a symbol for strength and power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will soar with wings like eagles

contextId.occurrenceNote: Turning them to dust and stubble is a metaphor or exaggeration for completely destroying everything the people of these nations have made. The armies of one from the east will conquer these nations and scatter the people easily.
