(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: He turns them to dust with his sword, like windblown stubble with his bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this is a metaphor in which he and his army moving very quickly is spoken of as if his feet barely touch the ground. Alternate translation: “by a path on which he moves with great speed” or (2) “feet” represents the whole person and the phrase indicates that this is a path that they have not traveled before. Alternate translation: “by a path that he has never traveled before” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: by a swift path that his feet scarcely touch

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. AT “the farthest places of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh strengthening his people is spoken of as if he were holding them with his hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will uphold you with my righteous right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh helping the people of Israel is spoken of as if he were holding their right hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I & will hold your right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) that this refers to the opinions of other nations regarding the people of Israel or (2) that this refers to Israel’s own opinion of themselves. Yahweh speaks of their insignificance as if they were a worm. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob you worm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of enabling Israel to defeat their enemies as if he were making the nation a threshing sledge that will level mountains. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I am making you like a sharp threshing sledge & you will make the hills like chaff

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a double metaphor. The mountains are a metaphor for grain, and threshing grain is a metaphor for the Israelites defeating the powerful enemy nations near them. Alternate translation: “you will thresh your enemies and crush them as if they were grain, even though they appear to be as strong as mountains” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: you will thresh the mountains and crush them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hills are a metaphor for the powerful enemy nations near Israel. People having the wind blow the chaff away after they have threshed the grain is a metaphor for them allowing Yahweh to destroy their enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you will make the hills like chaff

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh speaks of people who are in extreme need as if they are extremely thirsty, and of his provision for them as if he caused water to appear in places where it normally would not appear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of appointing a person as if he raised that person up. Alternate translation: “I have appointed one” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have raised up one

contextId.occurrenceNote: Conquering the rulers of other nations is spoken of as if it were trampling them under foot. Alternate translation: “he will conquer the rulers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will trample the rulers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the worthlessness of the idols as if the idols are wind and nothing at all. Alternate translation: “their idols are all worthless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their cast metal figures are wind and emptiness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of weak and helpless people as if they were crushed reeds and dimly burning wicks. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A crushed reed he will not break, and a dimly burning wick he will not quench

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet speaks of Yahweh creating the heavens and the earth as if the heavens and earth were fabric which Yahweh stretched out. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who created the heavens and stretched them out, the one who made the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of making his servant the one who delivers the nations from bondage as if he were making him a light that shines in dark places for the Gentiles. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a light for the Gentiles

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing blind people to see is spoken of as if it were opening their eyes. Also, Yahweh speaks of his servant delivering those who have been wrongly imprisoned as if his servant were restoring sight to blind people. Alternate translation: “to enable the blind to see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to open the eyes of the blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “zeal” refers to the passion that a warrior experiences when he is about to fight a battle. Yahweh stimulating his zeal is spoken of as if he stirred it up like the wind stirs up waves of water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will stir up his zeal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this metaphorical language to describe his great power to conquer his enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will lay waste mountains & will dry up the marshes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his people being helpless as if they could not see because they were blind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his people being helpless as if they could not see because they walked in darkness, and of his helping them as if he caused light to shine in the darkness. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn the darkness into light before them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rejecting those who worship idols is spoken of as if it is forcing them to turn back and move the opposite direction. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I will reject them and put them to shame” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: They will be turned back, they will be completely put to shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ability to hear is spoken of as if the ears were open. Here the word “hears” refers to understanding what one hears. Alternate translation: “people hear, but no one understands what they hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: ears are open, but no one hears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh’s anger as if it were a liquid that could be poured out. Alternate translation: “he showed them just how angry he was” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he poured out on them his fierce anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of Yahweh’s fierce anger as if it were a fire that burned the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Its flames encircled them & it consumed them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paying attention to something and learning from it is spoken of as if it were placing that thing on one’s heart. Alternate translation: “they did not pay attention” or “they did not learn from it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they did not take it to heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of suffering and difficult experiences as if they are deep waters and fires through which the people walk. The words “waters” and “flames” form a merism and emphasize any difficult circumstance. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: When you pass through the waters & the flames will not destroy you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people who belong to him as if they were his children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my sons & my daughters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of those who do not listen to him or obey him as if they were blind and deaf. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the people who are blind & the deaf

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dying is spoken of as if it were falling down to the ground. Alternate translation: “They all died together; they will never live again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: They fell down together; they will never rise again

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people dying is spoken of as if they were burning candle wicks that someone has extinguished. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “their lives have ended, like a person extinguishes the flame of a burning candle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they are extinguished, quenched like a burning wick

contextId.occurrenceNote: Forgiving sins is spoken of as either: (1) blotting them out or wiping them away or (2) erasing a written record of the sins. Alternate translation: “who forgives your offenses like someone wiping something away” or “who forgives your offenses like someone who erases a record of sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who blots out your offenses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of creating the nation of Israel as if it were forming the nation as a baby in its mother’s womb. Alternate translation: “he who made you, as I form a baby in the womb” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he who made you and formed you in the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of giving his Spirit to the people of Israel as if he were causing rain to fall and streams to flow on dry ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pour water on the thirsty ground, and flowing streams on the dry ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Dry ground is spoken of as if it were a thirsty person. Alternate translation: “the dry ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: the thirsty ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of giving his Spirit to the people as if his Spirit were liquid that he pours out on them. Alternate translation: “I will give my Spirit to your offspring” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will pour my Spirit on your offspring

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel being prosperous and multiplying is spoken of as if they were plants that grow because they have plenty of water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will spring up among the grass, like willows by the streams of water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself as if he were a large rock under which people can find shelter. This means he has the power to protect his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: There is no other Rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to those who worship these idols and who claim to be witnesses of the idols’ power. Yahweh speaks of their inability to understand the truth as if they were blind. Alternate translation: “those who serve as witnesses for these idols are like blind people who know nothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: their witnesses cannot see or know anything

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of those who cannot understand the foolishness of worshiping idols as if they were blind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for their eyes are blind and cannot see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of a person worshiping an idol as if that person were eating the burned ashes of the wood from which he made the idol. Just as eating ashes does not benefit a person, neither does worshiping an idol. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It is as if he were eating ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “ruins” refers to places that have been destroyed. Yahweh speaks of rebuilding them as if he were raising them up. Alternate translation: “I will rebuild what others have destroyed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will raise up their ruins

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Cyrus ruling and protecting the people of Israel as if Cyrus is their shepherd. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He is my shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh helping Cyrus and causing him to be successful is spoken of as if he were holding his right hand. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: whose right hand I hold

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of removing obstacles that would hinder Cyrus’s success as if it were leveling mountains before him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: level the mountains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his righteousness as if it were rain that falls on the earth, and of his righteousness and salvation as plants that grow on the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You heavens, rain down from above & righteousness spring up together with it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself as if he were a potter, and of the one who would argue with him as if that person and the rest of humanity were all clay pots. Alternate translation: “like one piece of pottery among many other pieces of pottery scattered on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: any other earthen pot among all the earthen pots in the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of those who would argue him as if they were unborn children who argue with their own parents. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to him who says to a father, & ‘What are you giving birth to?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of causing Cyrus to act as if it were stirring him from slumber. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I stirred Cyrus

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of removing obstacles and causing Cyrus to be successful as if he were making the paths smooth on which Cyrus walks. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will smooth out all his paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: Living in continual humiliation is spoken of as if it were walking in humiliation. Alternate translation: “will be continually humiliated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will walk in humiliation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. AT “all the farthest places of the earth” or “the entire earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: all the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of people placing the idols of Bel and Nebo into a cart for animals to transport as if these gods were made to “bow down” and “stoop.” These are both postures of humiliation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Bel bows down, Nebo stoops; their idols & for weary animals

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of people carrying off these idols as if the false gods whom they represent are being carried off to captivity. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they themselves have gone off into captivity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the nation of Israel as if it were a person, and of the nation’s beginning as if it were its birth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who have been carried by me from before your birth, carried from the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of helping and rescuing the people of Israel as if he were carrying them. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “whom I have carried” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: who have been carried by me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the nation of Israel becoming very old as if it were an old man with gray hair. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Even to your old age I am he, and until your hair is gray I will carry you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Cyrus as if he were “a bird of prey.” As a bird swiftly captures its prey, so Cyrus will swiftly accomplish Yahweh’s purpose to conquer the nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I call a bird of prey from the east

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people stubbornly doing wrong as if they were physically far away from doing the right thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who are far from doing what is right

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this chapter, Yahweh speaks to Babylon about her downfall as if she were a queen who is humiliated. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to the city, Babylon, which is spoken of as if it were a daughter. That the city is a “daughter” indicates how people think fondly of her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: virgin daughter of Babylon & daughter of the Chaldeans

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Babylon being the capital city of the Babylonian empire as if it were a queen who ruled many kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: queen of kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel being his special possession as if they were his heritage or inheritance. Alternate translation: “I defiled my people, who are my special possession” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I defiled my heritage

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the Babylonians oppressing the old people as if they had treated the old people like cattle and put heavy yokes on their necks. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you placed a very heavy yoke on the old people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon speaks of permanently ruling over many nations as if she were a queen who would rule forever. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will rule forever as sovereign queen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of thinking carefully about something as if it were placing that thing on one’s heart. Alternate translation: “You did not consider these things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You did not take these things to heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Babylon believing that other nations will never be able to conquer her is spoken of as if she will never become a widow or never have children die. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will never sit as a widow & loss of children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of disaster as if it were a person who captures Babylon. Alternate translation: “You will experience disaster” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Disaster will overcome you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks Babylon being destroyed as if destruction were an object that falls upon the city. Alternate translation: “You will experience destruction” or “Others will destroy you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Destruction will fall on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Babylon experiencing calamity as if calamity were a person who strikes Babylon. Alternate translation: “You will experience calamity” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Calamity will strike you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase emphasizes that they are the direct, physical descendants of Judah. Alternate translation: “are the descendants of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: have come from the sperm of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of explaining something as if it were unfolding it. The word “ears” represents the people who are listening. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I did not explain these things to you beforehand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: these things were not unfolded to your ears beforehand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the nation’s beginning as if it were its birth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: from birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of using affliction to purify his people as if they were precious metals and affliction were a furnace in which he refines them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Look, I refined you, but not as silver; I have purified you in the furnace of affliction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Standing up when Yahweh calls is a metaphor for being ready to obey him. Yahweh speaks of the earth and the heavens as if they were able to hear him and obey him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: when I call to them, they stand up together

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh teaching the people how they should live is spoken of as if he were leading them to walk on the correct paths. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who leads you by the way that you should go

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases share similar meanings. In both, Yahweh speaks of Israel’s experiencing abundant blessings as if those blessings flowed like water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Then your peace and prosperity would have flowed like a river, and your salvation like the waves of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the descendants of the people of Israel as if they were children to which the nation gives birth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the children from your womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. Alternate translation: “to all the farthest places of the earth” or “to the entire earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: to the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh protecting his servant and keeping his purpose secret is spoken of as if Yahweh’s hand cast a shadow over him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he hid me in the shadow of his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s servant being able to carry out Yahweh’s purposes effectively is spoken of as if the servant were a sharp, new arrow. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has made me into a polished arrow; in his quiver he has hidden me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh protecting his servant and keeping his purpose secret is spoken of as if Yahweh kept him hidden in a quiver. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: in his quiver he has hidden me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has honored me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I am honored in the eyes of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The places on the earth that are very far away are spoken of as if they were the places where the earth ends. This phrase also forms a merism and refers to everywhere in between the ends. AT “to all the farthest places of the earth” or “to the entire earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: to the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the land as if it were an inheritance that the people of Israel received as a permanent possession. It is implied that the servant is to reassign the land to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “to reassign the desolate land to the people of Israel as their inheritance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: to reassign the desolate inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people living freely and prosperously as if they were sheep that had plenty of pasture in which to graze. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will graze along the roads, and on all the bare slopes will be their pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of guiding his people safely and removing obstacles from their path as if he turned mountains into roads and level highways. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make all my mountains into a road, and make my highways level

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his unwavering devotion to Zion as if he had written her name on the palms of his hands. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have inscribed your name on my palms

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of always thinking about Zion as if her walls were always before him. The word “walls” is a metonym for the city. Alternate translation: “I am continually thinking about your walls” or “I am always thinking about you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your walls are continually before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people who are returning to live in Jerusalem as if they were the city’s children. Alternate translation: “Your inhabitants are hurrying back” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Your children are hurrying back

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the inhabitants of Zion as if they were jewelry that the city wears to show her beauty and joy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will surely wear them like jewelry, and you will put them on like a bride

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy destroying Zion is spoken of as if they had devoured it. Alternate translation: “those who destroyed you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: those who devoured you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the time when the people of Jerusalem were in exile as if the city was bereaved of her children. Those who were born while the people were in exile are spoken of as the city’s children. Alternate translation: “Those who will inhabit you, who were born while the people were in exile” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The children born during the time of your bereavement

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zion speaks of the people who are returning to inhabit the city as if those people were her children. Zion’s question expresses her surprise that so many children now belong to her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has borne these children for me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zion describes herself as a woman incapable of having more children. She indicates the reasons for her great surprise. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I was bereaved and barren, exiled and divorced

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people who will inhabit Jerusalem as if they were the city’s children. He also speaks of the people of other nations helping the Israelites to return to Jerusalem as if they were carrying the Israelites. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will bring your sons in their arms and carry your daughters on their shoulders

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people who will inhabit Zion as if they were the city’s children. The terms “foster fathers” and “nursemaids” refer to men and women who become responsible for the care of children. Alternate translation: “The kings and queens of other nations will provide for your inhabitants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Kings will be your foster fathers, and their queens your nursemaids

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people who will inhabit Zion as if they were the city’s children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will & save your children

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the oppressors will be so hungry that they will eat the flesh of their friends who have died. Alternate translation: “I will cause your oppressors to eat their own flesh” or (2) Yahweh speaks of the oppressors fighting against and destroying themselves as if they were eating themselves. Alternate translation: “I will cause your oppressors to destroy themselves, as if they were eating their own flesh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will feed your oppressors with their own flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the oppressors will be so thirsty that they drink the blood of their friends who have died. Alternate translation: “they will drink their friends’ blood and be like weak people who are drunk on wine” or (2) Yahweh speaks of the oppressors fighting against and destroying themselves as if they were drinking their own blood. Alternate translation: “they will shed so much of their friends’ blood that it will be as though they were getting drunk with wine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will get drunk on their own blood, as if it were wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of Zion as if the city were the mother of the people who lived there and of sending the people into exile as if he were divorcing their mother. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is the certificate of divorce with which I divorced your mother?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of sending the people into exile as if he were selling them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: To which of my creditors did I sell you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh gives the reason for sending the people into exile, which he speaks of as if he had sold them and divorced their mother. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I sold you because of your sins, and I divorced your mother because of your rebellion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you were sold because of your sins, and because of your rebellion, your mother was sent away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of drying up the rivers as if he were turning them into a desert. Alternate translation: “I make the rivers as dry as a desert” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I make the rivers a desert

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Yahweh speaks of causing the sky to become dark as if he were clothing it with sackcloth. Alternate translation: “I make the sky dark, as if it were wearing dark sackcloth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I clothe the sky with darkness; I cover it with sackcloth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh enabling his servant to hear and understand is spoken of as if Yahweh opened his ear. Alternate translation: “The Lord Yahweh has enabled me to hear and understand him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord Yahweh has opened my ear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Allowing people to beat him and pluck out his beard is spoken of as if it were giving his back and cheeks to them. Alternate translation: “I allowed people to beat me on my back and to pluck out my beard from my cheeks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I gave my back to those who beat me, and my cheeks to those who plucked out my beard

contextId.occurrenceNote: There being no one left to accuse the servant of being guilty is spoken of as if the accusers were garments that wear thin and are eaten by moths. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will all wear out like a garment; the moth will eat them up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant speaks of people who are suffering and feel helpless as if they were walking in a very dark place. Alternate translation: “is suffering and feels helpless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: walks in deep darkness without light

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues the metaphor from the previous verse of people who walk in darkness. Here people who try to live according to their own wisdom instead of trusting in Yahweh are spoken of as if they lit their own fires and carried about torches in order to see in the dark. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: all you who light fires & flames that you have ignited

contextId.occurrenceNote: Looking at something represents thinking about it. Alternate translation: “think about the rock … and the quarry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: look at the rock & and to the quarry

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the nation of Israel as if it were a building made of stones and as if their ancestors were a rock or quarry from which God cut them. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “your ancestors, who are like a rock from which you were chiseled and a quarry from which you were cut” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the rock from which you were chiseled and to the quarry from which you were cut

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God’s justice represents his law, and a light represents knowledge of what is right. This means the people of the nations will understand and obey God’s law. Alternate translation: “my law will teach the nations what is right” or “the nations will know my law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make my justice to be a light for the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of “near” represents “soon.” God’s righteousness being near represents him soon showing his righteousness. He will do this by fulfilling his promises and saving people. Alternate translation: “I will soon show my righteousness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My righteousness is near

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of saving people as if his salvation were a thing that could go out to them. Alternate translation: “I will save people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my salvation will go out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lifting the eyes represents looking at something above. Alternate translation: “Look up at the sky” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Lift up your eyes to the sky

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having God’s law in the heart represents knowing God’s law and wanting to obey it. Alternate translation: “who know and honor my law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who have my law in your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of people who abuse those who are righteous as if they were wool garments, and of their being destroyed as if insects ate them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For the moth will eat them up like a garment, and the worm will eat them like wool

contextId.occurrenceNote: Strength is spoken of as if it were some kind of clothing that people would wear to strengthen themselves in battle. Alternate translation: “make yourself strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: clothe yourself with strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: “who spread out the sky.” This speaks of Yahweh having created the heavens as if he had stretched them out in the same way one would stretch out a large garment. Alternate translation: “who stretched out the heavens like a garment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who stretched out the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh causing the sea to move and the waves to rise and fall as if he were stirring the sea as one stirs the contents of a bowl with a large spoon. Alternate translation: “who causes the sea to churn” or “who makes the sea move up and down” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: who churns up the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh telling Isaiah what to say as if his words were a physical object Yahweh had placed in Isaiah’s mouth. Alternate translation: “I have told you what to say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have placed my words in your mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “plant” means to establish something in the ground. Here Yahweh firmly establishing the heavens is spoken of as if the heavens were a tent that he would spread out and firmly set it in place with tent pegs. Alternate translation: “that I may establish the heavens” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: that I may plant the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of having punished his people as if he had forced them to drink from a bowl that was filled with his anger. And when they drank from the bowl of his anger, they staggered as if they had drank a lot of wine. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you who have drunk out of the hand of Yahweh & from the cup of staggering

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “anger of Yahweh” refers to Yahweh punishing his people because of his anger against them. This speaks of the people having been severely punished as if they had become full of Yahweh’s anger. Also, the word “rebuke” can be written as a verb. Alternate translation: “they have been severely punished by Yahweh because he was angry with them and rebuked them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: they are filled with the anger of Yahweh, the rebuke of your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people acting drunk because they are suffering as if they have become drunk from being forced to drink the bowl of Yahweh’s anger. Alternate translation: “you who are drunk from drinking the wine of the bowl of Yahweh’s anger” or “you who act drunk, because you have suffered greatly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: drunken one, but not drunk with wine

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh no longer being angry with his people as if his anger were the contents of a cup that he was taking away from them. Alternate translation: “I will no longer be angry with you. See, it is like I have taken away from you the cup that made you stagger, that is, the cup that was full of my anger, so that” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: See, I have taken the cup of staggering from your hand—the bowl, which is the cup of my anger—so that

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh punishing their enemies as if he were going to force them to drink from the cup filled with his anger. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will put it into the hand of your tormentors

contextId.occurrenceNote: This word is repeated for emphasis and shows urgency. Isaiah trying to arouse the people is spoken of as if he were trying to wake them up from sleep. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Awake, awake

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being strong again is spoken of as if strength were clothing that a person puts on. Alternate translation: “be strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: put on your strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to unclean people. A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “those who are not acceptable to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about Yahweh as if he were the owner of the people of Israel. Since he is the rightful owner he can give them away or take them back whenever he wants. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I sold you for nothing, and I will redeem you without money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: You were sold for nothing, and you will be redeemed without money

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that Yahweh has stated is unfit to touch or eat is spoken of as if it were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “touch nothing that is unacceptable to Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: touch nothing unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh protecting his people from their enemies is spoken of as if he were the warriors who go ahead of the people and the warriors who stay behind the people to protect them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will go before you; and the God of Israel will be your rearguard

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant causing the people of the nations to be acceptable to Yahweh is spoken of as if the servant were a priest who sprinkles the blood of a sacrifice to make someone or something acceptable to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my servant will sprinkle many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: “parched earth” is hard and dry ground that will not allow plants to grow and represents where the servant of Yahweh will come. Alternate translation: “out of an impossible situation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: out of parched earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “bear” or carry an abstraction like sickness and sorrow represents taking it up. Alternate translation: “he has taken our sicknesses and sorrows upon himself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he has borne our sicknesses and carried our sorrows

contextId.occurrenceNote: Our “iniquity” here represents the guilt for our sin. Alternate translation: “the guilt for the sin of every one of us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the iniquity of us all

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, “offspring” means those people that Yahweh has forgiven because of the servant’s sacrifice. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will see his offspring

contextId.occurrenceNote: Many versions understand “light” here to stand for life. That is, the servant will become alive again. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will see light

contextId.occurrenceNote:
The word “bear” means carry. This could mean: (1) “their iniquities” is a metonym representing the punishment for their sins. Alternate translation: “he will take their punishment” or “he will be punished for their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
    * or (2) “their iniquities” is a metonym representing their guilt. Alternate translation: “he will take their guilt upon himself” or “he will be guilty for their sins”
contextId.quoteString: he will bear their iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh telling the people of Jerusalem to rejoice because there will be many people living in Jerusalem again is spoken of as if Yahweh were telling a barren women she is going to have many children. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you barren woman & children of the married woman

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh telling the people that in the future they will not even think about the shame they experienced when their enemies defeated them is spoken of as if Yahweh were telling a woman that she will no longer think about the shame she experienced from being unable to have children and having her husband abandon her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you will forget the shame of your youth and the disgrace of your abandonment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh loving and taking care of his people is spoken of as if he were their husband. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: For your Maker is your husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh sending his people away into exile then bringing them back is spoken of as if Yahweh were a husband who had rejected his wife but now accepts her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has called you back as a wife & like a woman married young and rejected

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh being very angry is spoken of as if his anger were a flood that overwhelms people. Alternate translation: “When I was very angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: In a flood of anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continuing to love his people is spoken of as if his love would not turn away from the people. Alternate translation: “I will not stop loving you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: my steadfast love will not turn away from you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh not canceling his covenant with the people is spoken of as if his covenant were an object that would not be shaken. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and I will not cancel my covenant of peace” or “and I will surely give you peace as I promised in my covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: nor will my covenant of peace be shaken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people as if they were blown around and damaged by the winds and storms. This means the people were hurt and without stability. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: storm-driven

contextId.occurrenceNote: The reward that Yahweh will give to those who serve him is spoken of as if the reward were something they would inherit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: This is the heritage of the servants of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Yahweh speaks of blessing the people freely as if he were selling food and drink to needy people for free. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people trusting Yahweh for blessing and happiness is spoken of as if they are eating good food that is making them happy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: eat what is good, and delight yourselves in fatness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Listening to or paying attention to someone is spoken of as if it were turning one’s ears to someone. Alternate translation: “Pay attention” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Turn your ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the things that he does and how he thinks as being far superior to or higher than what people do and think, just like the sky is much higher than the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something ceasing to exist is spoken of as if it were cut off, as a branch is cut off of a tree or a piece of fabric is cut off of clothing. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that will never end” or “that will last forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that will not be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means eunuchs may have thought they could not be a part of God’s people because they were deformed by castration (and for this reason could not have children). Israelites did not practice castration; foreigners did, sometimes for punishment. Eunuchs who had accepted the Hebrew faith knew that normally they were not allowed to worship in the temple (Deut. 23:1). The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: See, I am a dry tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is calling armies of other nations by comparing them to animals to come and attack the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: All you wild beasts of the field, come and devour, all you beasts in the forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: The leaders are supposed to open their mouths and warn the people, but they do not. Comparing someone to a dog in this society is a great insult. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They are all silent dogs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh continues comparing Israel’s bad leaders to dogs. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The dogs have big appetites

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a strong insult against the people who practice sorcery because sorcery and magic includes idolatry. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: sons of the sorceress

contextId.occurrenceNote: After trying so hard, the idolators found they still had strength to keep going. Here “hand” equals “strength” or “capacity.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You found life in your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God will bless and restore them quickly, as a wound heals quickly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your healing would quickly sprout up

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Your light” represents the acts of kindness that will be examples to everyone, and the “darkness,” the bad deeds, will be overcome by their good deeds. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: then your light will rise in the darkness, and your darkness will be like the noonday

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Water” represents all they need for an abundant life even when their surroundings do not have enough. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: satisfy you in regions where there is no water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to God exalting the nation in reputation and power in response to living righteously. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will make you ride on the heights of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Conceiving” and “giving birth” emphasize how carefully they plan to do sinful things. Here “they” still refers to the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “they work hard to do sinful things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they conceive trouble and give birth to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eggs of a poisonous snake hatch into more dangerous snakes. “Poisonous snakes” represents evil the people do that harms more and more. Alternate translation: “They make evil that spreads out to make more evil” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They hatch eggs of a poisonous snake

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the deeds of the people that are useless. Alternate translation: “produce things and activities that are useless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: weave a spider’s web

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eating a poisonous egg will kill the one that eats it and represents self-destruction. Breaking the egg allows the young poisonous snake to hatch and represents spreading destruction. Alternate translation: “The activities they do will destroy them and will spread destruction to others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Whoever eats of their eggs dies, and if an egg is crushed, it hatches into a poisonous snake

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means their sinful deeds cannot be covered and hidden, just as a web cannot serve as clothing and cover someone. Alternate translation: “Their evil deeds will be exposed as useless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Their webs cannot be used for garments, nor can they cover themselves with their works

contextId.occurrenceNote: “roads” represents their way of life. Alternate translation: “are all they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: are their roads

contextId.occurrenceNote: “paths” represents their way of life. Alternate translation: “they never do what is just” or “everything they do is unjust” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: there is no justice in their paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Crooked paths” represents the way of life that is corrupt. Alternate translation: “They say and do dishonest things. They are devious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They have made crooked paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: “With us” represents being aware of them. Alternate translation: “for we are aware of our transgressions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for our transgressions are with us

contextId.occurrenceNote: “breastplate,” “helmet,” “garments,” and “mantle” are clothing for war and fighting. Isaiah describes Yahweh as putting these on to punish his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He put on righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation upon his head & e clothed himself with garments of vengeance and wore zeal as a mantle

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the glorious things Yahweh has done for the inhabitants of Jerusalem. They are now to show that glory through what they do and say and have hope in the future. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Arise, shine; for your light has come, and the glory of Yahweh has risen on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the light of God’s presence will appear for the people of Israel, and it will show the way they should go. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: yet Yahweh will arise upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes that the abundance will be like water that gushes out. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: be poured out to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the wealth and plenty that will be drained from foreign nations. Both clauses repeat the same idea for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: You will also drink the milk of the nations, and will nurse at the breast of kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The moon will not literally disappear. This exaggeration is saying that the light of the sun and the moon will be much less bright than the light of Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: Your sun will no longer set, nor will your moon withdraw and disappear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is comparing the people to young shoots coming up that he planted as if he was a gardener. Yahweh has placed his people in the land of Israel. This gives hope to the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the branch of my planting

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to something made by the skill of his handicraft. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the work of my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Yahweh has caused the people to be strong and sturdy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: oaks of righteousness, the planting of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of God speaking as one person now have salvation and righteousness as their distinct appearance visible to all. “Garments” and “robe” are clothing that everyone can see. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: clothed me with the garments of salvation; he has clothed me with the robe of righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression describes these virtues as growing from seed like plants do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: righteousness and praise to sprout up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Yahweh will love the people of Israel and will always be with them as is a husband. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your land will be married

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “I” refers to Yahweh. This imagery refers to Yahweh destroying his enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have trodden grapes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Yahweh made them stunned and senseless by his full wrath and punishment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: made them drunk in my wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “blood” represents the life of Yahweh’s enemies that was gushing out so they would die. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I poured out their blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to when God protected and saved the people of Israel from the Egyptians many years earlier. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he lifted them up and carried them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Leaders are sometimes referred to as “shepherds.” Alternate translation: “the leaders of his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the shepherds of his flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: To not do what Yahweh commands is spoken of as if a person wanders off of the correct path. Alternate translation: “why do you make do what is wrong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: why do you make us wander from your ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to become resistant to Yahweh’s teaching by refusing to listen and obey. Here “heart” represents their motives, feelings and desires. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: harden our hearts

contextId.occurrenceNote: If Yahweh had shown himself very dramatically by tearing open the sky. The words “split open” refer to ripping a piece of cloth apart. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: if you had split open the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God created the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: we are the clay & ou are our potter; and we all are the work of your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares these people who are continually annoying him to smoke that irritates a person’s breathing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: These things are smoke in my nose

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to a slow-burning fire that sends out smoke without stopping as it irritates. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a fire that burns all day long

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the people of Israel to a cluster of grapes that still has some good juice in it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: As when juice is found in a cluster of grapes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression compares the feeling of terrible disappointment and sorrow to something becoming deformed due to high pressure. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: crushing of the spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares heaven to a throne and the earth to a footstool to emphasize how great he is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: “what I consider to be evil” or “what is evil in my judgement” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: what was evil in my sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks about Zion as if it were a woman who is about to give birth. Although Zion was destroyed and the people no longer lived there, Yahweh promises that without delay and with little effort an entire nation will come from her. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Before she goes into labor, she gives birth; before pain is upon her, she gave birth to a son

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Jerusalem will be a place of safety and comfort for God’s people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “For she will satisfy you with her milk; she will comfort you with her breasts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: For you will nurse and be satisfied; with her breasts you will be comforted

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means Jerusalem will be a place of safety and comfort for God’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You will nurse at her side, be carried in her arms, and be dandled on her knees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s appearances in the Old Testament are often accompanied by fire that represents Yahweh’s anger and judgment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: coming with fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Judah” refers to the southern kingdom of Israel. “Jerusalem” was its most important city. The names of the places represent the people who live in them. Alternate translation: “those living in Judah and Jerusalem” or “the people of Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people of Israel. Judah is part of what had been the nation of Israel. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “new moons” are a metonym for the celebrations of the new moon. They are also a synecdoche for all regular celebrations. Alternate translation: “your celebrations of the new moon and your other regular feasts” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your new moons and your appointed feasts

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the reason that God will not listen to their prayers. The blood likely refers to violence that they have done against people. Alternate translation: “because it is like your hands are covered with the blood of those you have harmed” or “because you are guilty of violence” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your hands are full of blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “sword” refers to Judah’s enemies. Also, the word “devour” compares Judah’s enemies coming to kill them to a wild animal that attacks and eats other animals. Alternate translation: “your enemies will kill you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the sword will devour you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exclamation shows Isaiah’s anger and sadness about the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “See how the people of Jerusalem, who had been faithful to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: How the faithful city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to God’s power which he would use to punish his people. Alternate translation: “I will begin to use all my power against you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will turn my hand against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” and “town” refer to the people living in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “the city where the people are righteous and loyal to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the city of righteousness, a faithful town

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people who live on Mount Zion. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Judah” and “Jerusalem” are metonyms for the people who live there. Alternate translation: “those living in Judah and Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Judah and Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” is a metonym for the people of those nations. Alternate translation: “people from all the nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: “no nation will lift up its sword against another nation.” The sword is a metonym for war. Alternate translation: “one nation will not fight wars against another nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: nation will not lift up sword against nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: “You descendants of Jacob.” The word “house” is a metonym for the people who live in the house, the family. Here “Jacob” represents the nation of Judah, but it would be best to use “Jacob” here. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: House of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The pride of men” here is a metonym for proud people, and being “brought down” is a metaphor for being humbled or ashamed. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will bring down proud men” or “Yahweh will make proud people ashamed of themselves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the pride of men will be brought down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The catastrophe is still coming, but the people have finished doing what will cause it to come. The catastrophe’s causes are spoken of here as if they were the catastrophe itself. Alternate translation: “For they have done everything that will cause a catastrophe to happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For they have completed a catastrophe for themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” stands for the deeds that the person has done. Alternate translation: “for what the wicked person has done to others will be done to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for the recompense of his hands will be done to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here what the Lord causes others to do is spoken of as the Lord doing it himself. Alternate translation: “the Lord will cause others to remove” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the Lord will remove

contextId.occurrenceNote: Falling represents being killed, and the sword represents battle. Alternate translation: “Your men will be killed in battle, and your strong men will be killed in war” or “Enemies will kill your soldiers in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Your men will fall by the sword, and your strong men will fall in war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the city gates represent the people who sit at the public places near the city gates. Alternate translation: “The people of Jerusalem will sit at the city gates and cry and mourn” (See:- [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem’s gates will lament and mourn

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Blood stains” here represents violence and murder. Alternate translation: “will have taken away those in Jerusalem who harm innocent people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will have cleansed the blood stains from Jerusalem’s midst

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. In this case it refers to the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “Israel” or “the kingdom of Israel” or “the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “eyes” refers to their thoughts. Alternate translation: “to those who consider themselves to be wise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to those who are wise in their own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to God’s power and control. Alternate translation: “has shown his power against them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: has reached out with his hand against them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents God’s power and control. Isaiah speaks as if Yahweh were a person about to hit another person with his fist. This is a metaphor for Yahweh punishing Israel. Alternate translation: “he will still be ready to punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: his hand is still stretched out

contextId.occurrenceNote: A young age is a metonym for strength. Alternate translation: “the strongest lions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: young lions

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lips” represent what a person speaks. And, people saying things that are unacceptable to God is spoken of as if their lips were physically unclean. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: of unclean lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s mind. A person who does not think clearly and is unable to understand and care about what is happening is spoken of as if his heart were insensitive. Alternate translation: “Make these people unable to understand” or “Make the minds of these people dull” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Make the heart of this people insensitive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents as person’s mind. Truly understanding something and caring about what is happening is spoken of as if the people were to understand with their hearts. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: understand with their heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks as if the city itself were the people who live in it. Alternate translation: “to war against the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to war against it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “house” is a metonym for the family living in the house. Alternate translation: “King Ahaz and his counselors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Aram” and “Ephraim” refer to their kings. Here “Ephraim” represents the whole northern kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “that Rezin, the king of Aram was helping Pekah, the king of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: that Aram was allied with Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “Aram” and “Ephraim” refer to the kings of these lands. Also, “Ephraim” represents the northern kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “Rezin the king of Aram and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Aram, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “head” is a metonym for the most important part. It is implied that Rezin is only a man, and therefore cannot stop Yahweh’s plan. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “the king of Damascus is Rezin, who is only a man” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the head of Damascus is Rezin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the head” represents the hair that grows on it. Alternate translation: “the hair on the head” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s “face” is a metonym for his blessing or favor. Alternate translation: “who has taken away his blessing from the house of Jacob” or “who no longer looks with favor on the house of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who hides his face from the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Land” refers to the people who live in an area. Alternate translation: “In the past, the Lord humbled those living in Zebulun and Naphtali” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: In an earlier time he humiliated the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “it” refers to Galilee which represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “but in the future, the Lord will honor the people of Galilee of the nations, which is on the road between the Mediterranean Sea and the Jordan River” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but in the later time he will make it glorious, the way to the sea, beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” represents the people from other nations that live in Galilee. Alternate translation: “Galilee, where many foreigners live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Galilee of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting on the “throne of David” is a metonym for having the right to rule; only David’s descendants could be king over Israel. Alternate translation: “has the right to rule as David’s descendant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: rules on the throne of David

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression means that the people will grab food wherever they can find it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will grab food on the right hand & on the left hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Hand” here is a reference to military strength. Alternate translation: “As my powerful army has defeated” or “As I have conquered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: As my hand has overcome

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Samaria” refers to the people who lived there, and “her” refers to the city of Samaria. Cities and nations were often spoken of as if they were women. Alternate translation: “just as I did to the people of Samaria and their worthless idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: just as I did to Samaria and her worthless idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “I” refers to the king of Assyria. He was the leader of the Assyrian army and took credit for what the army did at his command. Alternate translation: “my army has removed … They have stolen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have removed & I have stolen
