contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a metonym for either the king’s power or his army. Alternate translation: “In my power I have seized” or “My army has seized” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: My hand has seized

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ramah” and “Gibeah of Saul” refer to the people who lived in those cities. Alternate translation: “The people of Ramah tremble and the people of Gibeah of Saul have fled” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Ramah trembles and Gibeah of Saul has fled

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of more cities and villages near Jerusalem that the Assyrian army traveled through causing fear among the people. All of these refer to the people who live in these places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Gallim & Laishah & Anathoth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of more cities and villages near Jerusalem that the Assyrian army traveled through causing fear among the people. All of these refer to the people who live in these places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Madmenah & Gebim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of a village or city near Jerusalem that the Assyrian army traveled through causing fear among the people. It refers to the people who live in this place. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Nob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “Spirit” refers to an ability or quality that the Spirit of Yahweh would give him. Alternate translation: “and he will cause him to have wisdom and understanding, instruction and might, knowledge and the fear of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the Spirit of wisdom & the Spirit of instruction & the Spirit of knowledge & the fear of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “earth” here represents the people on earth. Striking them with the rod of his mouth represents judging them, and that judgement will lead to punishment. Alternate translation: “He will judge the people of the earth, and they will be punished” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He will strike the earth with the rod of his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “breath of his lips” represents him judging them. Alternate translation: “he will judge wicked people, and they will be killed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with the breath of his lips he will slay the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “knowledge of Yahweh” represents people who know Yahweh. Alternate translation: “the earth will be full of those who know Yahweh” or “those who know Yahweh will cover the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the earth will be full of knowledge of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand is a reference to God’s power. Alternate translation: “the Lord will again use his power to bring back the remnant of his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the Lord will again extend his hand to recover the remnant of his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his name” refers to Yahweh. Calling on him represents either praising him or asking him for help. Alternate translation: “praise him loudly” or “call to him to help you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: call upon his name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his name” refers to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “proclaim that he is exalted” or “proclaim that he is great” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: proclaim that his name is exalted

contextId.occurrenceNote: The name of the city stands for the people of Babylon. Alternate translation: “about the people of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: about Babylon

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “the gates of Babylon where the nobles live” or (2) “the gates of the nobles’ large houses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the gates of the nobles

contextId.occurrenceNote: Executing God’s anger represents punishing people because of God’s anger. Alternate translation: “I have called my mighty soldiers to punish the people of Babylon because they have made me angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have called my mighty men to execute my anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people. Alternate translation: “the people of the world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the world

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “their bows” is a metonym for the soldiers who use the bows. Alternate translation: “Their soldiers will use bows and arrows to kill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Their bows will strike down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” refers to the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will have mercy on the descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will have compassion on Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The house of Jacob refers to the descendants of Jacob, the Israelites. Alternate translation: “unite with the descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: attach themselves to the house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the Israelites, the descendants of Israel. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “proud fury” refers to the king of Babylon being proud and treating other nations cruelly. Alternate translation: “his cruelty has ended” or “he can no longer oppress people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the proud fury ended

contextId.occurrenceNote: The staff of the wicked probably refers to a stick that wicked people would hit other people with. Breaking that stick represents destroying their power to treat people cruelly. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has destroyed the power of the wicked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh has broken the staff of the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: A scepter represents a ruler’s power to rule. Breaking the scepter represents destroying the ruler’s power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has destroyed the power of the wicked rulers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the scepter of those rulers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to everyone on earth. Alternate translation: “everyone on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The whole earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the earth trembled as the king’s army marched to conquer people, or (2) this refers to the people of the earth trembling in fear of him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who made the earth tremble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes “the dead” spoken of at the beginning of this sentence. Being pierced by the sword represents being killed in battle. Alternate translation: “those who were killed in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: those pierced by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “rise up” represents either becoming powerful or attacking. Alternate translation: “so they will not become powerful” or “so they will not attack” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: so they will not rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “gate” and “city” represent the people at the city gates and in the cities. “Howl, you people at the city gates; cry, you people in the cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Howl, gate; cry, city

contextId.occurrenceNote: These place names refer to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the people of Moab will weep because of what happened to the cities of Nebo and Medeba” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab laments over Nebo and over Medeba

contextId.occurrenceNote: These city names represent the people of these cities. “The people of Heshbon and Elealeh call out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Heshbon and Elealeh call out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Physical trembling is a symptom of fear and represents fear. Alternate translation: “they will be completely filled with fear” or “they tremble with fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they tremble within themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “I” refers to Yahweh. Also, “Dimon” refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “but I will cause even more trouble for the people of Dimon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but I will bring even more upon Dimon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “throne” refers to the power to rule as king. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **faithfulness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “faithful.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will be faithful to the covenant and he will appoint a king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: A throne will be established in covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “David’s tent” represents David’s family, including his descendants. Sitting on the throne represents ruling. Alternate translation: “a descendant of David will rule faithfully” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: one from David’s tent will faithfully sit there

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “Moab’s” and “his” refer to the people of Moab. Alternate translation: “We have heard that the people of Moab are proud and arrogant, boastful and angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: We have heard of Moab’s pride, his arrogance, his boasting, and his anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Moab” represents the people of Moab. “So all the people of Moab will cry out loud over what has happened to their cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: So Moab wails for Moab—they all wail

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “shouts of joy” represent people shouting for joy about the harvest of their fruit trees. Alternate translation: “Because of what I will do, you will no longer shout for joy when you harvest your fields of summer fruit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For on your fields of summer fruits and harvest I have ended the shouts of joy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the shouts” refers to the joy of the people who tread the grapes to produce the wine. Alternate translation: “therefore the people who tread the grapes do not shout with joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I have put an end to the shouts of the one who treads

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refer to the people of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metonym for the people of the city. Alternate translation: “the people of Kir Hareseth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Kir Hareseth

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these words refer to the people of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab & himself & his

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Moab” refers to the people of Moab. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: concerning Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” refers to the kingdom of Israel. Israel would no longer be glorious. Rather it would be weak and poor. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the glory of Jacob will become thin, and the fatness of his flesh will become lean

contextId.occurrenceNote: Looking to the altars represents worshiping idols with the hope that the idols will help them. Alternate translation: “They will not worship idols at their altars” or “The people of Israel will not go to their altars and ask their idols to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: They will not look to the altars

contextId.occurrenceNote: The second phrase identifies the things that the people made. Speaking of the fingers here emphasizes that the people made them, so these things are not real gods. Alternate translation: “the Asherah poles or the sun images, which they themselves made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: what their fingers have made & the Asherah poles or the sun images

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nation” here refers to the people of that nation. Alternate translation: “a nation whose people are tall and have smooth skin” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a nation tall and smooth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. Alternate translation: “a nation that is strong and conquers other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a nation strong and trampling down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. Alternate translation: “a nation that is strong and conquers other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a nation strong and trampling down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “name” refers to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to Mount Zion, where Yahweh of hosts dwells” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the place of the name of Yahweh of hosts, to Mount Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “city” represents the people of the city. Alternate translation: “people of one city will fight against people of another city” or “people from different cities will fight against one another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: city will be against city

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “kingdom” refers to a smaller kingdom within Egypt. It may also be called a province. It represents the people of that kingdom or province. Alternate translation: “the people of one province will be against the people of another province” or “people from different provinces will fight against one another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: kingdom against kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power or control. Alternate translation: “I will give the Egyptians over to the control of a harsh master” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will give the Egyptians into the hand of a harsh master

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “Egypt” represents the people of Egypt. Going astray represents doing what is wrong. Alternate translation: “made the people of Egypt go astray” or “made the people of Egypt do what is wrong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: made Egypt go astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, “they” refers to the leaders described in the previous verses. The word “Egypt” represents the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “the princes have led the people of Egypt astray” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they have led Egypt astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to God’s power, and raising the hand against them represents punishing them. Alternate translation: “because Yahweh of hosts has raised his powerful hand to punish them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: because of the upraised hand of Yahweh of hosts that he raises over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “land of Judah” and “Egypt” refer to the people in those places. The Egyptians will stagger because they are afraid. Alternate translation: “The people of Judah will cause the Egyptians to stagger” or “The people of Judah will cause the Egyptians to be terribly afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The land of Judah will become a cause of staggering to Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people of those cities. Alternate translation: “the people in five Egyptian cities will speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there will be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Hebrew, the language of the people of God living in the land of Canaan. Here Canaan represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the language of the people of Canaan” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the language of Canaan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” refers to the people of Egypt. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will make the people of Egypt know him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will become known to Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, “Egypt” refers to the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will afflict the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will afflict Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The names of the three nations represent the people of those nations. Alternate translation: “the Israelites will be the third with the Egyptians and Assyrians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Israel will be the third with Egypt and Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: The names of the three nations refer to the people of those nations. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I have blessed you, people of Egypt, because you are my people; and I have blessed you, people of Assyria, because I created you; and I have blessed you, people of Israel, because I securely possess you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Blessed be Egypt, my people; Assyria, the work of my hands; and Israel, my inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” refers to God’s power and action. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the work of my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ashdod refers to the army of Ashdod. Alternate translation: “he fought against the army of Ashdod and defeated it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he fought against Ashdod and took it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king orders his army to do this task. Alternate translation: “the king of Assyria will have his army lead away the captives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the king of Assyria will lead away the captives

contextId.occurrenceNote: Egypt refers to the people of Egypt. Alternate translation: “which will bring shame on the people of Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the shame of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hope and glory refer to their trust in the military power of these countries. Alternate translation: “because they had trusted in the power of the armies of Cush and Egypt” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because of Cush their hope and of Egypt their glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live in Babylon as being a desert, even though God has not made it into a desert yet. This event will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “about the people who live in a land that soon will be a desert” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: about the desert by the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Elam” and “Media” represent the soldiers from these places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Elam & Media

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “her” represents all the people who are suffering because of the Babylonians. Yahweh will cause them to stop groaning when he sends the armies of Elam and Media to destroy the Babylonians. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will stop all her groaning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “table” represents the food that people will eat at the feast. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: prepare the table

contextId.occurrenceNote: Arabia refers to the population of Arabia. Alternate translation: “about the people of Arabia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: about Arabia

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” and “bow” represents the soldiers who attack the inhabitants of Tema. Alternate translation: “from their enemies who attack them with swords and bows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from the sword, from the drawn sword, from the bent bow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Valley” refers to those who live in the valley, that is, Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “about those who live in the Valley of Vision” or “about those who live in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: about the Valley of Vision

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sword” represents the soldiers who fight in battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “daughter” represents the people and may imply Isaiah’s feeling of love for them. Alternate translation: “of my people whom I love” or “of my people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: of the daughter of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The quiver is a bag to carry arrows and represents the archer’s weapons. Alternate translation: “The soldiers of Elam take their bows and arrows” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Elam takes up the quiver

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Kir” represents the soldiers. Alternate translation: “the soldiers of Kir will take their shields out of their covers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Kir lays the shield bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eat and drink” represents having a party and over indulging in food and wine. Alternate translation: “we may as well have fun now by eating and drinking all we want, for we will die soon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents those in the king’s palace. Alternate translation: “who is in charge of all those who work in the palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who is over the house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents the people who work in the king’s palace. Alternate translation: “you will cause shame for all those in your master’s palace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you will be the shame of your master’s house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the tunic and sash represent authority in the king’s palace. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your tunic & your sash

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power or control. Alternate translation: “to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: into his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents the people. Alternate translation: “to the people of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “key” represents authority. This speaks of Eliakim having authority that no one can oppose as if he had the key to the palace and no one else could lock or unlock the door. Alternate translation: “I will put him in charge of those who work in the king’s palace, and when he makes a decision no one will be able to oppose him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I will place the key of the house of David on his shoulder & none will open

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “seat of glory” represents a place of honor. Alternate translation: “Eliakim will bring honor to his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he will become a seat of glory for his father’s house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” represents family. Alternate translation: “his father’s family” or “his family” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his father’s house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “weight” represents Shebna’s power and authority. It is spoken of as if it were an object hanging on the peg that represents Shebna. Yahweh causing Shebna to lose his power and authority is spoken of as if someone were to cut off the object that was hanging on the peg. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the weight that was on it will be cut off

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ships” represents the men on the ships. Isaiah speaks to the men on the ships of Tarshish as if they could hear him. Alternate translation: “Cry out in despair you men on the ships of Tarshish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Howl, you ships of Tarshish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling goods. Here “nations” represents the people. Alternate translation: “you were where people from other nations came to buy and sell goods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: it became the commerce of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the joyful people who live in the city of Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the joyful city

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “her” refers to the city of Tyre which represents the people of Tyre. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: her far away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “crown” refers to the power a person has as a ruler over people. Alternate translation: “who gives people power to rule over others” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the giver of crowns

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “her” refers to the city of Tyre which represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “their pride … their glory … their honored one” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: her pride & her glory & her honored ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “daughter” of a city represents the people of the city. Alternate translation: “the people of Tarshish” or “the people who live in Tarshish” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: daughter of Tarshish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to God’s power and control. Alternate translation: “has shown his power over the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: has reached out with his hand over the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “virgin daughter” represents the people of Sidon. Alternate translation: “people of Sidon, because other people will oppress you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: oppressed virgin daughter of Sidon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Tyre” represents the people who live in Tyre. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will help the people of Tyre” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will help Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: everything that is on the earth (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these represent everything that is on the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The earth & the world

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” represents the people of the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: gladness of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “in the east” represents the people living east of Israel. Isaiah is commanding these people as if they were there with him. But, he is talking to the people in the future after God devastates the earth. Alternate translation: “Therefore everyone from distant lands in the east will glorify Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore in the east glorify Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah is commanding the people who live on the islands in the Mediterranean sea as if they were there with him. But, he is talking to the people in the future after God devastates the earth. Alternate translation: “everyone in the islands will give glory” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pastforfuture]])
contextId.quoteString: in the isles of the sea give glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “to Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “praise you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: praise your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “city” and “nations” represent the people who live there. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: a city of ruthless nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “hand” represents God’s power. For Yahweh’s hand to rest on “this mountain” means he will protect his people Alternate translation: “The power of Yahweh will be on this mountain” or “For on Mount Zion Yahweh will protect his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: For on this mountain the hand of Yahweh will rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Moab represents the people of Moab. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will trample the people in the land of Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Moab will be trampled down in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” represents the power to do or make something. Alternate translation: “in spite of the great things they have built” or “in spite of the great things they have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in spite of the skill of their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh causing armies to bring down the walls as if he himself were going to bring them down. Alternate translation: “He will send an army to bring your high fortress walls to the ground, to the dust” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Your high fortress walls he will bring down to the ground, to the dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nation” represents the people. Alternate translation: “the righteous and faithful people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the righteous nation that keeps faith

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” represents a person’s thoughts. Also “you” refers to Yahweh. The phrase “stayed on you” is an idiom. Alternate translation: “The person who continually thinks about you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The mind that is stayed on you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh causing an army to destroy fortified cities is spoken of as if Yahweh would do it himself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he will lay low & he will level

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” and “reputation” represent Yahweh’s character which represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “our only desire is to honor you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your name and your reputation are our desire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “land” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “In the land where the people do what is right” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: In the land of uprightness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “see” represents realizing something. Alternate translation: “does not realize that Yahweh is great” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: does not see the majesty of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “see” represents realizing something. Alternate translation: “they will realize that you are eager to bless your people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will see your zeal for the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents the person of God. Alternate translation: “but we praise you alone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but we praise your name alone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “earth” represents the people who live on the earth. The meaning is unclear, but it seems to mean that the people of Israel have not been able to save themselves or other people by defeating their enemy in battle. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: We have not brought salvation to the earth, and the inhabitants of the world have not fallen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” and “Israel” are metonyms that represent the descendants of Jacob. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob & Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: These represent the descendants of Jacob. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob & Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “sending the Israelites away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sending Jacob and Israel away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “iniquity of the Israelites … removal of their sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: iniquity of Jacob & removal of his sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “he” refers to Jacob who represents his descendants. Alternate translation: “They will completely destroy all the altars on which they sacrifice to false gods, and they will remove all the Asherah idols and the altars on which they burn incense to false gods” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he will make all the altar stones as chalk and crushed to pieces, and no Asherah poles or incense altars will remain standing

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents what Isaiah says. Alternate translation: “to what I say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Ariel” represents the people who live in the city of Ariel. Alternate translation: “How terrible it will be for the people of Ariel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Woe to Ariel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “I” refers to Yahweh. This represents Yahweh causing an enemy army to besiege Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But I will besiege

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “she” refers to Ariel, which represents the people of Ariel. Alternate translation: “the people of Ariel will” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: she will

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “I” refers to Yahweh. This represents Yahweh causing an enemy army to surround Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “I will command the army of your enemies to surround you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will encamp against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “her” refers to Ariel which represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “their stronghold. They will attack the city of Ariel and its defenses and cause the people to be in great distress” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: her stronghold & hey will attack her and her fortifications to press upon her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Mount Zion” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “Yes, this will be what happens to the armies from the nations who fight against the people who live on Mount Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yes, so will be the great number of nations that fights against Mount Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “mouths” and “lips” represent what people say. Here it also represents saying something but not truly meaning it. Alternate translation: “The people of Jerusalem pretend to worship me and honor me with what they say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: This people comes close to me with their mouths and honors me with their lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” is a metonym that represents a person’s thoughts and emotions. The people not being truly devoted to Yahweh is spoken of as if their hearts were far away from him. Alternate translation: “but they do not honor me in their thoughts” or “but they are not truly devoted to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but their heart is far from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Lebanon” represents the large cedar forests in Lebanon. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will turn the mighty forests of Lebanon into a field” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Lebanon will be turned into a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jacob” represents his descendants. Alternate translation: “Jacob’s descendants will no longer … their faces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob will no longer & his face

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “he” and “his” speak of Jacob (verse 22) and represent his descendants. Alternate translation: “Jacob’s descendants will no longer … their faces … they see their children” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he sees his children

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” represents Yahweh’s power and action. Alternate translation: “When they see all the children I have given them and all that I have done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But when he sees his children, the work of my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “they will honor me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will make my name holy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. Yahweh refers to himself as “the Holy One of Jacob.” Alternate translation: “They will honor me, the Holy One of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: They will make holy the name of the Holy One of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “spirit” represents a person’s inner being. Alternate translation: “Those who are wrong in what they think” or “Those who are wrong in their attitude” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Those who err in spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the leaders of Judah are trusting in the Egyptian leaders who rule by oppressing and deceiving others or (2) the leaders of Judah have oppressed and deceived their own people in order to take their money and send it to the Egyptians leaders as payment for protection. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: trust in oppression and deceit and lean on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fire” here refers here to ashes. Alternate translation: “ashes from the fireplace” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: fire from the hearth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bread” and “water” make up the diet of a very poor person. The whole phrase represents the hard times and poverty of the people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the bread of adversity and the water of affliction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Yahweh comes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the name of Yahweh comes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s inner being. Alternate translation: “you will be glad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: gladness of heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” represents the power of God. It is implied that Yahweh will show his power by destroying his people’s enemies. Alternate translation: “show that he is powerful by destroying your enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: show the motion of his arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this represents the soldiers of Assyria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to evil people who live there. Alternate translation: “all who do evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: evil house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Egypt refers to the soldiers of Egypt. Alternate translation: “The soldiers of Egypt are men” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Egypt is a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: The term “hand” is often used in reference to God’s power and action. Alternate translation: “When Yahweh uses his power against them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: When Yahweh reaches out with his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Sword” refers to military might. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God’s sword, and not a man’s sword, will destroy the Assyrian army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Assyria will fall by the sword; a sword not wielded by man will consume him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah refers to himself by his voice to emphasize what he says. Alternate translation: “me speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the fort built on the top of the hill. Alternate translation: “the fort on the hill” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hill

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here heaven is referred to as “on high.” Alternate translation: “from heaven” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from on high

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh’s arm refers to his strength. This speaks of Yahweh strengthening them as if Yahweh would use his strength to act for them. Alternate translation: “give us strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: be our arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Lebanon” represents Lebanon’s trees. This speaks of the trees withering and decaying as if they were a person who is ashamed. Alternate translation: “Lebanon’s trees wither and decay” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Lebanon is ashamed and withers away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Assyrians’ plans are referred to as their “breath.” This speaks of their plans causing them to die as if their plans would literally burn up their bodies. Alternate translation: “your plans will cause you to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your breath is a fire that will consume you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a high hill or mountainside. Alternate translation: “the high hill” or “the mountainside” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the heights

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king’s royal robes are referred to as “his beauty.” Alternate translation: “the king in his beautiful robes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the king in his beauty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Edom refers to the people who live there. Alternate translation: “on the people of Edom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: on Edom

contextId.occurrenceNote: “you have the council and the strength to go to war.” The phrase “strength for war” refers to having a large enough and strong enough army with weapons. Alternate translation: “you have enough military council, strong men, and weapons to go to war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: there is counsel and strength for war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Egypt” refers to the Egyptian army. Alternate translation: “trusting in the Egyptian army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: trusting in Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Yahweh” refers to Yahweh’s orders. Alternate translation: “without Yahweh’s command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: without Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to fight against the people and cause destruction in the place where they live. The land referred to here is Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “against this people and destroy their land … Attack these people and destroy their land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: against this land and destroy it & Attack this land and destroy it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king’s “hand” refers to his “control.” Alternate translation: “the control of the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king of Assyria is referring to his army as himself. Alternate translation: “until my army comes and takes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: until I come and take

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king’s control is referred to as his “hand.” Alternate translation: “the control of the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live in the land. Alternate translation: “his people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his land

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who are left in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “for the few of us that are still here” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for the remnant that is still here

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” represents Sennacherib. Here Sennacherib represents his army. Alternate translation: “to fight against the army of Sennacherib” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to fight against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. The word “hand” refers to the king’s military power. Alternate translation: “The king of Assyria and his army will not conquer you in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people in the kingdoms. Alternate translation: “all the people in the kingdoms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the kingdoms

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that he sent a messenger to give a message to the king. Alternate translation: “sent someone to give a message” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: sent a message

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king’s “arrogance” refers to his arrogant speech. Alternate translation: “your arrogant speech” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: your arrogance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Judah’s “house” refers to his descendants. Alternate translation: “the descendants of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the house of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh doing something because of his zeal as if his “zeal” were actually doing the action. Alternate translation: “Because of his zeal, Yahweh of hosts will do this” or “Yahweh of hosts will do this because of his zeal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The zeal of Yahweh of hosts will do this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “heart” refers to the inner-being which represents a person’s complete devotion. Alternate translation: “with all my inner being” or “with my complete devotion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with my whole heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the king’s “hand” refers to his power. Alternate translation: “the power of the king of Assyria” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the king of Assyria

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Sheol” and “death” refer to “dead people.” Alternate translation: “For those in Sheol do not thank you; dead people do not praise you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For Sheol does not thank you; death does not praise you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live in Zion. Alternate translation: “you people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “arm” represents God’s power. Alternate translation: “he rules with great power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his strong arm rules for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live on the islands and in the lands bordering or beyond the Mediterranean Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: you coastlands

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases represent the people who live in those places. Alternate translation: “People who live on the isles … people who live at the ends of the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The isles & the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “right hand” represents Yahweh’s power. This could mean: (1) Yahweh’s right hand is righteous in that he will always do the right thing. Alternate translation: “my righteous power” or (2) Yahweh’s right hand is victorious in that he will always succeed in what he does. Alternate translation: “my victorious power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my righteous right hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “covenant” is a metonym for the one who establishes or mediates a covenant. Alternate translation: “I will … make you be the mediator of a covenant with the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I will & set you as a covenant for the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live in the desert and the cities. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Let the desert and the cities cry out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to be called by someone’s name represents belonging to that person. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “everyone whom I have called by my name” or “everyone who belongs to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: everyone who is called by my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. Alternate translation: “no one can rescue anyone from my power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: no one can rescue anyone from my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to “hand over” represents putting someone under the power of another. The noun “destruction” can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: “I will cause the enemy to completely destroy Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: I will hand Jacob over to complete destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Jacob’s descendants. Alternate translation: “descendants of Jacob, my servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob my servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: The heart represents the inner person. Alternate translation: “he misleads himself because he is deceived” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his deceived heart misleads him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people descended from Jacob, Israel. Alternate translation: “you descendants of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Jacob, and Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this phrase represents the people who live at “the ends of the earth.” Alternate translation: “you who live at the farthest places of the earth” or “all of you who live on the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the ends of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “throne” refers to the power to rule. Alternate translation: “without the power to rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: without a throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Babylon’s power or control. Alternate translation: “I put them under your power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: gave them over into your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “heart” refers to the inner person. Alternate translation: “you say to yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you say in your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents strength. Alternate translation: “the power of the flame” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of the flame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “house” refers to the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “descendants of Jacob” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: house of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” refers to Yahweh’s reputation. Alternate translation: “For the sake of my reputation I will delay my anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: For the sake of my name I will defer my anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel being destroyed is spoken of as if their name had been cut off, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree, or blotted out. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: “I would not have cut off nor blotted out their name” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: their name would not have been cut off nor blotted out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” refers to the descendants who would carry on the name of Israel. Alternate translation: “they” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: their name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the descendants of Jacob. Alternate translation: “the people of Israel, his servants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his servant Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live on the coastlands. Alternate translation: “you who live on the coastlands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: you coastlands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “mouth” represents the words that he speaks. His words are compared to a sharp sword to emphasize that they will be effective. Alternate translation: “He has made my words as effective as a sharp sword” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: He has made my mouth like a sharp sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “land” represents the cities in the land that had been destroyed. Alternate translation: “to rebuild the ruined places in the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to rebuild the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh’s power. Yahweh not being strong enough is spoken of as if his hand were short. Alternate translation: “Was I not strong enough” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Was my hand too short

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “tongue” represents what he says. This could mean: (1) Yahweh has enabled him to speak as one who has learned to speak skillfully. Alternate translation: “The Lord Yahweh has enabled me to be a skillful speaker” or (2) Yahweh has taught him what to say. Alternate translation: “The Lord Yahweh has enabled me to speak what he has taught me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The Lord Yahweh has given me a tongue as one of those who are taught

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “voice” represents what the servant says. Alternate translation: “obeys his servant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: obeys the voice of his servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of their ancestor as if he were their father. Alternate translation: “Abraham, your forefather” or “Abraham, your ancestor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Abraham, your father

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Abraham’s wife as if she were their mother and had given birth to them. Alternate translation: “Abraham’s wife, Sarah, of whom you are all descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Sarah, who bore you

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Abraham’s descendants being many as if Abraham were many. Alternate translation: “made his descendants many” or “made him have many descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: made him many

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Zion, which is also called Jerusalem, here represents the people of Zion. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will comfort the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will comfort Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “waste places” represents the people who live in those desolate areas. Alternate translation: “he will comfort the people who live in all her waste places” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he will comfort all her waste places

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God’s arm represents his power, and judging represents ruling. Alternate translation: “I will rule the nations with my power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my arm will judge the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live on the coasts of distant lands across the sea. Alternate translation: “the people who live on the coastlands” or “the people who live in the lands across the sea” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the coastlands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God’s arm represents what he will do. Here it refers to him saving people. Alternate translation: “they will eagerly wait for me to do something” or “they will eagerly wait for me to save them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for my arm they will eagerly wait

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s “salvation” here represents the result of his salvation, which is freedom. Alternate translation: “I will save you, you will be free forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my salvation will continue forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s “righteousness” here represents him ruling righteously. Alternate translation: “my righteous rule will never end” or “I will rule righteously forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my righteousness will never stop working

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s “righteousness” here represents him ruling righteously. Alternate translation: “my righteous rule will be forever” or “I will rule righteously forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: my righteousness will be forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: God’s “salvation” here represents the result of his salvation, which is freedom. Being “to all generations” represents lasting forever. Alternate translation: “I will save you, and you will be free forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: and my salvation to all generations

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people of Israel who are slaves of the Babylonians. This phrase describes how they work. Alternate translation: “The slave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The one who is bent down

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Sheol. Alternate translation: “the pit of Sheol” or “the grave” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the pit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s “hand” refers to his power. This speaks of Yahweh protecting Isaiah as if his hand were covering him to protect him. Alternate translation: “my power has kept you safe” or “I have protected you and kept you safe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: I have covered you in the shadow of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people who live there. Yahweh speaks to the people of Jerusalem as if they were there listening to him. Alternate translation: “Awake, awake, stand up, you people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Awake, awake, stand up, Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “famine” and “sword” describe the trouble that will come upon the people. The “sword” refers to “war.” Alternate translation: “many of you have died from hunger and war” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the famine and the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these refer to the people who live in Jerusalem. Isaiah is speaking to the people as if they were there listening to him. Alternate translation: “people of Zion … people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-apostrophe]])
contextId.quoteString: Zion & Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to Jerusalem which represents the people who live there. It is understood that the uncircumcised and unclean people would enter the city to attack the people. Alternate translation: “enter your city to attack you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: enter you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people who live there. Alternate translation: “People of Jerusalem, sit up and shake the dirt off of yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Shake yourself off from the dust; arise and sit, Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that the people of Jerusalem were wearing chains because they were slaves while exiled in Babylon. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: take off the chain from your neck, captive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Assyria refers to the people of Assyria. Alternate translation: “the people of Assyria have treated them badly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Assyria has oppressed them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “those who watch the enemy take away my people are continually saying evil things about me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: my name is blasphemed continually all day long

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents Yahweh’s reputation. Alternate translation: “Therefore my people will truly know who I am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore my people will know my name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Zion” represents the people of Zion. Alternate translation: “to the people of Zion” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Jerusalem” represents the people. Alternate translation: “he has redeemed the people of Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he has redeemed Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” represents Yahweh’s power. Yahweh showing all the people of the nations that he is holy and powerful is spoken of as if Yahweh were a warrior who removed his cloak, baring his arms for battle. Alternate translation: “showed his holiness and mighty power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: bared his holy arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” and “earth” represent the people of all the nations all over the earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: all the nations; all the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” represents the people of the nations. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: many nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Arm refers to God’s power. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has revealed his power to people.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: to whom has the arm of Yahweh been revealed?

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Face” represents a person’s attention or fellowship. Hiding one’s face means to turn away from someone. Alternate translation: “from whom people turn away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: from whom men hide their faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Mouth” represents what a person says. Opening one’s mouth means to speak. Alternate translation: “he did not protest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he did not open his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Mouth” represents what a person says. Alternate translation: “nor did he deceive anyone when he spoke” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: nor had there been any deceit in his mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his life” refers to the servant. Alternate translation: “After the servant has suffered” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: After the suffering of his life

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Exposed” means to be vulnerable or unprotected. The servant of Yahweh put himself in a situation where he would die. Alternate translation: “he willingly accepted the possibility of death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: because he exposed himself to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” represents the people. Alternate translation: “will conquer the people of other nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will conquer nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “spirit” represents a person’s inner being. Alternate translation: “grieved” or “made sad” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: grieved in spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Enemies not succeeding against Yahweh’s people is spoken of as if their weapons would not succeed against Yahweh’s people. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Enemies may form weapons to attack you but they will not defeat you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: No weapon that is formed against you will succeed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “name” represents Yahweh’s fame. Alternate translation: “for his fame” or “for his honor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: for his name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s “name” represents himself. Alternate translation: “who love Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who love the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here these refer to a person’s thoughts and emotions, not the spirit and heart literally. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: spirit & heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the Israelites kept rejecting the true God for false ones. Here “backward” and “way” are location words representing motivations and feelings. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he went backward in the way of his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fruit of the lips” refers to what a person says. Alternate translation: “I cause them to praise and thank me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I create the fruit of the lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: “wicked fist.” This shows that they fight viciously. “Fist” represents anger that is physically violent. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: fist of wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these phrases mean they should help those people whom the wicked are hurting and oppressing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: To release wicked bonds, to undo the ropes of the yoke, to set the crushed ones free, and to break every yoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Hand” represents power and ability. A “short” hand does not have power and ability. Alternate translation: “Yahweh is fully able” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh’s hand is not so short

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” and “fingers” refers to their actions. This means they are guilty of doing violent and sinful things. “Your” is plural. Alternate translation: “For you have committed violent sins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: For your hands are stained with blood and your fingers with sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The parts of the body that make speech represent what people say. Alternate translation: “You speak lies and malicious things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Your lips speak lies and your tongue speaks maliciously

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Hands” represents the ability and power to do these things and therefore their responsibility. Alternate translation: “they are fully responsible for the violence they do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: deeds of violence are in their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s “arm” represents his ability and power. Alternate translation: “Yahweh used his own power to save the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore his own arm brought salvation for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” refers to Yahweh’s reputation and character. Alternate translation: “fear Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: fear the name of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the people who live on the coastlands and describes the area of coastlands as if it was people looking out. Alternate translation: “The people from the coastlands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: The coastlands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Yahweh’s temple. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the place of my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The physical objects have the names of spiritual qualities. The city of Jerusalem will be a safe place, and the people there will praise Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but you will call your walls Salvation, and your gates Praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases refer to the same span of time. “Year” and “day” are both specific examples that represent the greater whole. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: the year of Yahweh’s favor, the day of vengeance

contextId.occurrenceNote: People put oil on themselves and dressed in beautiful, long robes during times of celebration and joy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: oil of joy & a mantle of praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: The right hand and arm represent power and authority. Alternate translation: “by his power and authority” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: by his right hand and by the arm of his strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: A signal flag represents something to draw the attention of others. This means Yahweh is calling the people of the other nations to take notice of the land of Israel and to see what Yahweh has accomplished as he said he would. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Raise up a signal flag for the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “year” refers to a specific time appointed by Yahweh for restoring Israel. Alternate translation: “the time for my redemption” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the year for my redemption

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” represents power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: but my own arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “right hand” represents the power of Yahweh through Moses. This means it was God’s power that enabled Moses to divide the water of the Reed Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who made his glorious power go with the right hand of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name of praise” refers to honor and one’s reputation. Alternate translation: “to make sure you have an honored reputation for yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to make yourself a name of praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” is a metonym for the power of those who are punishing the people for their iniquities. Alternate translation: “as you punish us for our iniquities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: in the hand of our iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sound represents the real fighting that is going on in the temple as Yahweh is carrying out the punishment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: A sound of battle tumult

contextId.occurrenceNote: The worms represent the horror of decay and rot that are Yahweh’s punishment on the wicked. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the worms that eat them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Fire also represents Yahweh’s judgment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the fire that consumes
