contextId.occurrenceNote: This question is used to scold the people of Jerusalem. Alternate translation: “Obviously, the potter should not be considered like clay … ‘He does not understand.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Should the potter be considered like clay & “He does not understand”?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These rhetorial questions have basically the same meaning and emphasize that no one can live with fire. Here fire represents Yahweh’s judgment. Alternate translation: “No one can live with raging fire! No one can live with everylasting burns!” or “No one can live bearing Yahweh’s judgment, it is like an everlasting fire!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Who among us can sojourn with a raging fire? Who among us can sojourn with everlasting burnings?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These rhetorical question are asked to emphasize that the Assyrian officials are gone. These questions may be written as statements. Alternate translation: “The officers of Assyria who counted the tax money that we were forced to pay to them have disappeared! Those men who counted our towers are gone!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: where is the scribe, where is he who weighed the money? Where is he who counted the towers?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria uses this question to challenge Hezekiah and to say that he does not have a good source for confidence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “You have no reliable source for your confidence.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What is the source of your confidence?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria uses questions to ridicule Hezekiah for believing he has the strength to rebel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “No matter in whom you trust, you will not have the courage to rebel against me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Now in whom are you trusting? Who has given you courage to rebel against me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule the people and to imply that Yahweh was angry about what Hezekiah did and would not protect them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “he is the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has taken away … Jerusalem.” or “he is the one whom Hezekiah insulted by tearing down his high places and altars … Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: is not he the one whose high places and altars Hezekiah has taken away & Jerusalem”?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander continues to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. When he says “you,” referring to Hezekiah, he is actually referring to Hezekiah’s army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Your army could not even defeat one captain … servants.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: How could you resist even one captain & servants?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander uses another question to ridicule Hezekiah and the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I came here with Yahweh’s command to destroy Jerusalem.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Now then, have I traveled up here without Yahweh to fight against this land and destroy it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander uses this question to emphasize that his message is for all the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Certainly, my master has sent me to speak this message to you and to all who can hear.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Has my master sent me to your master and to you to speak these words?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander uses this question to emphasize his insult. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “My master has sent me to everyone who hears this, who will have to … you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Has he not sent me to the men who sit on the wall, who will have to & you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander uses this question to ridicule the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “None of the gods of the peoples rescued them from … Assyria.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Has any of the gods of the peoples rescued them from & Assyria?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander uses these questions to ridicule the people of Judah. These questions may be combined and written as a statement. Alternate translation: “The gods of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, and Samaria did not rescue their people from my power.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they rescued Samaria from my power?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The chief commander uses this question to ridicule the people of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “there is no god who has rescued … and Yahweh will not save you in Jerusalem from my power.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: is there any god who has rescued & as if Yahweh could save Jerusalem from my power?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. Alternate translation: “So you too will not be saved.” or “So of course no one will rescue you either!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: So will you be rescued?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. Alternate translation: “The nations’ god did not rescue the nations that my fathers destroyed … Tel Assar!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have the gods of the nations rescued them & Tel Assar?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria uses this question to ridicule Hezekiah and his army. Alternate translation: “We also conquered the king … Ivvah!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is the king & Ivvah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses these rhetorical questions to ridicule the king of Assyria. These can be written as statements. Alternate translation: “You have defied and insulted Yahweh, you have shouted at and acted pridefully against the Holy One of Israel!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Whom have you defied and insulted? & Against the Holy One of Israel.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to remind Sennacherib of information that he should already be aware of. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Certainly you have heard how … times.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Have you not heard how & times?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah uses a question to emphasize he has nothing left to say. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I have nothing left to say.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What shall I say?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These rhetorical questions anticipate a negative answer and emphasize that only Yahweh is able to do these things. Alternate translation: “No one but Yahweh has measured … and the hills in a balance.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has measured & or the hills in a balance?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question anticipates a negative answer and emphasizes that no one is able to do these things. Alternate translation: “No one has comprehended the mind of Yahweh, and no one has instructed him as his counselor.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has comprehended the mind of Yahweh, or instructed him as his counselor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question anticipates a negative answer and emphasizes that no one has ever done this. Alternate translation: “He has never received instruction from anyone.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: From whom did he ever receive instruction?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question anticipates a negative answer and emphasizes that no one has ever done these things. Alternate translation: “No one taught him the correct way to do things. No one taught him knowledge. No one showed to him the way of understanding.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who taught him the correct way to do things, and taught him knowledge, or showed to him the way of understanding?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah uses two similar questions to emphasize that there is no idol that can compare with God. Alternate translation: “There is no one to whom you can compare God. There is no idol to which you can liken him.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: To whom then will you compare God? To what idol will you liken him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah uses these questions to emphasize that the people should know Yahweh’s greatness as the creator. Alternate translation: “You certainly know and have heard! It has been told to you from the beginning; you have understood from the foundations of the earth!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Have you not known? Have you not heard? Has it not been told you from the beginning? Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses two similar rhetorical questions to emphasize that there is no one like him. Alternate translation: “There is no one to whom you can compare me. There is no one whom I resemble.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: To whom then will you compare me, whom do I resemble?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a leading question that anticipates the answer, Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has created all these stars!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has created all these stars?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The question emphasizes that they should not say what they say. Alternate translation: “‘You should not say, O people of Israel … vindication’.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you say, Jacob, and declare, Israel & vindication”?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who caused this ruler from the east to be victorious. Alternate translation: “I am the one who called this powerful ruler from the east and put him in my good service.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has stirred up one from the east, calling him in righteousness to his service?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who has done these things. Alternate translation: “I have performed and accomplished these deeds.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has performed and accomplished these deeds?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “generations” represents all of human history, which Yahweh created and directed throughout history. The rhetorical question anticipates the answer, Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I have summoned the generations of humanity from the beginning.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has summoned the generations from the beginning?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses these rhetorical questions to mock the idols that the people worship. The implied answers are: (1) that the idols have not done these things and (2) that Yahweh is the one who has done these things. Alternate translation: “None of the idols announced this from the beginning, that we might know. And none of them announced this before time, that we may say, ‘He is right.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and[[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: Who announced this from the beginning, that we might know? Before this time, that we may say, “He is right”?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks these rhetorical questions to scold his people and to emphasize that no one is as blind or deaf as they are. Alternate translation: “No one is as blind as my servant. No one is as deaf as my messenger whom I send.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is blind but my servant? Or deaf like my messenger I send?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks these rhetorical questions to scold his people and to emphasize that no one is as blind or deaf as they are. Alternate translation: “No one is as blind as my covenant partner. No one is as blind as Yahweh’s servant.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is as blind as my covenant partner, or blind as Yahweh’s servant?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Isaiah uses this as a leading question in order to emphasize the answer that he will give in the next phrase. Alternate translation: “I will tell you who gave the people of Israel over to robbers and looters.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Who gave Jacob over to the robber, and Israel to the looters?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that Yahweh alone was responsible for Israel’s situation, and to explain the reason that Yahweh did it. Alternate translation: “It was certainly Yahweh … refused to obey.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Was it not Yahweh & refused to obey?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to teach the people of Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “surely you have noticed it.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: do you not perceive it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that there is no one like him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “If anyone thinks he is like me, let him announce” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is like me? Let him announce

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he is the one who predicted the events that have now happened. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. The word “announced” means basically the same thing as “declared.” Alternate translation: “I declared these things to you long ago.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Have I not declared to you long ago, and announced it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question again to emphasize that there is no other God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “There is no God besides me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is there any God besides me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is using this question to rebuke those who make idols. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Only fools would form a god or cast an idol that is worthless.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who would form a god or cast an idol that is worthless?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh says that these people should be asking themselves these rhetorical questions. The questions anticipate negative answers and emphasize how foolish it would be for a person to do these things. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the idea behind these questionsas statements. Alternate translation: “I should not now make … something disgusting to worship. I should not bow down to a block of wood.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Now should I make & something disgusting to worship? Should I bow down to a block of wood?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke those who argue with him about what he does. Alternate translation: “The clay should not say to the potter … on it!’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Does the clay say to the potter & on it’?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The unborn child asks these rhetorical questions to scold his parents for giving birth to him. These can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: “You should not be my father … You should give birth to me.” or “You are not fathering me correctly … You are not giving birth to me correctly.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: What are you fathering? & What are you giving birth to?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to scold those who argue with him about what he does. Alternate translation: “Do not question me about what I do for my children. Do not tell me … my hands.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you ask questions about what I will do for my children? Do you tell me what to do concerning the work of my hands?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that he was the one who told them these things would happen. Alternate translation: “I will tell you who has shown this from long ago. I will tell you who announced it. It was I, Yahweh.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has shown this from long ago? Who announced it? Was it not I, Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that there is no one like him. Alternate translation: “There is no one to whom you can compare me. I resemble no one, so that we might be compared.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: To whom will you compare me? Who do you think I resemble, so that we may be compared?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people of Israel for not admitting what they should know is true. Alternate translation: “you are stubborn and will not admit what I said is true.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: will you not admit what I said is true?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that he can never allow his own name to be dishonored. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “for I cannot allow anyone to profane my name.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: for how can I allow my name to be profaned?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that the idols have not told them these things. Alternate translation: “None of your idols has told this to you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who among you has announced these things?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to help his people understand that he will never forget about them or stop caring for them. Alternate translation: “A woman would not forget her nursing baby or stop caring for the son she bore.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Can a woman forget her baby, nursing at her breast, so she does not have compassion on the son she has borne?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Again, Zion uses questions to expresses her surprise. Alternate translation: “Look, I was left all alone; now all of these children that I did not raise have come to me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has raised these children? Look, I was left all alone; where did these come from?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah uses a question to express the difficulty of taking anything from a mighty soldier or a very strong warrior. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “A person cannot take the spoils from a warrior or rescue captives from fierce soldiers.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Can the spoils be taken from the warrior, or captives be rescued from the fierce?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question so that the people would produce “the certificate of divorce,” which would provide the reason Yahweh sent them into exile. Alternate translation: “Show me the certificate of divorce with which I divorced your mother.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is the certificate of divorce with which I divorced your mother?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to emphasize that he did not sell them because he owed a debt to a creditor. It is implied that this is what the people had thought. Alternate translation: “I did not sell you because I owed a debt to someone.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: To which of my creditors did I sell you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant uses these questions to emphasize that there is no one who can legitimately accuse him of wrong. Alternate translation: “If anyone would oppose me, let us stand … If anyone would accuse me, let him come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who will oppose me? Let us stand & Who is my accuser? Let him come

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant uses this question to assert that no one can declare him guilty. Alternate translation: “There is no one who can declare me guilty.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who will declare me guilty?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant uses these questions to identify those to whom he is speaking. Alternate translation: “If someone among you fears Yahweh and obeys the voice of his servant, but he walks in deep darkness without light, then he should … his God.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who among you fears Yahweh? Who obeys the voice of his servant? Who walks in deep darkness without light? He should & his God.

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speaker uses a question to emphasize Yahweh’s power to do mighty things. Alternate translation: “It is you who crushed Rahab, you who pierced the monster.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not you who crushed Rahab, you who pierced the monster?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Again, the speaker uses questions to emphasize Yahweh’s power to do mighty things. This refers to Yahweh opening the Red Sea for the Israelites to cross and escape the army of Egypt. Alternate translation: “You dried up the sea … for the redeemed to pass through.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Did you not dry up the sea & for the redeemed to pass through?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question emphasizes that people who have the Lord’s protection should not be afraid of human beings. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Do not be afraid of men … like grass.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why are you afraid of men & like grass?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that they should not forget Yahweh. Alternate translation: “You should not have forgotten Yahweh … earth.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why have you forgotten Yahweh & earth?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that the people should not fear those who want to oppress them. Their oppressors are no longer a threat to them. Alternate translation: “The fury of the oppressor is not a threat!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where is the fury of the oppressor?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah uses questions to emphasize that now there is no one to weep with them or comfort them. These questions may be written as statements. Alternate translation: “but there is no one to grieve with you … There is no one to comfort you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: who will grieve with you? & Who will comfort you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to make the people pay attention to what he is about to say. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Now look at what is happening … my people are again taken away for nothing.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Now what do I have here & seeing that my people are taken away for nothing?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question emphasizes that no one thinks about him. Alternate translation: “no one from his generation cared what happened to him.” or “no one among his contemporaries cared what happened to him.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: who from that generation thought anymore about him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks these questions to rebuke the people. He speaks of the people seeking happiness apart from Yahweh as if they were purchasing things to eat that were not food and working for things that could not satisfy them. Alternate translation: “You should not weigh out silver … bread, and you should not labor … satisfy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Why do you weigh out & bread, and why do you labor & satisfy?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to scold the people who are mocking him through false worship. Alternate translation: “You are mocking me and making fun of me by opening your mouth wide and sticking out the tongue!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Whom are you merrily mocking? Against whom are you opening the mouth and sticking out the tongue?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses another question to scold the people. This does not refer to their birth but to their spiritual state. Alternate translation: “You are children of rebellion, children of deceit!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Are you not children of rebellion, children of deceit?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. Alternate translation: “Certainly, these things do not please me.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: In these things should I take pleasure?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses these questions to scold the people. Alternate translation: “You must really fear these idols for you to act so deceitfully … about me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Whom are you worried about? Whom do you fear so much that has caused you to act so deceitfully & about me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel use questions to complain to God because they feel he is ignoring them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: ‘Why have we fasted,’ they say, ‘but you do not see it? Why have we humbled ourselves, but you do not notice?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. They act like they are humble before God, but they are hurting other people. Alternate translation: “This is not the kind of fast I want … under himself.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is this really the kind of fast that I would want & under himself?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to scold the people. Alternate translation: “Surely you do not think this kind of fast pleases me!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Do you really call this a fast, a day that pleases Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to teach the people about the kind of fast that pleases him. Alternate translation: “This is the fast that I choose … break every yoke.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is not this the fast that I choose & break every yoke?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses another question to teach the people. Alternate translation: “It is to … your house.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is it not to & your house?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions and poetic images to draw attention here. He compares the sails of the ships to clouds and doves. This is also a picture of the Israelites returning to the country where they belong. Alternate translation: “Look, I see something like clouds moving quickly and like doves returning to their shelters.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Who are these who fly along like a cloud, and like the doves to their shelters?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks as a watchman using the question and answer format to present this information about Yahweh’s judgment on Edom, an enemy of Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “I, Yahweh, am coming from Edom, clothed in red from Bozrah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is this who comes from Edom & Bozrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “The red on your clothing looks makes you look like you have been treading on grapes in a winepress.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why are your clothes red, and why & winepress?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses a question to express deep emotion and concern because it seems God is not helping them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “We do not see your zeal and your mighty acts!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where are your zeal and your mighty acts?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer uses a question to express a complaint of the people to God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “Yahweh, you have made us wander from your ways and become stubborn so that we do not obey you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh, why do you make us wander from your ways and harden our hearts, so we do not obey you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: They use questions to express their frustration because God has not yet come to help them. Alternate translation: “Please do not hold back, Yahweh! Please do not remain silent and continue to humiliate us!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: How can you still hold back, Yahweh? How can you remain silent and continue to humiliate us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that humans cannot build a place for him to dwell. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Where then is the house you will build for me? Where is the place where I may rest?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize how unique this event will be. The series of questions builds tension until Zion is finally mentioned. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who has heard of such a thing? Who has seen such things? Will a land be born in one day? Can a nation be established in one moment?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses questions to emphasize that he will not fail to fulfill his promises to the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Do I bring a baby to the birth opening & born?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “has become as small as a hut in a vineyard or a shed in a garden of cucumbers” or (2) “is left the way a farmer leaves a hut in a vineyard or a shed in a garden of cucumbers when he is finished with them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: is left like a hut in a vineyard, like a shed in a garden of cucumbers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Scarlet is a bright red color. Alternate translation: “bright red” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like scarlet

contextId.occurrenceNote: White is often a symbol for holiness or purity. “Snow” refers to something like frozen rain that is very white. Since this simply describes something as very white, you could replace it with something else that is white: “white as a seashell” or “white as a dove.” This means that their sins will be forgiven. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: white like snow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Crimson is a dark red color. Alternate translation: “dark red” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: red like crimson

contextId.occurrenceNote: Water gives life to trees and gardens. The people have cut themselves off from Yahweh, who gives them life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: For you will be like an oak whose leaf fades, and like a garden that has no water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the person’s deeds or evil works to a spark that falls on tinder and sets it on fire. Alternate translation: “his work will be like a spark that starts a fire” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: his work like a spark

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people of Judah are said to be like the people of Sodom, because they openly boasted about their sins. Alternate translation: “like the people of Sodom, they talk about their sins and let everyone know about them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they tell of their sin like Sodom; they do not hide it

contextId.occurrenceNote: That is, the lambs will graze there. The land will be worthless for any other use. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: in the ruins, lambs will graze as foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: The dead bodies are allowed to lie in the streets as if they were garbage. This implies that many will die but that no one will be there to bury them. The word “garbage” can also be translated as “refuse” or “manure.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their corpses are like garbage in the streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: “their hooves are like hard stone.” Isaiah compares the hard part of a horse’s foot to flint, which is a hard stone that can cause sparks when struck. This could mean: (1) Isaiah compares their hooves to flint so to describe the frightening image of their feet causing sparks as they run or (2) Isaiah compares their hooves to flint to emphasize how strong their hooves are which enables the horse to do whatever their master want them to do. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their horses’ hooves are like flint

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the chariot wheels to storms in order to imply that they will destroy everything in their path. Alternate translation: “the wheels of the chariots will spin like a windstorm” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: their chariot wheels like storms

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that even after Yahweh destroys Israel, he will still set apart people from among the Israelites to serve him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a terebinth or an oak is cut down and whose trunk remains, the holy seed is in its stump

contextId.occurrenceNote: The trembling of their hearts at this news is compared to the way trees shake when the wind blows through them. Alternate translation: “Ahaz and his people were very afraid” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His heart trembled, and the heart of his people, as the trees of the forest shake in the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The joy that Yahweh will give Israel is described as the same kind of joy people have when they bring in a harvest or divide valuable plunder. Alternate translation: “They will rejoice before you as people rejoice when they gather their crops or when a battle is over and soldiers divide what they took” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They rejoice before you like the joy at harvest time, as men rejoice when they divide the plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Yahweh compares the army of Assyria attacking Israel to people stomping through mud who do not care what happens to the mud. Alternate translation: “trample them until they become like mud” or (2) the people are stomping on other people so they are lying in the mud and unable to rise. This is a metaphor for completely defeating them. Alternate translation: “completely defeat them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: trample them like mud

contextId.occurrenceNote: “as strong as a bull.” Some ancient texts read, “like a mighty man.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a bull

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria compares taking the treasures from the nations to a person taking eggs out of a bird’s nest. This emphasizes how easy it was for him and his army to conquer these other kingdoms. Alternate translation: “My army has stolen the wealth from the nations just as easily as a man takes eggs from a nest” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: My hand has seized, as from a nest, the wealth of nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria speaks of taking over nations as if he was gathering eggs. Alternate translation: “just as a person takes eggs from a nest when the bird is not there to protect them, my army has taken the treasures of every nation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as one gathers abandoned eggs, I gathered all the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the nations to a bird who sits quietly while her eggs are taken. This emphasizes that the nations did nothing while the army of Assyria took all of their possessions. Alternate translation: “And like a bird that does not make a sound or flap her wings when someone steals her eggs, the nations did nothing as we took their treasure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: None fluttered their wings or opened their mouth or chirped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his punishment to a fire. This emphasizes that his punishment will completely destroy all the splendor and greatness of the kingdom of Assyria. Alternate translation: “I will destroy his greatness as if I were starting a fire to burn everything he is proud of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: under his glory there will be kindled a burning like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares either the forests and farmlands of Assyria or the army of Assyria to a sick man as he lies in bed dying. This emphasizes how something so great can become weak and dying. Alternate translation: “they will be like a sick man who grows weak and dies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: it will be like when a sick man’s life wastes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that there were a great number of people of Israel. Alternate translation: “are too many to count, like the sand on the seashore” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: are like the sand of the seashore

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used to show how full the earth will be of people who know Yahweh. You may want to help your readers to understand that it does this by using words that are similar to the words in the previous phrase. Alternate translation: “as the seas are full of water” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as the waters cover the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: A banner is a flag that a king would raise as a sign for people to see it and come to him. Alternate translation: “will be like a sign for the peoples” or “will attract the peoples to come to him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: will stand as a banner for the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: A branch thrown away represents something worthless. Alternate translation: “like a worthless branch that is tossed aside” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a branch thrown away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents many dead bodies being on top of his body. Alternate translation: “The bodies of dead people completely cover your body” or “The bodies of dead soldiers are piled on top of your body” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The dead cover you like a garment

contextId.occurrenceNote: All the people of Moab, which includes the women, are forced to flee from their homes. Alternate translation: “Like birds without a home, the women of Moab will flee across the river to another land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As wandering birds, as a scattered nest, so the women of Moab are at the fords of the Arnon River

contextId.occurrenceNote: There will be nothing left in the land after God punishes the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: It will be as when a harvester gathers the standing grain & in the Valley of Rephaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: People harvested olive trees by shaking them so that the olives would fall out. Alternate translation: “like the few olives that remain on the olive trees after people harvest them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as when the olive tree is shaken

contextId.occurrenceNote: An uproar is a very loud noise. Alternate translation: “The sound of many people, that is very loud like the seas” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The uproar of many peoples, that roar like the roaring of the seas

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy armies appear to be a powerful force that no one can stop. Alternate translation: “the nations come rushing in like the mighty waters” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the rushing of nations, that rush like the rushing of mighty waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases show how quietly God will watch the nation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the simmering heat in sunshine, like a cloud of mist in the heat of harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the people of Egypt doing what is wrong as if they were made to wander about like a drunken person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a drunk staggering in his vomit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that the people of Egypt will be afraid and helpless when God punishes them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Egyptians will be like women

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the army that will attack the people to a storm with strong winds. They will be quick and powerful. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like stormwinds sweeping through the Negev

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares his pain to the pain of a woman giving birth. This emphasizes the great pain he is feeling. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: pains like the pains of a woman in labor have taken hold of me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) Isaiah is telling the people of Tarshish to start planting crops since they can no longer trade with Tyre or (2) Isaiah is telling the people of Tarshish they are free from Tyre’s control. Alternate translation: “Pass through your land like a river, daughter of Tarshish. The people of Tyre no longer have any power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Plow your land, as one plows the Nile, daughter of Tarshish & here is no longer a marketplace in Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the nations after Yahweh devastates the land to trees and vines after their fruit has been picked. This means there will be very few people left in the land. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as when an olive tree is beaten, as the gleanings when the grape harvest is done

contextId.occurrenceNote: These similes emphasize how the earth will shake back and forth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The earth will stagger like a drunken man and it will sway back and forth like a hut

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ruthless people oppressing the people of God is spoken of as if they were a storm beating against a wall. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: When the breath of the ruthless was like a storm against a wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the enemies of God’s people to the heat that dries up the land. This emphasizes how much the enemies cause the people of God to suffer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like heat in a dry land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh stopping ruthless people from singing and boasting is compared to a cloud providing shade on a hot day. This emphasizes that Yahweh comforts his people by stopping those who cause them to suffer. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as the heat is subdued & ruthless ones is answered

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how badly Yahweh will humiliate the people of Moab. They will spread their hands in dung like a swimmer spreads his hands in water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: They will spread their hands & his hands to swim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the people to a woman giving birth. This emphasizes their suffering and crying when Yahweh disciplined them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As a pregnant woman & cries out in her labor pains

contextId.occurrenceNote: “but it is as if we have only given birth to air” or “it is like we gave birth to nothing.” This is a simile that emphasizes that the people’s suffering resulted in nothing. Alternate translation: “but nothing good resulted from it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: but it is as if we have only given birth to wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “storm of hail” or hailstorm happens when hard pieces of ice fall from the sky. Here it is a simile that refers to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Samaria. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: storm of hail

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the enemy soldiers seeing the beauty of Samaria and quickly plundering it as if they were a person who sees the first fig of the season and quickly eats it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: will be as the first ripe fig & gulps it down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Translators may add a footnote that says, “The name Ariel means ‘altar.’” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like Ariel

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these statements mean basically the same thing. They emphasize that the people who once spoke with proud words will be weak and grieving after the enemy defeats them. Alternate translation: “you will only be able to speak with weak whispers like a spirit speaking from where dead people dwell” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: will speak from the ground; your speech will be low from the dust & our voice will sound like a spirit that speaks from the ground, and out of the dust your speech will whisper

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes how weak and insignificant the invading army is before God. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will easily remove the horde of your invaders and the multitude of the ruthless ones”(See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The great number of your invaders will become like fine dust, and the multitude of the ruthless ones as chaff that passes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: These similes mean that the enemy will expect victory but they will fail because God will not allow them to conquer Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: It will be like when a hungry man dreams he is eating & his thirst not quenched

contextId.occurrenceNote: The other prophets in Jerusalem are unable to hear or understand God’s message. Alternate translation: “All that Yahweh has revealed is to you like a sealed book” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: All revelation has become to you as the words of a book that is sealed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that God will destroy the people of Judah suddenly because of their sin. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: so this sin will be to you like a broken part & in an instant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that the piece of wall will break as quickly and completely as a clay jar that falls to the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a potter’s vessel is broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means there will be so few people left that they will be like a single flag on top of a hill. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: until your remnant will be like a flagstaff on the top of a mountain, or like a flag on a hill

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means they will throw away their idols like they were garbage. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: You will throw them away like a menstrual rag

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the air coming out of Yahweh’s mouth to a flood to emphasize its power to destroy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His breath is like an overflowing torrent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how happy the people will be. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as in the night when a holy feast is observed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how happy the people will be. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as when one goes & Rock of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh’s breath as if it were a river of fire that will set the pile on fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The breath of Yahweh, like a stream of brimstone, will set it on fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: “A lion … in the same way Yahweh of hosts.” Here Yahweh speaks of how he will defend the people who belong to him and not be scared away by comparing himself to a lion who guards it’s prey. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As a lion & thus Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the way that Yahweh protects Jerusalem is compared to the way that a mother bird protects her baby birds in their nest. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like birds in flight, so Yahweh of hosts will protect Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the king and princes who protect the people to a shelter. Alternate translation: “the rulers will protect the people like a shelter does in a storm” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Each one will be like a shelter from the wind and a refuge from the storm

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another comparison that means that the rulers will provide for the needs of the people. Alternate translation: “they will provide for the people like streams of water in a dry place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like streams of water in a dry place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another comparison that means that the rulers will provide comfort and rest for the people. Alternate translation: “they will provide rest for the people like a huge rock gives shade to weary people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the shade of a great rock in a land of weariness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how quick and eager Yahweh’s people are when they gather the spoils from their enemies to the eagerness of locusts when they gather food. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Your people gather spoils from your enemies with the same fierceness as the locusts have who devour green plants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Your spoil is gathered as the locusts gather; as locusts leap, men leap on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how dry Sharon is to a desert plain. Alternate translation: “Sharon is as dry as a desert plain” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Sharon is like a desert plain

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how the peoples’ dead bodies will be burned to the way thornbushes are burned. Also, If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Fire will burn the peoples’ bodies to lime in the same way that a farmer cuts down thornbushes and burns them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The peoples will be burned to lime, as thornbushes are cut down and are burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes even the things in the sky that people thought would be there forever will fall as easily as a leaf. Alternate translation: “all the stars will fall from the sky like a leaf falls from a vine or a fig falls from a tree” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: all their stars will fade away, as the leaf fades from off the vine, and as the overripe figs from the fig tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the way the plants of the desert blossom to the way a rose (verse 1) has many blossoms. Alternate translation: “The desert will grow many new plants and trees” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: it will blossom abundantly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deer can jump far and high. Jumping like a deer is an exaggeration for being able to move about quickly and easily. Alternate translation: “the lame man will jump high” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: the lame man will leap like a deer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This comparison is made to emphasizes that they are in a time of extreme difficulty. Alternate translation: “It is as terrible as the day when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how Yahweh is ending Hezekiah’s life quickly by comparing it to how a shepherd removes his tent from the ground. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has taken my life away from me quickly like a shepherd packs up his tent and carries it away” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: My life is removed and carried away from me like a shepherd’s tent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh quickly ending Hezekiah’s life by comparing it to how a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom and rolls it up. Alternate translation: “you are ending my life quickly, like a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom when it is finished” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I have rolled up my life like a weaver; you are cutting me off from the loom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah speaks of how he is in extreme pain by comparing it to having his body torn apart by lions. Alternate translation: “my pain was as though I were being torn apart by lions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a lion he breaks all my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet compares the nations to a drop of water and to dust in order to emphasize how small and insignificant they are to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the nations are like a drop in a bucket, and are regarded like the dust on the scales

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet compares the way Yahweh considers humans to the way humans would consider grasshoppers. Just as grasshoppers are small to humans, humans are small and weak before God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the inhabitants are like grasshoppers before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile extends the metaphor of the rulers as plants and Yahweh as the wind that causes them to wither. The wind of Yahweh’s judgement will remove the withered plants as easily as wind blows away straw. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the wind carries them away like straw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the way in which this person will trample the other rulers with the way that a potter tramples on clay to mix it with water. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a potter who is treading on the clay

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is compared with a warrior who is ready to defeat his people’s enemies. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh will go out as a warrior; as a man of war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh’s activity as a shouting warrior is compared with a pregnant woman who cries from labor pains. This emphasizes sudden unavoidable action after a period of inactivity. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I will cry out like a woman in labor; I will gasp and pant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the magicians and sorcerers to straw that burns quickly in a fire. This means that Yahweh will destroy them as easily as fire burns stubble, and so they are powerless to save Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: they will become like stubble & he fire will burn them up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the tightness of their neck muscles and the hardness of their foreheads to the hardness of iron and bronze. Here, to have a tight neck or a hard forehead is a metaphor that means the people are stubborn. Alternate translation: “it is as if your necks were iron and your heads were bronze” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: your neck muscles tight as iron, and your forehead like bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant compares himself with a student who learns from his teacher. This could mean: (1) “like one who learns from his teacher” or (2) “like one whom he has taught” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: like those who are taught

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these refer to things that quickly and easily disappear or become useless. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like smoke & like a garment & like flies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares men to grass to emphasize that their lives are short and that they die quickly. Alternate translation: “who live and die quickly like grass” or “who will wither and disappear like grass” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: who are made like grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the children being exhausted and helpless as if they were an antelope caught in a trap. Alternate translation: “they are helpless, like an antelope caught in a net” or “as helpless as a trapped antelope” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like an antelope in a net

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the way their enemies walked on their back to the way people walk on the street. Alternate translation: “you lay in the streets so your enemies could walk on your backs” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: you made your back like the ground and like the street for them to walk on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “he” refers to God’s servant whom Isaiah compares to a very young tree. This emphasizes that he will appear weak. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: For he grew up before Yahweh like a sapling

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sheep often leave the path on which the shepherd leads them. Isaiah means that we do what we want instead of what God commands. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: We all like sheep have gone astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the servant to a lamb and a sheep to emphasize that he will remain silent as people harm and humiliate him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a lamb that is led to the slaughter, and as a sheep that before its shearers is silent

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “just as a lamb is silent as a person slaughters it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: as a lamb that is led to the slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the wicked to rough water on the shore that makes the water dirty. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: But the wicked are like the tossing sea & mire and mud

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means shout loudly. Here “your” refers to Isaiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Lift up your voice like a trumpet

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the person is bowing down, but he is not truly humble. “A reed” represents a weak plant that bends easily. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: A day for anybody to humble himself, for him to bow down his head like a reed

contextId.occurrenceNote: “A watered garden” represents abundance and plenty so they will have all they need. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: You will be like a watered garden

contextId.occurrenceNote: “A spring of water” represents a source of abundance in a land where water is precious. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a spring of water, whose waters never fail

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that because God is not coming to them, they feel helpless, not finding the right path and despairing of the future, with no hope for a vibrant life. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: We grope for the wall like the blind & like dead men

contextId.occurrenceNote: These refer to the sounds the people made because they were distressed and mourning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: We growl like bears and moan like doves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Narrow valleys in Judah were dry most of the year until a sudden, heavy rain turned them into fast-moving water. When that happened there was a lot of noise and wind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: for he will come as a rushing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: This comparison emphasizes that the speaker is extremely happy, joyful, celebrating. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a bridegroom adorns himself with a turban, and as a bride adorns herself with her jewels

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both clauses reassure the people that God will eventually come and save the people of Israel and that it will be as apparent as light is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: until her righteousness proceeds brightly, and her salvation as a burning torch

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “sons” refers to the people of Israel and “you” refers to Judah, the land of Israel. This means the people will take possession of the land as a man takes possession of his young wife. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a young man marries a young woman, so your sons will marry you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes God’s happiness about his relationship with his people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: as a bridegroom rejoices over his bride, your God will rejoice over you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the people of Israel were sure-footed as horses in open country on their travels toward Israel from Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Like a horse running on flat land, they did not stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This image pictures cattle going into a valley where there is green grass and water and emphasizes that God led the people of Israel and took care of them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: As the cattle that go down into the valley & rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This possibly emphasizes how easily God’s presence would have caused the mountains and the people to tremble. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: as when fire kindles the brushwood, or the fire makes water boil

contextId.occurrenceNote: A “menstrual rag” is a cloth that a woman uses during the time of month when she bleeds from her womb. This means all their attempts to please God fail. This sentence was meant to be shocking. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: all our righteous deeds are like a menstrual rag

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the people of Israel to leaves that dry up when dead. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: We have all withered like leaves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means their sins, as a community, are the reason for their failure. Isaiah compares the iniquities to the wind as the force for their suffering Yahweh’s punishment. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: our iniquities, like the wind, carry us away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God will cause the people of the nations to bring a very large amount of riches, which will be permanent like a river and abundant. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like a river & like an overflowing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Tender grass” grows fast and strong and compares to the health and vigor of God’s faithful people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: will sprout like the tender grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: Storms represent Yahweh’s powerful actions to make his judgment effective. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the windstorm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “mouth” emphasizes that Yahweh has spoken and what he says will certainly happen. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has spoken” or “Yahweh has said that this will happen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the mouth of Yahweh has spoken it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are synecdoches for weapons of any kind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: swords & spears & sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are synecdoches for tools of any kind that people use in peaceful activity. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: plowshares & pruning hooks

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “hands” is a synecdoche for the people themselves. Alternate translation: “their own craftsmanship” or “their own work” or “things they have made with their hands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: craftsmanship of their own hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “fingers” is a synecdoche for the people themselves. Alternate translation: “things that they have made with their own fingers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: things that their own fingers have made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the eyes” stands for God himself, who is glorious. Alternate translation: “him who is glorious” or “Yahweh who is glorious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the eyes of his glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “branch” is a synecdoche that represents the crops Yahweh will cause to grow in the land of Israel. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will cause the crops in Israel to be beautiful” or (2) “branch” is a metaphor that refers to the Messiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the branch of Yahweh will be beautiful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym “hands” represents the person who has done something. Alternate translation: “what Yahweh has done” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the doings of his hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “I have seen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eyes have seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” represents the Lord himself. Alternate translation: “the Lord say” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the voice of the Lord say

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks as if the kings were the armies they led. Alternate translation: “Rezin … and Pekah … led their armies up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Rezin & and Pekah & went up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Rezin” represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: “Therefore, Yahweh will bring Rezin and his army against the people of Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Therefore Yahweh will raise up against him Rezin, his adversary

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “mouth” refers to the person. Alternate translation: “every person speaks foolish things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: every mouth speaks foolish things

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “him” here also refers to the king of Assyria. But it does not mean God is only sending the king; he is sending with him the army of Assyria. Alternate translation: “I send the army of Assyria … I order them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I send him & I order him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “I” refers to the king of Assyria. He was the leader of the Assyrian army and took credit for what the army did at his command. Alternate translation: “I and my army have brought” or “we have brought (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I have brought

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “He” refers to “the Assyrian” which represents the king of Assyria and his army. Alternate translation: “He and his army will strike” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He will strike

contextId.occurrenceNote: The earth is pictured as if it has four corners, and those corners are its most distant places. This refers to everywhere on earth where those people might be. Alternate translation: “from even the most distant places of the earth” or “from all over the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: from the four corners of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the Assyrian king and his army. Alternate translation: “the king of Assyria and his army” or “the Assyrian army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the Assyrian

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his “heart” which emphasizes his emotions. God speaks of his great sadness as if his heart cried out. Alternate translation: “I am extremely sad about what is happening to Moab” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] or [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: My heart cries out for Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “my heart” represents Yahweh and his sad feelings. He compares his sigh to the sound of a sad song played on a harp. Alternate translation: “So I sigh like a sad song on a harp” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: So my heart sighs like a harp for Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim was the largest tribe in Israel. Here it represents the entire northern kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: “Strong cities will disappear from Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Fortified cities will disappear from Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “men” represents people in general. Alternate translation: “people will look” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: men will look

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents the people who look. Alternate translation: “they will look” or “the people will look” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: their eyes will look

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their “hands” to emphasize that they made the altars or idols. Alternate translation: “that they made with their hands” or “which they themselves built” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the work of their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “nations” refers to the armies of those nations. Alternate translation: “the rushing of the enemy armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the rushing of nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bread” represents food in general. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: with bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ears” represents Isaiah as a whole. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh of hosts revealed this to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: This was revealed in my ears by Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “feet” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “who went to distant places to live and make money” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: whose feet carried her far away to foreign places to settle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “pit” and “snare” represent all the different bad things that will happen to people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the pit, and the snare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “snare” represents all the different bad things that will happen to people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: caught in the snare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “spirit” represents the speaker as a whole. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my spirit within me seeks you earnestly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “one” refers to a mighty king who also represents his powerful army. Alternate translation: “the Lord sends a king with his powerful army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the Lord sends one who is mighty and strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lips” and “tongue” represent the foreigners who speak a different language than the Israelites do. It is implied that this refers to the Assyrian army that will attack Israel. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will speak to this people through enemy soldiers who will speak a foreign language” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
