contextId.quoteString: with mocking lips and a foreign tongue he will speak to this people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) these are a synecdoche representing anything in general that will cause destruction or (2) these are a metaphor referring to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Hail & the floodwaters

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “flood” is a synecdoche that represents anything in general that will cause destruction or (2) “flood” is a metaphor referring to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: When the raging flood passes through

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “those who are blind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the eyes of the blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eyes” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “you yourselves will see your teacher” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: you will see your teacher with your own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ears” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “You will hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Your ears will hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bread” represents food in general. Alternate translation: “he will cause the ground to produce plenty of food for you to eat” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: bread with abundance from the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “lips” and “tongue” are metonyms that represent Yahweh speaking. And, Yahweh speaks with so much anger and power that it is spoken of as if his tongue were a fire. Alternate translation: “When he speaks his fury is like a fire that destroys everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His lips are full of fury, and his tongue is like a devouring fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are referred to by their “hands” the emphasize that they made something with their hands. Alternate translation: “that you have sinned by making with you own hands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: that your own hands have sinfully made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the foolish person is referred to by his heart to emphasize his inner thoughts. Alternate translation: “he plans evil things in his heart” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: his heart plans evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the whole day, not just the morning. Alternate translation: “every day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: every morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Bashan and Carmel are represented by their trees. Alternate translation: “there are no more leaves on the trees in Bashan and Carmel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers the audience by their “eyes.” Alternate translation: “You will see … you will see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Your eyes will see & they will see

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the audience by their “hearts.” “The terror” refers to their war with the Assyrians. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “You will remember the terror that the Assyrians caused you when they attacked” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Your heart will recall the terror

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people are referred to by their “eyes” to emphasize what they are seeing. Alternate translation: “you will see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your eyes will see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is referred to by his “mouth” to emphasize what he has said. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh has commanded it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: for his mouth has commanded it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the plants in the desert blossoming as if the desert itself were blossoming. Alternate translation: “its plants will blossom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: blossom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “weak hands” and “knees that shake” represent a person who is fearful. Alternate translation: “Strengthen those whose hands are weak and whose knees shake from fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Strengthen the weak hands, and steady the knees that shake.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are referred to by their hearts, which emphasize their inner feelings. Alternate translation: “to those who are fearful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: those with a fearful heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who cannot speak. They are referred to by their “tongues” to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: “mute people will sing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the mute tongue will sing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This uses a person’s head to mean the person as a whole. Alternate translation: “they will have everlasting joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: everlasting joy will be on their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: “Sennacherib and his army … attacked all the fortified cities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Sennacherib & attacked all the fortified cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: These men destroyed the cities listed by conquering them with their armies. Here the word “fathers” refers to his father and his other ancestors who were kings. Alternate translation: “that my fathers destroyed with their armies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: that my fathers destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the messengers are referred to by their “hand” to emphasize that they personally gave it to the king. Alternate translation: “that the messengers gave him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: from hand of the messengers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that humans made these idols with their own hands and are therefore worthless. Alternate translation: “because they were false gods that men made out of wood and stone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: for they were not gods but the work of men’s hands, just wood and stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib speaks of himself conquering many things. He is actually conquering them with the armies and chariots that he commands. Alternate translation: “We have gone … We will cut … we will enter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I have gone & I will cut & I will enter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib speaks of himself conquering many things. He is actually conquering them with the armies and chariots that he commands. Alternate translation: “We have dug … we dried … our feet” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I have dug & I dried & my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. Alternate translation: “His army will not come … They will not come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He will not come & He will not come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. Alternate translation: “they came … they will not enter” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: he came & he will not enter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib refers to both him and his army. They all left Israel and returned home to Assryia. Sennacherib returned to the city Nineveh. Alternate translation: “Sennacherib and his army left Israel and went home, and Sennacherib stayed in Nineveh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Sennacherib king of Assyria left Israel and went home and stayed in Nineveh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Hezekiah refers to himself my his “eyes” to emphasize that he is looking for something. Alternate translation: “I” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “from Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: from Yahweh’s hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “voice” represents the person who cries out. Alternate translation: “Someone cries out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: A voice cries out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “mouth” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh has spoken it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hand” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “Yahweh has done this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the hand of Yahweh has done this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “their eyes” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “for they are blind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: for their eyes are blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their “hearts.” Alternate translation: “they cannot understand” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: their hearts cannot perceive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “the things that I have made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the work of my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “hands” represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: “It was I who” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: It was my hands that

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “knee” and “tongue” represent the people. Alternate translation: “Every person will kneel before me, and everyone will swear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: To me every knee will bend, every tongue will swear

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Mouth” refers to someone speaking. Alternate translation: “I spoke these things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: they came out from my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to Yahweh. Alternate translation: “I laid the foundation of the earth, and I spread out the heavens” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my hand laid the foundation of the earth, and my right hand spread out the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my ear” refers to Yahweh’s servant. Yahweh enabling him to hear and understand what Yahweh teaches him is spoken of as if Yahweh awakened his ear from sleep. Alternate translation: “he has enabled me to understand what he says” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he awakens my ear to hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding one’s face means to protect oneself. Alternate translation: “I did not defend myself when they mocked me and spat on me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: I did not hide my face from acts of shame and spitting

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my face” refers to the servant. The servant being steadfastly determined to obey Yahweh is spoken of as if his face were as hard as flint. Alternate translation: “so I am absolutely determined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: so I have made my face like flint

contextId.occurrenceNote: People speak as if Yahweh’s arm were asleep because it has not been helping them. Here the “arm of Yahweh” represents Yahweh, specifically him helping people. The word “Awake” is repeated to show that they need God’s help urgently. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Awake, awake & arm of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This uses a person’s head to mean the person as a whole. Alternate translation: “they will be glad forever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: with gladness forever on their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “bread” represents food in general. This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: “nor will he be without food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: nor will he lack bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is referred to by his hand to emphasize that he is the one who gave the bowl to his people. Alternate translation: “that he gave to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: out of the hand of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses the word “one” here to refer to all of the oppressed people. Alternate translation: “you oppressed people and drunken people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: you oppressed one and drunken one

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “feet” represents a messenger who is walking. Alternate translation: “It is beautiful to see a messenger coming over the mountains to announce good news” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of the messenger who brings good news

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “eye” represents the whole person. Alternate translation: “every one of them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: every eye of theirs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “bread” represents food in general. It is implied that the people were buying things to eat that were not really food. Alternate translation: “for things to eat that are not really food” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: for what is not bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “mouth” represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: “the word that I speak” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my word will be that goes from my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “hand” represents the whole person and emphasizes the person’s actions or behaviors. Alternate translation: “does not do evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: keeps his hand from doing any evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their “feet.” God did not allow long travels or work on the day of rest. Alternate translation: “you stop traveling and doing what you want to do on the Sabbath, my holy day” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: you turn back your feet from traveling on the Sabbath day, and from doing your own pleasure on my holy day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “mouth” symbolizes what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: “for Yahweh has spoken it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are represented by their “feet.” This speaks of them doing something quickly as their feet running to it. Alternate translation: “They are quick to do evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Their feet run to evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Take the stones out of the road to make it smooth.” Stones represent all the obstacles to quick travel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Gather out the stones

contextId.occurrenceNote: These ancestors of the nation of Israel would not able to identify their descendants because they changed so much. “Abraham” and “Israel” represent the people from the distant past. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: though Abraham does not know us, and Israel does not recognize us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the “eye” refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: “nor has anyone seen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: nor eye seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The sword” represents various weapons of war that Yahweh will use to punish those who do not respond to Yahweh’s call. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: appoint you for the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is represented by his hand which emphasizes his power and authority. Alternate translation: “I have made all these things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: My hand has made all these things

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Bones” refers to the whole body. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: your bones will sprout

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Sword” is one weapon that represents all of warfare and killing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: with his sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what the Lord Yahweh of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel, has declared” or “this is what I, Yahweh, the Mighty One of Israel, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: this is the declaration of the Lord Yahweh of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself by name to express the certainty of what he is declaring. Alternate translation: “this is what the Lord Yahweh of hosts has declared” or “this is what I, the Lord Yahweh of hosts, have declared” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: This is the declaration of the Lord Yahweh of hosts

Alternate translation: “you will not be able to do what you plan to do … your soldiers will not be able to do what their commanders tell them to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be translated in active form. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: “destroy everything in the land just as he has determined to do” or (2) Alternate translation: “destroy the people in the land just as he has determined to do.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Yahweh will lift the burden that Assyria has put on your shoulder, and he will remove the yoke that they have put on your neck.” These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The words “burden” and “yoke” refer to slavery. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will remove the Assyrians who oppress you and will stop them from making you their slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: his burden is lifted from your shoulder and his yoke from off your neck

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression suggests that the neck of the animal that is wearing the yoke will become too fat to fit the yoke any longer. This is a metaphor for Israel becoming so strong that the Assyrians can no longer rule them. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “your neck will become so fat that it will break the yoke” or “you will become so strong that you will no longer be the Assyrians’ slaves” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the yoke will be destroyed because of fatness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes something that could have happened in the past but did not. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: If Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes something that could have happened but did not. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: If only you had obeyed my commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes a hypothetical condition to explain what would happen even if those conditions were met. Alternate translation: “Even if the mountains fell and the hills shook, my steadfast love” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Though the mountains may fall and the hills be shaken, yet my steadfast love

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah introduces this desire for Yahweh’s presence in their past history with a strong exclamation. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: Oh, if you had

contextId.occurrenceNote: The mountains would have trembled as in an earthquake. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.quoteString: mountains would have shaken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “those who are poor” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the poor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the evil” and “the good” refer to evil and good things in general. Alternate translation: “refuse to do evil deeds and choose to do good deeds” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: refuse the evil and choose the good

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases refer to people who have these qualities. Alternate translation: “poor people … humble people … wicked people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the poor & the humble & the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases refer to people who have these qualities. Alternate translation: “wicked people … proud people … ruthless people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the wicked & the proud & the ruthless

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a nominal adjective. Alternate translation: “ruthless people” or “those who are ruthless” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the ruthless

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be reworded so that the nominal adjective “dead” is expressed as the verb “have died.” Alternate translation: “Your people who have died will live again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: Your dead will live

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nominal adjective “the ruthless” can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: “For the ruthless people will cease” or “For there will no longer be cruel people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: For the ruthless will cease

contextId.occurrenceNote: The nominal adjective “the scoffer” can be stated as a verb. Alternate translation: “those who scoff will vanish” or “the people who mock will disappear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the scoffer will vanish

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who act rashly and people who stutter. Alternate translation: “The rash person … the stuttering person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: The rash & the stutterer

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The fool” refers to foolish people. Also, “folly” and “evil” may be expressed as adjectives. Alternate translation: “For the foolish person says foolish things and his heart plans evil things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: For the fool speaks folly, and his heart plans evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The hungry” refers to hungry people. They are hungry because they have empty stomachs. Alternate translation: “the hungry person have an empty stomach” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the hungry empty

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The thirsty” refers to people who are thirsty. Alternate translation: “he causes the thirsty person to have nothing to drink” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the thirsty he causes to lack drink

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a person who deceives others. Alternate translation: “The deceptive person’s” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: The deceiver’s

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The poor” refers to poor people. Also, the phrase “to ruin” does not means to kill them but to harm them by telling lies about them. Alternate translation: “to harm the poor people by telling lies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: to ruin the poor with lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who are cannot walk. Alternate translation: “those who are lame” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the lame

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the dead people. Alternate translation: “those who died” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: their dead

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The blind” refers to people who are blind. They are referred to by their “eyes” to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: “blind people will see” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the eyes of the blind will see

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The deaf” refers to people who cannot hear. They are referred to by their “ears” to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: “deaf people will hear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the ears of the deaf will hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to unclean people. A person who God considers spiritually unacceptable or defiled is spoken of as if the person were physically unclean. Alternate translation: “Those who are unclean” or “People who are not acceptable to God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who God has redeemed. Alternate translation: “those who are redeemed” or “those who God has redeemed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the redeemed

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “ransom” means to “rescue.” This refers to people whom Yahweh has rescued. Alternate translation: “Those whom Yahweh has rescued” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: The ransomed of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: “The living” refers to people who are alive. Alternate translation: “in the land where people are alive” or “in this world where people are alive” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: in the land of the living

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “ransom” means to “rescue.” This refers to people whom Yahweh has rescued. Alternate translation: “Those whom Yahweh has rescued” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: The ransomed of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: These nominal adjectives can be stated as adjectives. Alternate translation: “Those who are uncircumcised or those who are unclean” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the uncircumcised or the unclean

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “wicked” refers to wicked people. Yahweh speaks of wicked people no longer sinning as if they were to stop walking along a path that they had been traveling. Alternate translation: “Let wicked people change the way they live” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Let the wicked leave his path

contextId.occurrenceNote: The “harvest of the Nile” refers to the grain that was harvested near the Nile River and transported on the river and then to Phoenicia. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])
contextId.quoteString: the harvest of the Nile was her produce

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the times when they are experiencing trouble. Alternate translation: ““when we have troubles” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])
contextId.quoteString: in the time of trouble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they have their festival and feasts at this city. Alternate translation: “the city where we have our feasts” or “they city where we celebrate our festivals” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])
contextId.quoteString: the city of our feasts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the scroll of Yahweh” means that it contains the messages spoken by Yahweh. Alternate translation: “Read carefully what is written in this scroll that contains the messages of Yahweh” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])
contextId.quoteString: Search through the scroll of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they land is full of natural resources, such as grain. Alternate translation: “a land where there is plenty of grain … a land where there is plenty of bread” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-possession]])
contextId.quoteString: a land of grain & a land of bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: “For you have left your people” and do not care what happens to them. Here the word “you” refers to Yahweh and so is singular. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: For you have abandoned your people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of himself as if he were someone else to remind the people of who he is. Alternate translation: “therefore I, the Lord, am” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: therefore the Lord is

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “you” refers to the people who live in Judah and so is plural. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to the elders and rulers. Yahweh is speaking of his people as if they were a vineyard. Like someone who fails to care for a vineyard so that the vines give no more grapes, the elders and leaders are discouraging the Israelites from serving God. Alternate translation: “My people are like a vineyard, and you have ruined it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have ruined the vineyard

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is singular and refers to Ahaz. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: have planned evil against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: “you fear.” Here “you” is singular and refers to Ahaz. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you dread

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “they” refers to those who do not trust Yahweh. The word “you” is plural and refers to those who trust Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: They will say to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to Yahweh. The word “their” refers to the people of Israel, but Isaiah includes himself as part of Israel. Alternate translation: “Lord, you will greatly increase our people and our joy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: You have multiplied the nation; you have increased their joy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here, **your** is singular. Possible meanings are: (1) God is speaking to Isaiah and “your” refers to Isaiah. Alternate translation: “your people Israel are” or (2) Isaiah or God is speaking to the nation of Israel and “your” refers to the nation. Alternate translation: “your people, O Israel, are” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your people, Israel, are

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “your” is singular, but it refers to the people of Israel. Also, “suffering” and “anguish” mean basically the same thing and are used together for emphasis. Alternate translation: “from the things that have caused you to suffer greatly” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: from your suffering and anguish

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to God. Yahweh punishing his people as much as they needed is spoken of as if God’s punishment were something that could be measured. Alternate translation: “But you did punish them as much as was needed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: In exact measure you have contended

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “you” refers to the people of Jerusalem. This could mean: (1) “Yahweh of hosts will come to help you” or (2) “Yahweh of hosts will come to punish you.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Yahweh of hosts will come to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: “sign for you, Hezekiah.” Here “you” is singular and refers to Hezekiah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: sign for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Judah. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you will eat & you must plant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is singular and refers to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you are cutting

contextId.occurrenceNote: “do not have hope in your faithfulness.” Here “your” is singular and refers to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: do not hope in your trustworthiness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “your” is plural and refers to those whom the prophet tells to comfort God’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: says your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is plural and refers to all of God’s people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the idols. Alternate translation: “the person who chooses you idols” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who chooses you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is singular and refers to Yahweh’s servant. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: have called you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: I will tell you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. Yahweh speaks of their failure to listen to him and obey him as if they are deaf and blind. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you deaf & you blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Who among you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel. The phrase “my servant” refers to the nation, as a whole. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: You & my servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “your” refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your Redeemer & your God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” is singular and refers to the barren woman. She represents herself and all of her descendants. Alternate translation: “For you and your descendants will spread out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: For you will spread out

contextId.occurrenceNote: These plural pronouns refer to the people of Israel as a single group. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your & you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “you” refers to all of God’s servants. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: But you will be glad

dublin_core.creator: Door43 World Missions Community
dublin_core.description: Open-licensed exegetical notes that provide historical, cultural, and linguistic information for translators. It provides translators and checkers with pertinent, just-in-time information to help them make the best possible translation decisions.
dublin_core.subject: TSV Translation Notes
dublin_core.title: unfoldingWord® Translation Notes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) the word “fifty” represents the exact amount of soldiers that the captain led. Alternate translation: “the captains of 50 soldiers” or (2) the word translated as “fifty” does not represent an exact number, but is the name of a small military unit. Alternate translation: “the captain of a small military unit” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: the captain of fifty

contextId.occurrenceNote: “50” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: fifty

contextId.occurrenceNote: “65 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: sixty-five years

contextId.occurrenceNote: “there were 1,000 vines.” That is, when Isaiah wrote, there were vineyards, in some of which were 1,000 vines or more each. He says that these vineyards will become full of briers and thorns. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: there were a thousand vines & briers and thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: “1,000 silver shekels.” A shekel is a silver coin worth 4 days wage. Alternate translation: “1,000 silver coins” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bmoney]])
contextId.quoteString: a thousand silver shekels

contextId.occurrenceNote: “for 70 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: for seventy years

contextId.occurrenceNote: “70 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: seventy years

contextId.occurrenceNote: “1,000” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: One thousand

contextId.occurrenceNote: “2,000 horses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: two thousand horses

contextId.occurrenceNote: “one hundred and eighty-five thousand soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: 185,000 soldiers

contextId.occurrenceNote: “15 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: fifteen years

contextId.occurrenceNote: “1,000” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: a thousand

contextId.occurrenceNote: “100 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: one hundred years

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) “join together with” or (2) “be the third blessing with” or (3) “be equal to.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: be the third with

contextId.occurrenceNote: “year 14” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the fourteenth year

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the year after the second year. Alternate translation: “the year after that” or “in the following year” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: in the third year

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is not clear whether the Hebrew word translated “Sun” here means “sun” or “destruction.” It is also not clear what the name tells us about the city. Alternate translation: “the city called Sun City” or “the city called Destruction City” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-textvariants]])
contextId.quoteString: called The City of the Sun

index.name: Making Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information Explicit
Singular Pronouns that refer to Groups
